text: The food is average at the best, especially for the price.  Between myself and my party we had the ribeye steak, kung pow chicken,  fried rice with pork, and the sea bass. The sea bass was the only thing good...oh and donuts dessert was Horrible!... I can't believe how many people give this place such a high rating.

This restaurant just adds to a perfect Vegas trip. I has the Pork dumplings which had a little spice to it, the Sizzling Mandarin fried rice and the Kung Pao chicken with vegetables. Everything from the food to the atmosphere was amazing. We had a party of 11 and were taken care of as soon as we got there on a busy Thursday night. A must on your trip to Vegas.

I was in Las Vegas helping a friend with an art show and stayed at the Venetian where I experienced the yumminess that is Tao.  

I was dining alone which some people can't muster but I keep great company with myself and tend to talk to strangers LOL!  

I made the earliest reservations possible but still had to wait 15 mins which was totally okay because while I was waiting I won $400 on some weird monkey slot machine nearby.  I told the Hostess what happened and handed her $20 as a celebratory tip which of course she reciprocated by seating me at a really nice table.

Besides referencing my fellow Yelper's feedback, I sometimes like to preview menus online before dining out so I have a couple of choices instead of randomly ordering.  Here are the choices I divulged in and all were REALLY delicious:

Lacquered Roast Pork   $12
Toro Fatty Tuna                $15 per piece
Squab Lettuce Wraps     $15
Tempura Sweet Potato     $4

(Blurb from website)
Specializing in Hong Kong Chinese, Japanese and Thai cuisines, Chef Ralph Scamardella's creations include everything from Kobe beef to traditional Peking Duck, all prepared by master chefs from across Asia.

At 42,000 square feet, TAO's entertainment complex is among the largest in the world and features Las Vegas' hippest nightclub, coolest ultra-lounge, largest banquet facility and of course, the hottest restaurant in town. This "Asian City's" d√©cor includes lush velvets and silks, waterfalls and century old woods and stones, and a hand-carved 20-foot-tall Buddha floating peacefully above an infinity pool complete with Japanese Koi.

I love the eclectic Asian inspired offerings, the atmosphere and the service.
Vegas has a lot of competition but I find that I return to this place each time.
Got there ten minutes early to the reservation and proceeded to wait 40 minutes to be seated. Left.

My first two-star review - and well-deserved, lol. 

Why do so many non-asians fall for the Asian-named, fakey Asian themed restaurants?

Could I open a retail establishment with an 'exotic' name like Shangri-La, Tao, or Buddha Bar and start raking in the bucks because Americans believe in exotica due to never traveling internationally?

Le Bistro??

Le Car????

This place is as overrated as they come. My bias is that I don't like Vegas in general, but this place reminds me of the worst fakey aspects of Vegas, Hollywood, and Beverly Bills. The real Buddha might have laughed his belly off at the vanity, superficiality, and ego-parfum of this place, or silently glided through the materialistic depravity.

I had a vegetarian bowl....about 3.00 worth of vegetables with a 400% markup, which was my fault. I read some online reviews that were all so glowing I lost my marbles and went. Lost some bucks, and more importantly I wasted another sliver of my life. Going to Vegas even for that 80 minutes, after being in Zion National Park , almost ruined the serenity I gained the during the whole trip.

The restaurant Tao has nothing to do with the real Way of the Tao, as far as I can see. It's just another trendy, forgettable, disposable waste of time and money, situated in a shopping mall!

Quite a scene here.  Consistent with other reviews, we weren't seated until an hour after our reservation time.  Which meant I dropped about $100 at the bar waiting.  As the night gets later, the crowd really pours in.  I couldn't wait to get to our table.  The amount of dudes standing around gawking at the women was ridiculous.  I don't know if the cheese dick bus stopped off but some of the people here were straight out of central casting for 'Night at the Roxbury'

Overall, my dining experience was good.  I thought the food was good considering its Vegas and everything here seems to be a knock off of an respectable restaurant elsewhere in the country.  The service was SLOW, but I can't blame our server, it was hectic in there.

I was in Las Vegas for a work event and two of my colleagues and I decided to try Tau out for dinner. 

We had reservations but still waited almost 20 minutes to be seated and were only seated at that time because my colleague went back up to the host stand. I understand that the restaurant was busy but expected that if the wait was that long (with a reservation) that the host would let us know. 

Once we were seated we decided to let the waiter (who had been there for 5 years) decide how we would attack the menu. His recommendations were spot on. We started with the spicy tuna tartare on crispy rice (which was tasty but had too much rice for me) and the lobster wontons with shitake ginger broth (wontons were light and the lobster and sauce were rich - delicious). 

He had us move onto sushi and had the Surf and Turf roll and the yellowtail sashimi with jalapeno and Ponzu sauce. The yellowtail has a great balance of flavor and while the surf and turf roll was good, it had almost too many flavors going on. 

We moved onto heartier dishes like the wok-seared New York sirloin (which was good and WAY less expensive than the 12 oz Kobe ribeye our waiter suggested), the Chilean sea bass (he suggested two appetizer portions as opposed to one main which was the same price and we got more fish), and the Buddha's vegetables. All were delicious and the perfect amount of food for the group. 

We finished off with the oversized fortune cookie which came with a fortune for everyone and was fun to share. 

Overall it was a fun dining experience as long as your are ok with sharing plates (which i am).
AMAZING food, service and setting. Loved it. Will definitely go back.  Get a reservation though - it gets VERY busy on a weekend.

Tao is the best place in Vegas ! The flavors are unmatched ! Every single dish we ordered from the hamachi with truffle sauce to the biggest fortune cookie and banana pudding was amazing. Hands down the best place to eat in Vegas

Not sure the point of a reservation because my name went right onto a list with others who just showed up. Food was good but not the best I've ever had nor particularly innovative. We had Peking duck spring rolls, soft shell crab sushi ( which barely had any soft shell crab), dragon roll, and the night's special drunken lobster pad Thai. The sushi was average and the lobster pad thai was good, but nothing extraordinary.  Service was good. People watching was more interesting than the food.
Great ambiance and nice food. Being vegetarian, we were offered good options for entree and were served promptly.

This place is great! The food was awesome. If you come here and you don't get the lobster dumplings you are doing yourself a disservice. The server said their signature dish was the miso sea bass, definitely worth trying, and our server suggested the sausage fried rice with fried egg on top, also amazing. Service was great, drinks were tasty. 

So why only 4 stars?  A couple reasons. Number one, I don't like being sold something right away. When we sat down our server briefly went over the drink lists and immediately asked if we wanted something from the bar. Nice to ask, but how about giving us some time to look through the lists you just pointed out. Or even better, how about offering some water first.  And when I say offering, I mean offering all options. Not just bottled water. It just seems like a sneaky way to get just a little more money out of me. I don't want to feel like I'm at a car dealership when I'm eating at a restaurant. 

The second reason for the downgrade was the robotic repetitiveness in the restaurant. Explanation. We got our appetizers, ther server came by and asked us if we had everything we needed and we said we were fine. 5 minutes later a  manager came by and asked us if we have everything we need and we said we were great. Our entrees came out and our server asked if we had everything we needed, we were fine. A few minutes later a different manager came by and asked us...you guessed it, do we have everything we need. Not how is the food or how are we enjoying everything so far, just do we have everything we need. Now, you might say to yourself that's not so bad. But it was just me and my friend, and all the tables of two are literally right next to each other so we can hear the interactions of all the tables around us.  We had 3 tables within earshot of our own, and I must have heard "do you have everything you need?" 15 times between the servers and the managers. It's one of those things that once you notice you can't help but hear it. 

Normally I wouldn't even nitpick over something so trivial but i also heard the other servers in the area ask for drink orders immediately and only offer bottled water.  These are all clearly restaurant policies that take away from the restaurant. I don't want to feel like a step in a training manual. All those little annoyances aside this restaurant is awesome. It's not the quietest restaurant in the world but as long as you understand you are eating essentially at a nightclub I highly recommend this place.
Delicious food. Fast and efficient service! Sushi was very fresh and all of our small plates were so tasty! We will be back again. Thank you for giving us a great night out!
A very expensive PF Changs. The food isn't bad. I love PF Changs, but for this amount of money, it's better spent on one of the many unique restaurants in Vegas

Always a good combination of food, fund and flare.  Just be sure to get there early (before 6:30 PM unless you have a reservation).  The dishes are always scrumptious, from tuna on rice, to sushi combinations to simple edamame.  And for Sake lovers, the menu is F - I - N - E.  But be prepared to shell out some dollars.

So have a cocktails (or 2) before heading to this treasure trove of Asian splendor.  Order an appetizer to share (I like the edamame, tuna...well, I really haven't had anything bad), then move into something more substantial.  Consider splitting dinner or even a few appetizers.  (You're in Vegas...save your money for the tables or the streets!)  But when you finally have to eat...skip the buffet's.  I mean, let's face it, you don't know when the last kid sneezed on it, right?  Go to Tao's an experience some zen....ah'uummmmmm.....

Very good food and great atmosphere. It was my husband and I's night out on the town just to get a late bite to eat while visiting in Vegas from lA. it's definitely a people watcher scene and a very loud place but the ambiance was incredible. The food was very good. We had the lobster wontons, yum! and 3 different sushis and the steak. I would have liked to tried the seabass my favorite but my husband wanted some beef. Overal the place was great the only negatives were the drinks were not that strong, usually on  greygoose lemondrop I am good to go, but i had two of their tigerlillies and didn't seem like there was a lot of alcohol.. also we had a reservation and had to wait about 25 minutes, but was told wait a few minutes while they were setting our table. which probably was not the case.

overall i'd come back w/a girl's night out but for romantic date night, probably choose a quieter place

(also agree w/ the guy that mentioned the tap water request, they ask what type of "bottle" water you want and if you say no they say oh ok, so tap water is fine, instead of just saying water..)

Very nice dining experience, food is amazing! For appetizer we ordered lobster dumplings and spice tuna tartar, love them both. Entr√©e we had omakase chefs choice sushi plate and Seabass, both were delicious! Price is reasonable and I'm positive that I'll visit them again for my next trip to Vegas!

Tao Fortune: "Help! I'm being held captive in a fortune cookie factory!"  I had dinner at Tao with my family while we were on vacation in Las Vegas. They have lots of gluten free friendly options on their menu and are very cautious about cross contamination. I was too full after finishing my dinner to eat dessert. However, my brother wanted to order the giant fortune cookie. Even though it's not a gluten free dessert, the restaurant did include a fortune for me. The giant fortune cookie came with multiple folded fortunes. I thought it was funny the one I chose said I was being held captive in a fortune cookie factory. #CeliacStruggles #GlutenEnvy
Great food! Great ambience! One of my favorite places to eat in Vegas! Make sure to check out the club after dinner!
Amazing. Would go back to Vegas solely for this!

Wait staff and servers were excellent. The bus boy was on top of filling our water to the rim at all times.  But, be ready to wait for 45 mins for your food - especially if you get fried rice.  Apparently, they only have 1 wok in the whole restaurant, that what's the manager told me when I asked why did the other tables (who got seated after we ordered) got their meals before us (and had finished eating).  He said the wok was slow tonight.  Lame excuse.

Love!! This place tired it a few months back and our waiter wish I remember his name he was so nice and awesome, came back in July got the same waiter, we had ordered so many dishes it was so delicious flavor and all can't wait to go back!!

this was my big splurge for food for our vegas trip... so worth it!! 

most memorable dish was the duck fried rice & raspberry chocolate wontons dessert

definately will be back for my next trip!

heard this place gets more promiscuous for latenight

appreciated the dresscode also

Exists only so you can check in here on your phone. Sceney without substance. Better food at Trader Joe's; better service from the guys on the street handing out cards. There is, however, an oversized buddha and a bunch of employees standing around in suits.

It's probably no coincidence that I scheduled my afternoon full body massage at Canyon Ranch Spa on the day that I was eating dinner at Tao. Sound body followed by a sound appetite makes Scott a happy boy (an old Buddhist proverb).

I already knew what to expect from the Tao experience, and it was a welcomed seductive relief from the Venetian's baroque architectural jitters that hit me between the massage and dinner. Feeling relaxed like Gumby and dressed in my favorite black D&G suit, I rolled into our private party at Tao with a few people on my staff...we were greeted by a friendly and attentive wait staff holding trays of coconut shrimp, ginger-chicken ravioli, and chicken ginger dumplings...I was stuffed before the main event.

Since we had a large party, we did Tao buffet style. Here is the beef & reef sampling that I picked up along the line:

- A piece of miso glazed Chilean sea bass (Delighted my taste buds. Superb.)
- A slice of wasabi-crusted filet mignon (Tender. Vibrant. Absolutely delicious.)
- Chicken in hoisin sauce (Just okay. I've had better at Saigon Grill here in Manhattan)
- Pad Thai noodles (Mildly nutty. Tender noodles. The sweet & spicy flavor wasn't balanced enough for me...hey, I'm a pad thai snob.)

The best part was the dessert. Nothing is sweeter than watching the "WTF?" looks on the faces of people waiting to get into the nightclub as 150 of us are given priority access. Oh well, sometimes membership does have its privileges. The rest of my evening is well-documented and sealed inside the Vegas city limits ;-)

I ate here on Labour day and I have to say the food was amazing. It was a pleasurable experience, I had shrimp sushi to start and  duck rice as my main...love love love!! The decor is really nice too and how many places can you think of that has a restaurant, club and pool!? :-| fantastic

Let me just start off by saying that the food was delicious! I'm so in love with the restaurant and nightclub. Both are absolutely beautiful. The menu is not pricy, it's your average $15-$35 per person depending on which dish you get. Service is fast, so that's definitely a plus!

First thing I noticed as I walked into this place was the buddha statue, can't help that as it is a really big statue. The decor is very modern and the low hanging lamp shades also create an eastern influence which sort of sets the right kind of atmosphere for an asian bistro. We were there at 6 pm and even though most tables were empty the staff scrambled to get us seated. Most of the tables had a reserved sign on them and many of them were unoccupied during our entire time there so even though we did have a reservation I find it hard to digest that it could take them 15 minutes to get us seated at a time like 6 pm. Coming to the food - we ordered the chilean sea bass satay (on recommendation by the waiter) and peking duck. Both were disappointing. The waiters seem to be in rush to get us out of there so hurried us through our dinner which was annoying. I'd not visit this place again on any future trip to Las Vegas.

We had dinner reservations at 10:15pm on Saturday (April 9th) and due to the craziness of it all, our group of ten ladies ended up at two different tables (5/5).  (Our other option was to wait until 11pm to be seated at one table; no thanks!)  Btw, dinner reservations gets you complimentary entry to Tao Nightclub, which is right above the restaurant.  A promoter gave me and my girls bracelets for free drinks upstairs from 10pm-11pm and we managed to get one drink before being seated for dinner.

The food was good as usual (see pics):
* Chicken satay with peanut sauce ($10)
* Soy ginger-glazed salmon with udon noodles ($26)
* Unagi (one for $5)
* Uni (one for $8)

May seem like a lot of food, but bear in mind that the portions are very small.  You're paying more for the ambiance, I would say. I also tried their Tao-tini ($13), which was good and strong.  ;-)

Although the initial plan was to dance the night away at Tao Nightclub, our "new friends" from Tryst invited us to Marquee Nightclub at the Cosmopolitan Hotel.  We took them up on the offer since it's the new "IT" club, and we didn't have to wait in line or pay cover.  However, in hindsight, even though we had a good time at Marquee, I wish we had stayed at Tao.

Awful.  The decor an obvious ripoff of the now-dated Buddha Bar in Paris.  Whenever I go into a place this dark, I wonder how filthy it must be when the lights are turned up.  We had 9 pm dinner reservations, and we weren't seated until 11.  Plus one star for comping us a free round of drinks, no small feat when there were 16 of us, and a round of appetizers, but only one because the food took an hour to arrive and was lukewarm and when it did, not to mention uber salty.  The quality was low - anyone who says it's any good obviously hasn't had any Chinese food that's any better than P.F. Chang's.  The only reason to have dinner here is to avoid the line for the club, but when you've got a bachelorette party totaling 16 chicks, there is really no need to wait in line anywhere, or pay any cover charges.  I suspect the reason why we wound up here (and many of the other dining patrons) is because this place was featured on the Kardashians.  Go figure. :P
My favorite restaurant before going out in Vegas. Food is amazing (especially the Chilean sea bass skewers and lobster wontons)...always great vibe, energy and great service.

Do NOT waste your time or money here.  The service was terrible, the food was expensive and for the price, the worst sushi I've had.  I've had better sushi from the grocery store.  We arrived for our 10:30 reservation at 10:40 (we had a 15 minute grace window on a contract with the restaurant and nightclub), but they made us wait 40 minutes for a table anyway.  I will say that the bartender was super friendly, which was nice considering we spent 40 minutes with her waiting for our reservation.  Dinner took 2.5 hours to complete and they KNEW we had a reservation at the nightclub afterward, which made that experience terrible too.  Just don't waste your time, too many other delicious, more caring restaurants in Vegas to bother with this place.

Make reservations!

The sushi is very fresh! Try the wild yellowtail! The rice is perfectly cooked and served nice and warm.

Toro toro roll 10/10 get this amazing roll and enjoy every last bit. 

This place has excellent music and the Buddha statue adds to the ambiance. Go upstairs to the club afterwards(no cover w purchase of an entre)!

Waited 1hr after scheduled reservation to be seated. Waiter was interested in a high priced receipt, not in being a great waiter. Food = WAY to expensive....Serving Sizes = WAY to small....Drinks = Eh quality and HUGE price tag. The restaurant itself, though, is an amazing visual display, and the food was pretty good.

This is a highly over rated establishment.  The sushi rolls are pre made for speed and the toppings are added upon ordering so the rice is hard and cold.  The hot food is good but very pricey.  There are many other options that will yield you a better value.
Great food, great service, nice atmosphere, great place highly recommend it. try the beef tartar roll, awesome. the banana bread pudding was amazing as well. Can't wait to come here again.

Tao Asion Bistro is a must from now on. A visit to Las Vegas is not complete until you dine at Tao. I went with a party of 5 and we all ordered different plates so we could share food and let's just say that we  were all extremely pleased. I don't even remember what we all ordered but it was all delicious. For around $30 a person you get excellent food and not your cookie cutter Chinese restaurant food, but extremely delicious food. The atmosphere of the restaurant is excellent, service was great, and the food was prepared quick. The day after we all went to the Bellagio Buffet which was more expensive than Tao and the food was nowhere near to Tao. Bellagio buffet was a waste of money. I would have rated Tao 5 stars but I was unhappy with the way we felt as if were being hurried to leave the place so the next party could sit.

If you are looking for a memorable meal, this is a great place to go while in vegas. From start to Finish this was one of the most memorable dinners I have had in my life. The Atmosphere, music, staff and Food make this a great place to dine.

I went for my birthday with my girlfriend, so we had reservations, so we didn't wait to be seated. The wait staff was very very attentive and truly catered to anything we needed.

The food didn't dissapoint as I had read a lot about TAO before going. We chose from a very extensive wine list, decided on our appetizers and meal and were pleased with every part of the meal.

The part of the dinner that was the most memorable was when they brought out a HUGE fortune cookie for my Birthday (I didn't realize my GF had planned for them to do that) By this point I was very stuffed, but it was such a great Idea for a Birthday dessert. I didn't feel rushed at all and was able to truly enjoy my meal.

Thank you TAO for making my Birthday that much Better.

we went late so we could get into the club for free. i like the restaurant better than the club. but it was loud and busy. definitely loud on a weekend night. our server was not very attentive but it was very busy. the food was great. my fish just fell apart in my mouth and my buddy loved her food too. we had a great time! you are close to the other diners so... never mind! talk scandalous. what happens in vegas...

From the moment we walked in and were greeted by the Host it was the best! Friendly people and a warm inviting atmosphere set the tone for the evening. Our waitress Anne was perfectly attentive and accommodating. The food was amazing and so was the service. We will definitely go back the next time we're in Vegas!.
Food was amazing! You must get the chicken pad Thai (very filling), crab cakes, peppers (app) and giant fortune cookie dessert. The food was very high quality.yes not cheap but well worth it.

Living in Las Vegas, Tao is by far my favorite restaurant on the strip. Francis Fox is one of the most personable and professional Assistant GM's I've every met and is one of the reasons why I dine here on a regular basis. The hostess greeted us with a smile and was so friendly. Tonight we had Alex as our server. He had a constant smile on his face, was extremely professional, described his recommendations (which we ordered) like none other before, and really enjoyed our evening. The food at Tao speaks for itself! The decor and music is absolutely perfect. I cannot speak enough wonderful things about this place and share with others in the entertainment and hotel industry just how amazing it is. My future clients will definitely be dined here to experience this one of a kind restaurant. Thank you so much to the team of individuals that continue to make this such a special place. WELL DONE!!

BROOKE IS HORRIBLE!! Such horrible service, the 'manager' Brooke accused us of being drunk when we hadn't drank any alcohol of any sort! I'm appalled that she thought she had the authority to say something like that to us!! We weren't drunk, we didn't have anything to drink there, we had a small baby with us, yet she was so rude as to assume we're drunk!! I would never eat there!! They have an inflated view of themselves and this was just the worst experience I've had at any restaurant at the palazzo/Venetian! I have no idea why they would think its ok to call anyone drunk when they have no idea whether it's true or not!! I immediately called my credit card company and declined that charge because we didn't eat anything and their busboy called us names!!! BROOKE IS THE WORST!!

DO NOT come here if you are looking for really good Thai food! Only the decor is nice and the waiters/waitress are polisged. Waited 25 mins for one appetizer, chicken satay and when it finally arrived it tasted more like boiled chicken. Ordered 3 dishes in the main course, only the fried rice was good. What a waste of money and time!!

Enjoyed our dinner here a lot. Yes, it's $$$ but I loved the decor, I loved the food, and the staff was VERY friendly and helpful.

A few notes: 
It is VERY loud for a restaurant. Made it hard to have conversations with business associates.
Getting to the restroom is a bit of a "chore" when they are packed. They had a table set up all the way up to the hallway door for the restrooms - with a chair in the way of all patrons.

LOVED the Duck Lettuce Wraps, and the Sashimi dinner.

We'd come here again

We went to the Tao Asian Bistro that is a celebrity hangout in The Venetian.  It is over 42,000 square feet, that boasts a nightclub, lounge and restaurant.

The decor is lush velvets, waterfalls , many unique Buddha sculptures and a hand-carved 20-foot tall Buddha floating over a pond. 

The food was awesome. Kudos to Sam Hazen the executive chef who has created a menu that features specialties from China, Japan and Thailand. Not going to list everything ordered, as that would make for a very long blog. But the highlights were the Lobster Wontons, the addictive Edamame, Filet Mignon, a Sea Bass dish that was unlike anything that I have ever had, and of course all topped off with a hot sake.

The only downside to the visit - even though we had reservations -  we had to wait an hour for a table. 

But I will go back just for the dessert - Chocolate and Raspberry Wontons served with Tahitian Vanilla Bean Ice-Cream. (Next time - NO SHARING!!).

I agree with everyone else who wrote that the customer service is terrible.  I went to the restaurant about 4:30 pm to take a look inside because I heard the decor was exotic.  The hostess said the restaurant was closed and would not let me in to take a look.  It made no sense since I just wanted to look around the corner.  A very fashionable friend of mine went on a different day and was allowed to take a look in.  I don't know what is worse....I wasn't allowed to look at the restaurant because I was there when the hostess working was a bitch or because I wasn't fashionable looking enough.  I was in Las Vegas for the HR convention (15,000 people) and told my counterparts to avoid the restaurant if they expected good service.

While staying in Venetian, this restaurant is the star of the hotel. So I went there. Entrance looks nice, have several flower filled tub. Buddha statue and ancient figures decorate the place. Chinese calligraphy on the roof. Overall, this decoration give me strange feeling. Besides, it's also a night club with disco and dancing at night, I think they doesn't match well.

Lukewarm tea water doesn't meet my standard. Food is ok. I would say that this restaurant is more suitable to non Asian customers. For Asian, with this price, we would expect better food.

A little expensive  but a great place to go for a special occasion.  Service was A+++   had the curry prawns for  an appetizer HUGE . The snapper was great also. If you don't mind a little noise ,this place rocks.

We were at Tao for the night life, and from all the crazy dancing we needed a snack, and what is this??? the restaurant is OPEN?? score!! So we ask for a table, maybe wait for about 15 minutes, and get seated. the waiter was super nice, kept filling my water up (hurray! gotta hydrate!) and he was super patient with us as we took forever deciding what to order.

Ok, so this was actually like a month ago, so i dont remember the EXACT dish that we ordered, but I remember not liking the gyoza/dumplings. I was sooo disappointed because i had been craving for some, but it was not good. i forget why, but it just wasnt. maybe it was just bland, nothing special for however much it was.

i DO remember loving the fried rice with the fried egg on top, and their phad thai was really good. 

You can also hear the music in the restaurant, i think it might have been different from the dance floor, but it was really good. hip hop music but it wasnt too loud where we had to shout across the table to talk to each other. just a great place overall.

I have to say this place was great. The service was top notch and the food was incredible. I would have loved to given this place 5 starts But, as soon as we folded our menus and gave them to the waiter someone else seemed to have come with our food. It brought the question of 'heat lamp' to mind. The food was amazing so I can't say anything about that. It is a lot of money, which is ok, because that fact isn't hidden up front, but being rushed for a quick turn around isn't good either. I would highly recommend Tao to anyone visiting Vegas, make it clear you intend to stay awhile and really enjoy the great job they did decorating and take in the ambiance. I give the food and service 5 stars!!

Great location, great menu, great vibe, great waiter, fun creative food.

For starters we did the Crunchy Spicy Yellowtail Roll and the Alaskan Salmon Crab and Avocado Roll - would have been happy if all we'd had was the sushi!  For dinner we had the coconut shrimp, the tile fish special (my favorite), a filet shabu shabu (Asian fondue) and the Mandarin Sizzled Fried Rice with Shrimp - loved it. I loved it all.....

Just go for yourself - it's worth the ride!

4 and 1/2 stars.  Based on one visit, two people.

Sort of spur of the moment meal.

Atmosphere and decor:  fantastic; rose petals floating in tubs in the entryway lend pleasing and tranquil aroma to being this dining experience.
Service: well above average; professional.
Menu: not overbearing with choices - they have narrowed the menu to a strong selection covering many bases.
Food:  Tasty, wonderful, positive, unique, balanced seasonings.

Highly recommended for relaxing resort-type dining experience.

the price is the price, its listed outside before you enter so if you don't like the prices dont bother going in.

food service beverages were exceptional

we had the lobster wontons, wasabit crusted filet mignon (house special) both were amazing

our new favorite place in vegas!
Make sure you ask for TJ when you come he is the bomb !!! Super attentive and friendly the perfect waiter !! And food wise you have to try the filet mignon pepper steak it's phenomenol !!

Had a great night at Tao. We let the server choose our dishes, omakase style. Unfortunately I can't repeat what he ordered but it was all delicious. He was from the east coast/Brooklyn I believe. Great server and great food. On the pricey side so save up for the experience.

I saw the Chilean sea bass on the best thing i ever ate, and really wanted to try it. We arrived later in the evening and only had to wait maybe 15-20mins. We started with the sea bass as a appy which was amazing! next time i am ordering the entree. We ordered the lobster and crab rolls which while good they were not worth the price. We also ordered the fingerling lobster which was really good. I didnt order any fancy drinks only because i didnt see anything that appealed to me. My husband always gets beer and thing time i talked him into trying something diiferent. He went for the sake flight and was so happy he tried it. The restrooms are really fun to try and figure out which one to go in. While washing my hands in the restroom i could hear my husbands calling me. I checked to see if he was at the bathroom door and i saw him looking at me under the mirror! LOL. There is a huge gap between the mens and womens mirrors so make sure to check this out :)

I will be adding a updated review because i will be visiting again in april.

My favorite Vegas dining experience ever.  I make sure to hit Tao every time I visit Vegas.  First off, the staff is top-notch.  They will make sure dinner is complete and make sure you don't wait long for either drinks or your meal.  Very friendly, and very attentive.  Second, the food is among the finest anywhere.  Yes, it's Chinese - and the menu names suggest you can order this from your local carry-out.  But be warned...you cannot.  The food here tastes on a whole new level.  From the ingredients to the spices, they do not get lazy.  The best is the desserts!  Who would have thought you could order amazing desserts from a Chinese restaurant?  Visit one time and you will know.   I can't wait to come back in March!!

I've been here four times and aside from a minor intoxicated mix up on bottle vs. drink service made by moi and group and small service lapse whilst sitting alone, this is dining nirvana. 

Located inside the Venetian, which already smells great, the entrance and gift shop have the wonderful smell of sandalwood. The stone "baths" greet you as you walk to the hostess station...each time I've visited they have been filled with water, rose petals and candles. I've heard mention that there may be events where Buddha nymphs are soaking in the tubs...could be urban legend, could be wishful thinking by drunken pigs. Either way, I wish I was a Tao bath girl.... 

But I digress...back to the food. Whether dining alone at the sushi bar, partying with friends, or starting at a special someone this place accommodates the mood. Dark wood, candle light, ginormous statues of the Buddha, fresh flowers, small medium and large Buddha statues abound. I have not yet had the pleasure of seeing the club - but dining here has been enough satisfaction. 

The sushi is divine and overpriced...individual order are great but if you really want to be impressed, throw your credit card to the wind and go for the "chef's special". - otherwise known as sushi roulette in Vegas. You give them an amount to spend and then wait for monster plate. The sashimi of Kobe beef (think carpaccio) is glorious, buttery, melty goodness and even better with the smokey sauce that accompanies the avocado tempura (sin on a plate). 

Peking duck eggrolls, Sea Bass meal or satay small plate, scallops...you could spend forever savoring. The sake menu is amazing and must be sampled - probably the reason I have never gotten to desert. But then again, there are great places within the Venetian to venture to for liquid desert!

If you like Asian food or sushi it's a must visit for the food and the atmosphere.  And no, the swanky couches in the front room are not for the uncool to lounge upon and think they can order drinks from - bottle service only and all that goes with it!

Omakase was very lacklustre, I was served the $58 by mistake and still thought it was overpriced.

Tuna was both oily and stringy with no visible fat. Salmon was bland and flavourless in the omakase but more acceptable when ordered as nigiri.

3/10, would not recommend.

This is possibly one of the best meals that I have ever had. We did a full on family style meal for our group. We got to try a little of everything! The sea bass is as good as everyone says. One of the best fish dishes I have ever had. The Kobe beef is amazing, and sushi rolls are delicious. We also had lobster, pad thai, beef, and peking duck. It was all so so delicious, and I was glad to get to taste so many dishes. We were all STUFFED at the end of our meal. We ended with the giant fortune cookie- AH-MAZING experience. The server had impeccable product knowledge on all the dishes. A++ for him!

This restaurant sucks. Service is crap!!!!! My boyfriend had made reservations through Open Table at 12:30am and so we got there and the hostess seated us. Then........we waited a million gazillion bajillion years for someone to take our order. We got drinks first and that took another infinite amount of time. And after some more damn waiting.. the manager person man came up to us and was like, well no one is serving you because the kitchen is closed and this isn't open seating and you can't seat yourself. WTF?!?!? You're f'ing hostess sat us down retard... And we made a reservation so kiss my ass. Then he got all pissy and that ruined the night so then when they opened the kitchen again we ordered two things to make their life miserable. Opening the kitchen for two small things. Service sucked ass at this place don't ever eat here. They wouldn't even come to us to give us the check so we just saw ourself out.


Edit: OKKKKK it says on their website dining hours for dinner Fri-Sat are 5pm-1am.. how can we get seated at 12:30 and NOT GET FOOD?!?!?!?

Excellent and highly recommended Asian restaurants. Very fresh fish dishes! Portions not too big but well presented and tasteful. Menu is served a little bit in a hurry and not at the same time for all guest. As everything in the States the location is very huge but the interior is designed quite cozy and chic. Air condition as usual too cold! Try! It's better than boring burgers ;-)

3.5 
our large group had reservations and got there early as suggested. it was pretty empty, but filled up fast. seated by buddha himself, we had the good fortune of great service. prices are from average to surreal. $16 for pad thai to $88 for kobe beef! i might as well sell my soul for those succulent strips. they were tender and tasty, but my word. $88 how does a restaurant come up with these prices? for 10 of us, the entire bill came out to almost $700 including drinks, tax and tip. i guess the whole thing was worth it because having dinner there allows you complimentary guest passes into the club later on AND you get to SKIP the monster line like you're some kind of celebrity.... when really you're just a sucker for japanese meat thinly sliced and cooked to perfection.

Iz all bout wut chyu ordr n hur cuz iz gon b a hit or miss but dis quuurl bout 2 run u sum favorzzzz. If I goin on friyay nite, make dat reservation. Dey got a nice loungin area while u wait. FURRRST uh alll, if monay ain't on yo mind, dat CHILEAN SEA BASS DOE. DAAAYYUUUUUUUUMMMMMMMMM, fish I luh u loooooong time. Iz fluffeh n flaky n moist n I gotta sey chef sho sum srious TLC, putta lottta RESPEK ON DAT FISH, PUT SUM RESPEK ON MA PLATE. He gon blessed ma palate wid dis dish. Pad Thai, peanuts on peanuts on peanuts n beanspouts n phat noodlz n slightly swt n I wud nevr git it agen. Didn't like dem short ribs too, plain n chewy n juss nawww son, keep dat meat on tha cow next time. Chinese sausage fried rice wid fry egg wuz prtty gud, if u dun like fish raw or cuked, do it. Peking duk spring roll wid hoisin sauz, not wurth yo monay or yo time. I got da shrimp tempera spicy tuna roll but wid regular seaweed not soy paper n it wuzzz guuuud. I think all dem special rollz gon b decent. Watch out fo dey cooked fudz, lotsa mediocre underwhelming itemz EXCPT DAT CHILEAN SEA BASS I GON TOLD U NOW AGEN IZ SKIVJEPAICRJW GUD. U been advised. Btw, our service wuz gud, he wuz rul nice n it wuz a busy nite n entrees took a while, but he sey sorry n I'm like iz aiite bruh n he wuz all thx gurl n I wuz all npnp. He also hooked us up wid big as yo face fortune cookie dessert fo bday gurl filled wid bunch uh fortunes inside n vanilla n choco mouse n fresh fruit. Holla atchyo gurl, wuz a gud nite.

Great atmosphere. Very upbeat. Great service. Tuna tartare appetizer was fantastic. Never will like sea urchin. Had admission to the club but didn't make it. It was worth it to have the hostess stamp our hand.

Been here a few times, always a lively and fun atmosphere. The lounge is a nice area to people watch as you wait for your table or if you have no reservation, you can eat there on a first come-first serve basis. We always get a plate of sushi for starters. The spicy tuna roll is good. Had the wasabi crusted filet w/ onion rings, decent. The wasabi was a different twist on things, but I think I can do without. Also previously had the miso sea bass with peking duck fried rice as a side, both were decent as well. Service has always been pretty good. 
I would reserve a table a couple of weeks in advance or you'll be dining late. I mean starting dinner at 11:30pm late. 
I've learned when you go to a trendy Asian-fusion place the food is going to be mix results. Sushi is usually good, but main dish can be a hit or miss. If you're looking at Tao then you heard about the nice decor. The vibe is Vegas/Hollywood glam, seen someone famous every time. If you dine here, you also get a line stamp for the club. You can impress your friends and said you had dinner at the highest grossing restaurant in the country, which Tao is. The place is more about the scene than the food. But worth checking out once to see what the fuss is all about.

Had a great experience here. Luckily, i had checked yelp prior to coming so I prepared myself and my party to wait about 45 minutes prior to being sat, regardless of our reservation. I would guess the reason for that is to encourage bar patronage, which is awesome because without it I wouldn't have discovered the blushing geisha..holy top 5 best drinks I've ever had. Bartenders are particularly unfriendly but it's forgivable as I'm not a 7 star high roller that'll tip then $100 to stare at their boobs all night. On to the meal, the ENTIRE staff was a dream. Our servers was awesome and friendly without being fake. Our busser was sweet as well and on top of his game. Unfortunately a glass broke next to us and the manger all but RAN over to make sure we were all a-ok. On the the food, while delicious, the portions are VERY small. Hence, my 4 star review.

We decided to go to dinner here after seeing a show.  It was very crowded since it is probably the #1 nightclub in Vegas and the line to get into the club was wrapped around the atrium.  We showed up for our 10:15p reservation and was told they were running a little late so 10:15 turned into about 1045p or later.  We decided to sit at the bar and order some sushi and a drink.  Both the sushi and the mango martini were very good.  We then sat at a table and ordered the Shrimp Pad Thai and Kung Pao Chicken.  Both dishes were really good and the portions were very generous.  Service was good as well.  While you are waiting for your table it is very entertaining and I would definitely recommend trying this restaurant if you are in the mood for asian food.

I love Tao- mainly for their amazing Tao-hito.  When we went to dinner here on Saturday, I ordered my favorite drink and the waiter brought out something different.  A different type of "tao-hito" with no sugarcane.  He said they took their old one off the menu and replaced it with this... SO disappointed. The new drink sucks!  Bring back the original one with the sugarcane!

Der Tao Club ist super stylish und hat auf dem Dach noch eine Dance und Chill out Area. Tolle Atmosph√§re, allerdings fand ich 30 $ Eintritt f√ºr M√§nner doch ein bisschen happig, aber naja...Vegas halt :)
Man(n) sollte sich √ºbrigens auch nicht auf die Podeste zum Tanzen verirren, da man sonst sehr schnell und sehr bestimmt darauf hingewiesen wird, dass Man(n) dort nichts zu suchen hat, da die f√ºr Frauen in knappen (!!) Minis reserviert sind. Naja einen Versuch war es trotzdem wert ;-)

Absolutely terrible.  

Reservations
Waited an hour to be seated with dinner reservations on a slow Tuesday night.  

Bar Area
Flagged down manager after 1/2 hour sitting in bar area with no drink service.  Manager got argumentative, said I was exaggerating and it hadn't been a 1/2 hour since we had been sitting there.  He was right it was 35 minutes.  Finally ordered drinks, got wrong drinks and took forever to close out especially when they don't give you a pen to sign check while walking away.    

Employees
If you like going to places where the employees have attitudes and treat you as if you're lucky to be there, this is the place.  Don't expect an apology, free app or any acknowledgement for being seated after waiting an hour after your reservation.

Food
The sushi dishes not good.  Go to some of the many other great sushi restaurants in Vegas if this is what you want.  Other dishes rival PF Chang's only at a higher cost with crappy service.  

There are so many restaurants with great ambiance and food in Vegas so don't waste it on a sub par, negative experience with a restaurant like Tao.

The front desk kept us waiting over a half hour past our reservation and treated us like we were one of the "not cool enough" people at the nightclub next door (who they clearly put in front of our reservation). 

The waiter was fantastic and the food was excellent. It's too bad the front desk was so rude. It could have been a great meal but I won't go back.

Friday 10/28/16 - OK now I can say that I've been here and tried the food.  We ordered the Yellowtail Sashimi, TAO Angry Dragon Roll, Lobster Wontons, Miso Glazed Chilean Sea Bass and Pad Thai Noodles with Shrimp.  My favorite dishes were the Lobster Wontons and the Sea Bass.  The seasoning was enough so that it's not too salty or spicy.  The sashimi was simple and had a hint of jalapeno (I didn't eat the jalapeno).  I had the Sake Flight which was not impressive.  I probably should have ordered a cocktail instead.  Overall the food was delicious but a bit pricey.  Our group of 4 people was perfect to share the different dishes.  The d√©cor is unique with the large Buddha in the center, dimmed lights (you need a flashlight to read the menu) added a warm glow to the place.  We dined here around 8 p.m., the music was starting to get louder and we couldn't always hear each other talk.  I enjoyed the 80's music that was playing.  I would come here for the experience.

Greeted by incredible decor as you walk in and are seated, you're already excited about the meal to come. Japanese, Chinese and Thai fused in a way that made us extremely happy. White tuna sashimi, soft shell crab roll, lobster tail dumplings, duck spring rolls. All delicious dishes. Our favorites however were Kobe tartare and five spice beef short ribs - OMG!!!! Of you like sake, and vodka, sake and fruity cocktails you're in for a treat. I had a sake called 'First Embrace of Snow'. A must if you live food and are in Vegas.

This review is strictly for the restaurant. I had one of the best meals I've ever had while there. The waiter was attentive and all of his recommendations paned out. We told him we wanted what he would recommend. He took input as to what we don't like and everything he brought out ended up being perfect once it came out. 

The food was expensive, but you're in the wrong city if that is a deal breaker. If you're going to go big - go here.

The food was amazing. We had sushi, lettuce wraps, edamame, fried rice, and more. We had a lot of girls with us. It was amazing I hope to get back here while I'm here with all of my girl friends. The ambiance here is sexy and beautiful. Great service and great cocktails. Mmmm

I would give Tao zero stars except it deserves credit for being a really cool looking place.  The food is mediocre, insanely salty, and totally overpriced.   The sushi is not on par with any good sushi restaurant in LA or Vegas, and the rest of the menu is like Katana's.  The service is horrendous and the attitude is a joke.

The catch-phrase for this place is "Spiritual dining, Religious nightlife". That alone shoulda been a clue.

Come on guys, just cause we're Asian and all exotic or whatever doesn't mean we invite our spirits to the table for meals or like, pray or something while we go clubbing. I mean, wtf. 

Well anyways, if you're able to get past the obvious whoring out of different Asian cultures, you'll find that the menu is made up of day-to-day plain-jane dishes dressed up and sold for 10 times its usual price. And it's not like they're so well-executed either. I'm talking fried beef udon and wonton... uhh, they sell better udon on the streets in Japan, and for a tenth of Tao's price.

Btw, our salad came with a fruit fly crawling in it. A LIVE INSECT. Our server was plenty horrified when we pointed the fly out to her, but God forbid she actually offer to give us comps for our lousy meal. She simply whisked the salad away and acted as if nothing's happened.

Minus one for the crappy, stingy service.
Minus one for lumping three different, unique Asian cultures into one shitty themed restaurant.
Minus one for charging sky-high prices for blah food.
Minus one 'cause I just feel like it.

Loud and overpriced. The spicy tuna tar tar was amazing, other than that the food was just OK. We ate here in hopes of checking out the club for drinks after dinner. Only to be told we would have to go out, get our id's checked then wait in line again to get in. What a waste! There are MUCH better places in Vegas!

I've been to both Tao Las Vegas and Tao NYC.  Same experience: beautiful swanky ambiance paired with great food!

Being buddhist, I kind of have a problem with Buddha as decorations, but in some way, I like it.    

Tao is beautifully decorated, but a huge buddha in the main dining room.  We were seated immediately, but they want all of your party to be there to be seated.  My family loved this restaurant, all of their dishes were delicious.  The miso chilean seabass and lobster dishes were fantastic.

It's expensive asian good, but they're of great quality.  I love TAO and would always go back when I'm in LV.

It was ok. 
Nice even. 
Tasty food, nice atmosphere, knowledgeable and helpful staff. 
But for the prices I expected something a lot more amazing
Oh and they charge for tap water.

My husband and I were in Vegas celebrating our recent marriage and we made reservations at Tao for dinner. We were staying at the Venetian, so it seemed appropriate that we went here for dinner, plus we heard you get free access to Lavo (the other club at the Palazzo) if you eat there.

We had 8:30 reservations and when we got to the place on a Tuesday night, we had to wait about 10 minutes for a table. The place did not seem that crowded, especially for a weeknight. Anyways, once we were seated, we told the waiter about the reason for our trip and he said we would be taken care of! After browsing the menu we settled on Filet Mignon Pepper Steak ($35) and Pad Thai Noodles with Chicken ($19) and we each had a specialty cocktail. The Filet Mignon pepper steak might have been the best thing I have ever eaten. It was fabulous. I know it was my husband's favorite meal of the entire trip. I mean, pepper steak from most chinese restaurants is pretty good, but then when you add filet mignon to the dish- it takes it to a whole new level! The pad thai was pretty good too, but the star of the meal was the pepper steak.

After our meal, our waiter brought us over 2 glasses of champagne and we weer able to choose a dessert for free. We selected the Yuzu Sugar Dusted Donuts with a trio of 3 dipping sauces. OMG these were amazing. They were warm and crispy on the outside and soft and fluffy on the inside. The dipping sauces made this dessert extra special. 

We had great service here, the decor was very romantic and I would definitely go back to this place next time I am in Vegas!

Food was great, but the venue was even better! I mean they really went the distance to dress this place up. It makes you feel like you are at a fancy hipster kind of place. Dress to impress and prepare to spend some money. Drinks are unique and tasty! I liked the lychee drink the most.

I had heard so much about this place & was so excited because I absolutely LOVE Asian food. But I'm so sad to say, I felt like it was over-hyped & over-priced.

First of all, Tao is probably one of the most sought-after, hot restaurant/clubs on the Vegas Strip. The architecture and decor of the place is absolutely incredible! The beautiful Buddhas, the tubs with rose petals, the scent of incense and the gorgeous Asian artwork is completely the opposite of the uber-modern, loud, well-decked, expensive perfume- & cologne-doused, busy crowd that it attracts, especially on a Saturday night.

Our meal had its high points. A group of 7 of us plus 1 child were there to celebrate my Mom's b-day. We tried to make a reservation earlier in the day, but were told the only one they had available was after 11 p.m. Rather, they said try coming in & waiting for a table, which we took a chance on.

We waited for about 45 minutes in the bar area for a table on a Saturday night, which isn't bad at all. We ordered some drinks & a few appetizers off what I thought was an app menu while we waited.

But once we were seated, we got the same exact menu, which is kind of limited. There were enough options & our group had a lot of vegetarians, so everyone was happy.

I wasn't super hungry -- a horrible thing that happens to me when I travel! -- so I wanted to go with something somewhat light. I ordered the Pad Thai w/chicken, which was pricier than most neighborhood Thai restaurants at almost $19, so I had high expectations. Though it came in a really cool dish that was sort-of elevated, it tasted about the same as if I had paid $9 for it at a local spot. And it was completely SMOTHERED with tasteless bean sprouts. I don't mind a few, but I don't want a mouthful with every bite.

I wanted to order the shrimp tempura appetizer, too, but the waiter said you get 2 pieces for $8 which I didn't think was worth it!

The service was good, tho, and my family enjoyed their meals. My husband said the orange chicken was really good and he would have loved some more. The giant fortune cookie dessert with Happy Birthday all over the plate for my mom was a real treat!!

All in all, I'm glad I got to experience Tao, but I feel like I was slightly let down. That being said, given the chance, I would go back again & try the sushi. It looked fantastic!!

Came here on my last visit to Vegas, was pretty easy for me to get in unlike the unfortunate "prom" dressed "teeny hoppers" that were waiting to get in. Don't mean to brag but whats all the " rage" about I love Asian food!! But this was alright on the fusion side. The dark ambiance is kind of typical too, maybe I just and higher expectations was all.

Came last year and had Stephanie as a server and loved her.  The food was amazing as was the service.  This year, the service was awful-we asked three people for silverware before someone brought it, meanwhile our food was getting cold.  Wish we had Stephanie again this year.  We didn't go back again--went to maggianos instead.

Terrific ambiance, swift and attentive service and great food- it's pretty much everything I like in a restaurant.  It's a bit on the pricey side, but worth it.
My husband and I started with a few appetizers- he had the hot & sour soup with shrimp toast.  The shrimp toast was the best I've ever tasted.  I had the shrimp tempura which was made with large, meaty prawns.  We split the pork dumplings, which we both praised.
We shared the orange chicken as an entree.  We also ordered a side of rice, which was perfect because the entree also came with rice.  The chicken was excellent and served with that green Chinese vegetable I like and always forget to look for at the grocery store.  We both agreed that the dish was sweet- it would be perfect with another spicy dish to balance it.
Loved the 20 foot Buddha and the opium pipe wall.  Hated the meditating Buddha heads on the wall behind the host desk- it looked like body parts.  We also didn't quite get the large bathtub type objects filled with rose petals in the entrance.  I am guessing it's a nod to offerings to Buddha.
If you are thinking about trying this place, go.  There is a reason it's the highest grossing restaurant in the country.  Our waiter said on a Saturday night they serve 1500 tables.

I have one word to describe both the restaurant and club at Tao:
HYPE.

I had a dinner here and there was what seemed to be a endless 5 course dinner.  The two or three staff members were great as well.  I believe my favorite part of the meal was a walleye filet.

Only improvement I might suggest, and this is for the customer, make sure your group arrives early or on time.  As the absent might delay people from eating good food and they may fill up on the edamame during a multi course dinner and those present might not even eat the good food as a result.

Tao is a beautiful restaurant and the food is very good.  Especially the Chilean sea bass it was to die for.

However the service was very bad.  Our server was non-existence.  Only came a couple of times and it took 10 minutes to take our order.

He seem pre-occupied and even when he took our order he was looking elsewhere. 

We spent $200 for two people but I had way better service at Denny's.

I wish I had brought it up to the manager at the time but we were in a rush to get to a club.  I guess it's a hit and miss reading some of these reviews.  All else equal this would of been a 5 star but service was so bad it warrants only 2.

This should be at least a 3.5 but that wasn't an option.  I gave them a 3 instead of a 4 because the food was just ok and despite being told ahead of time that we would get into the nightclub free if we dined there.  After the meal they said it was still half price for guys because it as a busy weekend.  There's not much you can do but was still a little upset that I told a table of 10 we'd get into a club for free only to be told differently after we ordered.  The waited did hook us up with a tasting menu for the table which for about $70 a person proved to be plenty of food with a wide variety of dishes to try.  The sea bass skewers were by far the best dish we had, all agreed.  The lobster pad Thai was good but the lobster was tougher than lobster should be.  I wish there was more sushi because that wasn't bad at all but all there cooked items were marginal.  I like the at,osphere but for the price there are much better options to choose from, especially if you still have to pay to get into the nightclub which was the restaurants best perk.

Loved this place...sat at the Sushi bar and the food was amazing. Service was super and staff very informed. Very trendy atmosphere with a nightclub upstairs for those who fancy it. A little bit of class in the heart of Vegas. Buddha inspired d√©cor and great music and vibe

I stayed at the Venetian for 4 nights and went to Tao every day! The first night I went with my husband just for a drink and a light snack after arriving and he got hooked on the sugar cane in the Taojitos. We met Stephan the second time we went and he is awesome! He made our favorite drinks perfectly and suggested cocktails with similar ingredients that he created himself. He is also a great resource for where to go and what to do. Thank you, Stephan!

My review is only for the club.  It's the best nightclub in LV by far.  It gets super crowded but the crowd is hype and the music is off the hook.  Drinks are expensive and cover sucks for guys.  The ratio for guys to girls are really good for the guys side, so definitely a good place for the fellas.  I don't think they let guys in unless there's at least one girl for every guy.  Last time I was here, Jaime Foxx and Diddy were at the club and did an impromptu performance.
Super lecker, stylisch und hervorragender Service. Laut ist es, muss man m√∂gen. Aber alles scheint dort so zu sein...

Went with a group of ten. Half the table got the "chef's selections" and the other half ordered off the menu. The off the menu selections were great, the filet, the strip steak, and the chicken were all great. The steaks were cooked perfectly and the chicken came out flavorful and juicy. 

The chefs selections came out in a bunch of small, family style portions, and featured everything from pad thai to fish skewers and edamame beans. Drinks were okay, the wines by the glass were good, and prices were more than fair for the offerings. Don't however, ask for anything off the menu. One person at the table ordered a grapefruit martini, and the waiter looked as though he had been hit in the head with a baseball bat, and ran off. What came to the table 20 minutes later was a glass of vodka with a splash of crappy grapefruit juice cocktail, it was horrid...Then showed up on the bill for $15+...

More things went awry when the bills were presented. The server dropped them off then disappeared for a half hour, with our table size he already got his built in gratuity so he seemed to not care anymore. We were billed 3 times for something we ordered once, and there were other things that got rang in more than once. The waiter conveniently attributed this to the "chefs selections" choice, and would do nothing to fix the bill. It ended up being $85+ per person for the chefs selections menu (those who ordered, requested to stay at the $50 price point, which the restaurant offered),

Overall, the food was good, the steaks were well worth the $35-$40, and the wines were worth the $10-$12 glass, other than that, it was a bit over done. I would go back for the steaks and wine, but would recommend against summoning yourself to the chefs menu, seems like a great way for the restaurant to pawn off whatever isn't selling on you while charging whatever they feel like.

I've been to the Venetian many times and passed in front of Tao and always wondered if it was any good. I wasn't interested in the nightclub but with such hype about the restaurant I had to try it.

The ambiance is great. Lighting was just so. The place was just as I expected. Good food, good service. Gyoza was one of the best I've ever had.

I just wish they were open for lunch.

Was here celebrating my 30th Birthday. It was way too loud and crowded, even for a Wednesday! The music was pumpin', and it just was too loud during dinner. For a club, yes fine, but I didnt like dining like that.
The service was great, and the food was all good. Had some sushi, then Pad Thai. My husband had a fried rice meal. I also got a special birthday mousse filled fortune cookie! Was really cute :)
I probably wouldn't return to eat here...

Tao is always one of my favorite restaurants in Las Vegas. Not just for the great food but for the ambiance as well. The wasabi crusted filet mignon is so good. The filet itself is great but the added flavor of the wasabi crust make it both different and delicious as the same time. The miso glazed Chilean sea bass though may be the star of the menu here. One of the tastiest pieces of fish I've ever had and anyone who I've ever been with here loves it. The spicy tuna on crispy race is great but not as good as the one at Koi (although the portion size is bigger here). If you want to enjoy a great environment while you eat, hit up Tao restaurant.

Where to begin... birthday dinner treat from the best friend. And what a treat it really was! Started off with a mix of shrimp and vegetable tempura, moved on to chicken pad Thai and this delicious prawn shrimps encrusted with coconut breading. Sipped on their specialty martini. Sweet and yummy! And their delicious hot green peach tea! For dessert the giant fortune cookie was beautiful... a giant fortune cookie dipped with white and milk chocolate with fresh fruits (berries, lychee, banana, etc). Once u run out of chocolate and fruits, the cookie alone is kinda blahh. But I loved it, I mean atmosphere and service alone won me over.

Terrible service by Sam. For a $200 meal I was extremely disappointed. The food was fine but I shouldn't have to wait 15 minutes and have to ask for the check before it comes to the table. The waiter seemed annoyed to be serving us. I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone!

Yum!  I had the coconut shrimp and it was delicious.  The dinner prices were not bad, mine was $31.00, and I thought it was well worth it.  Everything is a la carte but they do come with rice.  My plate had a large serving and I did not need anything else to go with it.  My hubby also enjoyed his dinner, he got the Kung Pao Chicken ($28).  The drinks on the other hand were ridiculous...$8 for an iced tea and one bottle of Sapporo was $12! Overall it was very good, and I would definitely go back.

The girl in the front I think her name is Cassie was a total BITCH!  She completely ignored us because she was too busy flirting with some waiter and when she finally had time for us she was rude and arrogant. She seemed to like my boyfriend though. Otherwise the service was fine but the food was horrible. Do not eat here. Yuck.
The best Asian fusian food I've ever had. Our group had the coconut shrimp, orange chicken, pad Thai, sushi, chicken ... It was all fantastic! The service was even better. I will gladly return!

This was my second meal at Tao. I've been to the one in New York and now in Vegas. It was incredible. The waiter was super accommodating and was very receptive to food allergies. My 2 besties and I shared: the rock shrimp in lettuce cups, the vegetable spring rolls, the king California crab roll, the salmon sashimi with avocado, and miso soup with a surprise addition of mussels inside. It was effin delicious- there's no other word to describe the food here. They also brought out 2 fortune cookie desserts for our bachelorette party. Can't wait to come back!

Absolutely love this place but they  seem to decline with every visit. It became sort of a tradition to come here whenever I'm in Vegas. And I always order the same thing (wasabi crusted steak and kobe beef sashimi). Well, this time the sashimi was missing the flavor, it was pretty bland and the onion rings were under way cooked. Maybe it's time to find another yummy steak place in LV.
Very attentive service, awesome decor, however the food was just OK and certainly not worth the price.
Delicious food (sea bass melts in your mouth!) and good service overall but quite busy and loud, with tables VERY close together. You definitely know you are on the strip when the check comes!

Got the roasted Thai Buddha chicken...huge portion however it only comes w veggies, no rice! Cheapest side of fried rice is $13 (but it was a huge portion). Those two combined with a beer and my meal was over $60 after tip. Ouch ...BUT food was really good! IF it was a bit cheaper I would give it 5 stars.

I thought the food was great. I had the grilled yellowfin tuna, which was extremely flavorful, albeit slightly too grilled than I would have liked. The edamame appetizer was really really tasty. My friends had the miso-glazed chilean sea bass, lo mein, soy ginger salmon and a few sushi rolls. Overall, everyone was pretty happy with their dishes. I'm definitely satisfied with the portions...was happy to see they didn't serve bite-sized pieces on expansive white plates....the portions were large enough to fill.

The waiter was snooty, but he kept our water glasses filled. The restaurant is  also really loud. I sat at a table for 7, and I could barely hear the person talking one seat away from me.

I'd probably go back for dinner next time I'm in Vegas.

KEVIN, the manager, destroyed the experience . Treated us with disrespect as if we were his employees . Hospitality should be about putting the client first and he actually raised his voice and said he didn't need us there. Do not come here if you want good service !!

Amazing food, our waiter was fantastic and the manager we talked to was great. Only negative was the hostesses who were fairly rude. Would recommend to anyone heading to Vegas. Chinese sausage was divine and the drinks were delicious.
Quick entry to the night club after dinner was a big plus.

Get a booth near the sushi bar as it gives you a great watching spot. They move fast to get tables seated and get you out of there unless you get a bottle of sushi or any wine. The food is good and on Thursday's apparently turns into a happening spot. The line is freaking long so to avoid that, get in at around 9:30 and get your dinner to end at 1030ish and find the hostess to stamp your hand and enter the club and get down and dirty.

I wish there was a way to give it a negative number of stars.  I have been to the Tao NY location and loved their giant fortune cookie dessert!  I can't tell you that the food itself or drinks were memorable but I did want to check out the Vegas location so I made a reservation.

Boy, did I make a mistake. My friends and I arrive right on time and are told that even w/ reservations, everyone waits 30 mins.  So we asked them how long we would have waited if we didn't have reservations.  Apparentlly, they didn't have our reservations although I had made the reservations w/ them directly that day.  Strike one from the host who was the rudest man on earth.  He must have taken too many "cool pills" since he had something up his ass!

Then, while we wait for our reservations they screwed up at the bar, my friends and I are given a cocktail menu that we ordered off of.  We ordered one round of drinks that clearly stated that it should have been about $30 + tip for drinks.  We get the bill and it says $60.  When I point the mistake out to the server (while clearly showing her the menu we were given), she is so dumb that she mentions that we also got a Diet Coke in addition to our 4 drinks!  So the Diet Coke accounts for the $30 difference?  What a moran!  When I asked her to bring out the manager as she clearly did not have one brain cell, the  server started giving me an attitude.  After a 10 min. wait for the "manager", I was told that they had given us the wrong menu w/ incorrect prices.  Apparently, the bill was supposed to be $60 although the menu THEY gave us said it was supposed to be $7 each.  We were not given an apology for the mistake or anything!  

Because I have worked at a restaurant and currently work in advertising, I know that good customer service would have included an apology for THEIR mistake and then an offer to honor the lower price.  No such thing was done so I demanded a talk w/ the manager.   

Only after I bitched out the manager did she apologize for the mistake and correct the bill for our 1 round of $30 drinks!  This after making us deal w/ this and completely ruin a fun night out!  After such horrible service, we were told our table was ready (as if we were LUCKY to be given our table 40 mins after our reservation time!).  We told them that we would not be dining there.  We didn't want to give this establishment any of our money!

We gave them a piece of our mind and walked out w/ the glasses in hand! 

This pompousness and outright HORRIBLE customer service ruined our evening.  We ended up eating at the casual Asian restaurant in the venetian as we were so hungry by this time that we couldn't wait to try to find another "trendy place".  It turned out to be a good decision as the food was good and we got great service!  The best part, we ended up spending probably 1/6th what we would have spent at Tao.  I would have paid for a great meal, great service at Tao but the point that they would not quickly resolve the issue from THEIR mistake made me furious!  

Tao, get your act together!  If you went to a store and they clearly had the wrong price marked on a sweater or in their ad, they should honor the lower price.  Same goes for the menu you gave us!  I will NEVER go to this location again!
Oh what FUN it is to dine at this cool place! The expected Vegas atmosphere.

Deem light, very romantic.... Food is great, pricy but its Vegas so who cares. 
It's not a lounge type restaurant 
I tried couple of their dishes- they were all good.
Excellent service and obviously, the food was spectacular. Our waiter answered all questions and was extremely knowledgable of almost every menu item.

Went to Tao for dinner with my wife on Thurs nite, waited at the lobby area where they have some comfy couches. Ordered the Taotini which was excellent n the waitresses serving drinks are hotties!! Had the Chilean Sea Bass for main course which was superb! My wife is veg & ordered a few things off the menu but none of the veg items were good unfortunately. Go with the Chocolate Zen Parfait for dessert....it so rich n delicious! The waiter offered to get us in for free at the Tao nightclub n we didn't even have to wait in line. Totally worth it!
Food is great and one of the best atmospheres in LV for a restaurant.  Check out the nightclub after dinner!

The good: service, beautiful, stylish restaurant.  
The bad: music from nightclub is a distraction, soup and food was cold, vegetables, soup and Thai noodles were  bland and tasteless.  Expensive for what you get.  You'd be better off at Pei Wei 's or PF Changs.  Unless you are young and headed to the adjoining nightclub don't waste your money here.

We had a little bit of everything, and I don't remember it all, but what I do remember was this was some of the classiest chinese food I've had, lol. Well, classiest asian cuisine I've had for sure-- lots of good food and good service. 

Also free admission to TAO's club afterwards, if you're 21+. 

I didn't have to pay so that may have affected my experience, but overall it was gorgeous and I enjoyed it.
the food are good?but I got two lucky cookies both says:"lose money on strip poker"??DAMN!

Exceptional food and exceptional atmosphere.
The Rib eye is absolutely magical, fish is also great.
Fried rice with crab is good.

With all the hype I though we were just paying for the ambiance at Tao but the flavors were bold and delicious! We made reservations and we had no problems getting in on a friday night (even with reservations some end up waiting)  Half of us went towards the towards the Noodle dishes the other half got rolls. Personally I don't think its worth getting rolls The Lo Mien was bad ass the Pad Thai was unlike any other i have tried we loved it.  We had the Sweet potato tempura as the appetizer it was nice. The drinks however were not. the Tao-tini (I had to go there wanted something lighter) was just bad another person in our party got the lemon grass something and he didn't like that much either. The prices are so fair its ridiculous. Noodles ranging from 14-20 dollars. The Desert was sexy we got a big fortune cookie stuffed with Chocolate cream on one side and vanilla cream on the other It was hot. The best part is we got comp admission to tao night club and didn't even have to wait in line and honestly admission alone would have been the price of our tab. Tao is defiantly a Must!

I went to Tao with three friends and we were very disappointed in our experience.   We were rushed through the entire meal.  The server kept hovering around the table to take our order even though we were just seated.  After we placed our order, he forgot to bring one of the appetizers.  Then, our entrees were brought out before we finished our appetizers.  We were asked about dessert before the table was cleared.  It is unusual for four women not to want dessert, but we were just not up for any with the remains of dinner in front of us.  We did like the atmosphere.  The food was good, although I wish my meal, the Roasted Buddha Chicken, was a larger portion.  Overall, we were really looking forward to a nice night and meal, and Tao did not measure up due to service issues.

Very average food for upscale pricing. I had some sushi and the duck which was recommended to us. Needless to say the duck was below average and the sushi was average. The service wasn't bad but average.  If you like dark places where you can barely see who you are with this would be a nice place for you. I will not be going back here. I can get better Asian food for more than half the price down the street to Chinatown.

Lisa:  this place is totally not worth the price tag.  we ordered 4 appetizers, four entrees, and one dessert for about 90 per person.  if the food was good, i wouldnt mind, but it was simple overpriced mediocre food.  meat  and fish was dry and flavorless.  the only this that was good was the kobe tartar and the hotpot soup.  dessert was nothing special.  they blended their nightclub and restaurant together, so it was super crowded and we couldnt distinguish the line for the club and restaurant.  the super loud techno music made it extremely hard to hear our waitress.  presentations were nice and the restaurant itself was really pretty.  you're basically just paying for the view

Best Sea Bass ever. 
I just wish that I knew the recipe so that I can cook it for myself every other time. 
Every time I wish that I could go to Vegas just to have this.

That is how good it gets.

The food was 3.5 stars, the service was 3 star, but the management is easily one of the most racist teams I have come across. Buyer beware, they cater to a certain type of people, and if you aren't that, you aren't a priority,

Hey Tor, you must have been there at an off night.  I've been to Tao Vegas a handful of times and Tao New York once, and never been disappointed.  Food was always awesome, both hot and cold dishes.  Great Kobe beef, great fresh sushi, great lobster and seabass appetizers.  My mouth is watering thinking about it.  Service is always outstanding and you can always request best seat in the house.  It is pricey, but worth it.  Great music, great drinks, great food and great "scene and be seen" place.  Dress to kill and be ready to have a great time.   Not sure why it's not a 5 star for me, but damn near.

Mischung aus Bar, Restaurant und Club. Derzeit wohl die absolute "in- Location, deshalb unbedingt vorher reservieren! Ging in unserem Fall ganz einfach √ºber den Concierge des Hotels. Das Essen war grandios (Sushi Sashimi), wirklich selten so lecker gegessen. Das Ambiente ist zwar super stylish, allerdings ist der Ger√§uschpegel extrem hoch. Wenn man damit leben kann, TOP!

Best Asian food I've ever had.
