They literally treat you like kings, My glass of sake, water or wine was never empty and I didn't lift a finger, I used about 18 forks, 13 spoons, and 12 knives just from my meal alone, and never had to ask to have it picked up or to have a new one. It was ridiculous in the best way. I've been to 5star  restaurants in London and Melbourne that don't treat you this well. Will definitely go back, but bring a large group and bring your wallet. lol

One of Japanese sushi chef was so embarrassing.. The way he talks makes us want to leave the restaurant.
Very dissapointing management.

Food was just ok. Another salty Asian dish you can eat anywhere. I would not come back for this service and the food.

Disaster. One of the worst restaurant experiences I have ever had. Complete cluster trying to get my 9:00 reservation seated.  I wouldn't let my dog eat here. Hostess are rude and useless only to be coupled with managers that have no regard for customer service.  Thank you for ruining my birthday.
Wow! Delicious! My absolute favorite restaurant out of all the places in Vegas! Vegetable dumplings! Snapper, and chicken/rice plate- amazing!

food was okay but service was blah.  i've never been told no so many times.  ordered two entrees each for the table.  normally they would put one on each end of the table , they didn't, made the request was ignored twice and finally insisted the third time around with some convincing along the way..ridiculous.  we spent a good amount of money here and the staff just made it unpleasant..unfortunate but then again tao has just been around forever and so maybe just relying on its name and club to stay relevant.  skip it and find better sushi elsewhere.

Very cool atmosphere. LA type reservations though. Reservations: 10:00. Seat time 10:50. Very nice with the decor and dj's. Good music. Good apps. I recommend the Thai Shrimp app. The Filet with noodles was too peppery but everone who had the most popular miso fish came to conclusion: Delicious.

Alexander was the absolute best waiter we've ever had. Goes by Zander- most impressive service ever. Food was great as always, his suggestions were phenomenal and he set the tone for a wonderful night. Love Tao love Zander!

This place is absolutely beautiful. There's a huge lot up bar with a lounge area when you enter and the restaurant is just immense. Make a reservation if you're going with a group and ask to be seated near the huge Buddha; it makes for some great photos. I was with a large group and tried a bit of everyone's dish so I think it's safe to say that everything is delicious here. My favorite is the pad thai. A bit pricey but what isn't pricey in Vegas? This is the place to be for dinner.

There is a bit of hype when it comes to Tao. From the west coast to the gulf coast when people talk about going to Las Vegas someone always says Tao is a great place...so kudos on the marketing guys. 

There are, however, two sides to this coin. The food side is not extraordinary rather it is very good and very well plated. Not adventurous with the menu and the tastes as one would imagine an expensive highly touted restaurant would be. The best thing by far on the menu was the fortune cookie dessert. Holy moly it is the one thing that saved an otherwise typical experience at an westernized Asian restaurant. The fortune cookie dessert with the different chocolates littered with the fresh fruits is by far the best thing I ate all day. 

The club...well the decor and the ambiance make it the great place that people talk about all the time. The drinks stand out better than most clubs in high priced casinos. Ultimately, it is a trap for first time Las Vegas visitors. 

Stick with the restaurant side.

Plan on spending a little money here to experience it all. We had the pleasure of being served by Jeffrey.  He was so knowledgable and made every dish we asked about a "must" to try.  We were not disappointed at all!  He knows his job well and is delightful.  The service and atmosphere and food were top notch.  Will definitely go again!

A must try. Jewel in the bunch of restaurants in between the Venetian / Plazzo. Tried Chilean Sea Bass, very very tasty. Tried lobster dumplings again very tasty and juicy. Dessert selection is very good. Cocktails are a bit expensive side as compare to wines but they are all worth a try.

Must go!!

Ate here for my 21st birthday! The decor was amazing from the tubs filled with flowers at the entrance to the giant Buddah in the main dining room.

Dinner was comped thanks to our awesome promoter Thisoo, so the menu was pre-selected. Everything tasted incredible from the edamame to the dumplings to the fried rice.

We had 1 round of shots which were good(I think they were lemon drop) and 1 drink each. I got the tao-tini and I hated it, but that's personal preference! The drinks the other girls got were great.

Dessert was the giant fortune cookie with white and dark chocolate mousse inside and that was to die for. Not too sweet, and enough for all 6 of us.

Our servers were so friendly and accommodating! The only issue I had was that it was so loud inside, I couldn't hear my servers talking unless they were basically screaming in my ear. Overall a great experience and would def recommend :)

Hostess could use a lil help with customer service, other than that the waiter was great, definitely made up for the hostess lack of customer service.  The ambiance is hip and music is loud.  Good place to hang out for birthday, bachelor, bachelorette or girls/guys night out.  Food is really good.  My favs are the sea bass, Kobe beef  sashimi and anything on the sushi menu.

I have wanted to eat here for years, but never had until recently. The atmosphere is great. Dim lighting, asian decor, loud music. Our waitress was nice, we tipped her like she was fabulous! The sushi was so so. I love spicy tuna and theirs was mushy. Also we ordered a surf n turf sushi and it wasn't my thing. The warm meat just threw me off I'm not used to that. Wait, actually I love deep fried sushi rolls! So I guess I just wasn't into the surf n turf roll. We did get a raspberry mousse dessert that was Delicious!!!!

I remember really liking this place years back, but I was underwhelmed during my latest experience. The food and drinks were just okay. I ordered the salmon special, which was recommended by our server, only to find out that they were out of it. Everything I tasted was a bit too sweet. My colleague ordered some sort of dish that had inedible peppers in it. They were very tough and hard to chew, but there were literally dozens in his dish. There are so many great dining choices in Vegas that I doubt I will be rushing back to TAO anytime soon.

Yes, I came back - and yes the kimchi fried rice was as good as I remembered. Everyone enjoyed their food. The missing star is for the loud r&b music and the busboy who started wiping down our table before we left.

I've been here many times and always had a good experience but last night was just ridiculous. I came here for work and took a client for dinner. The service was slow and I noticed on my bill they charged me $8.00 for TAP WATER! I called the manager over and I asked since when does anyone charge for tap water? His answer to me was "oh we didn't think you would realize it" and took it off the bill. I find it insane that they even tried to charge me for water they poured from the sink. The answer from the manager was just rude and not professional. At least apologize and offer dessert for trying to scam me. Another thing is how it was done in front of a client of mine. What the hell kind of service is this. I paid $250 dinner and they are this cheap to charge us for tap water. This is the biggest joke and I will never come back here. I stay at palazzo every time and I come here 8-10 times a year. They have lost my business and I'll never recommend anyone to deal with a prick manager and cheap place.

Aside from it's beautifully decorated ambiance, the food was a hit and miss. The fried rice with Chinese BBQ pork is a must try. The Pad Thai was extremely mediocre. Their vegetable bamboo dumplings were pretty decent if you are looking for something simple and vegetarian. The Peking Duck was nothing special. The wrapper that came were very disappointing: too dry like they were left out in the air for a while. I liked the coconut shrimp, but it was a bit too sweet. Chicken with Bakchoy was very boring. It wasn't tender or flavorful. Again, I love the ambiance, it was designed with taste and thought. It's more of a place for drinks and little appetizers.

OMG AMAZING!  we went as a group of 9 people.  we all ordered drinks and the waitress was really helpful in helping us decide which ones to choose.  for appetizers we had the spicy yellowtail roll and some scallop/lobster roll, gyoza, and some fried triangle thing.  the sushi rolls and gyoza were my favorite.  the triangle thing was good but it wasn't as good as the other appetizers.  i specifically ordered the sand pot lobster and other seafood.  it was good.  i tried my friends Chilean sea bass and it was delicious.  i only had a piece but it was perfect.  i would definitely recommend it!  the only thing is that it's kinda dark and after a certain time the music starts to get clubby.

the atmosphere is terrific, but it is advertised as a 'spiritual' experience. Yet they played top classic 40 music. Totally killed the vibe of an asian bistro. Food was also very bland. And service just ok.
Food was really good and service was friendly. We went in for a simple dinner and sat at the bar..would do it again.

Amazing food. This is an upscale restaurant but with prices that are perfectly reasonable. There was a great selection of upscale Asian dishes.

I loved the ambience, but it was extremely loud. Like much louder than I am accustomed to even when it comes to vibrant "trendy" restaurants. But overall I definitely plan to go here again.

Though the service was average and no celebrities were anywhere to be found, the food at Tao was delish! 
 
We arrived 10 minutes before our reservations and were seated right away. The ambiance was cool and sensual but the decor was a bit too busy- not very zen. The 3-story Buddha was beautiful, though. A definite keeper.

Our meal was delicious. My only complaints are that 1-the sushi we ordered came with cucumber when the waiter said it came with avocado, and neither one of us like cucumber, and 2-no cream cheese...I LOVE cream cheese in my sushi! So, that made me a little sad. 

Other than that, it was an overall nice experience.

Disappointing at most every level. The ambiance is good, but the service is awkward - multiple servers asking you if the food is good.  The food... simply disappointing.  I had the sea bass - disgusting - doused in butter and some terrible sauce. I just wanted the bill so that I could watch Love with some popcorn.
it was fine! cocktails were good--especially the skinny margarita. they have decent gluten free options but i just wasn't super impressed overall. it still feels like you're just eating in a club.
Delicious. Great fried rice, great fish. Would def. come back, especially if it was a bit less expensive! wink wink

If I could give no star I would but the service made my night. We make a reservation at 10:30 and she told us that it would take 5 minutes. That 5 became 10 then 15 then 5, we sat at 11:45 yeah i was so upset and disappointed we had Josh as our waiter and kinda make it up for it very nice and took time with us 
But in general I would never go back very trashy too not worth my money

SKIP IT!

Food was average at best, it's just another trendy restaurant that caters to people who want to be cool!

I'll bet you don't find any locals in here, service is bad, food is bland, lukewarm, and wayyyyyyyy overpriced!!!

SKIP IT!!!!!!!!

I've been coming to Vegas for 22 years and entertaining clients for dinner all those years.  The hostess staff at Tao is inefficient and rude. I've never gone to a restaurant where I had reservations that made those costumers wait 20 minutes in line to "check-in". I did tell them it was but professional but I got a "talk to the hand" attitude. 

Then when the "beeper" they gave us notified us the table was ready the staff challenged me that ally party of seven were actually present. She was wrong and "allowed" us to be seated without apology. 

Look, I'm not going to argue with front-of-house staff but it was embarrassing (for them and management) for the way they acted. 

Wait staff was excellent - if not stretched thin. I will not return.

The decor is nice,  great service,  great music and a fun vibe.  I was expecting a little more from the food.  I got the spicy tuna on crispy rice and the chicken Popsicles. The food along with my $20 cocktail were average.  I would say it's a good place for groups but I wasn't overly impressed.  Manage your expectations and give it a shot.

The only thing I really liked about this place were the drinks and the atmosphere. It's a see-and-be-seen kinda place which I knew to expect. Three of us waited 1 hour on a Monday night to eat here, which wasn't really a problem since we sat at the bar for that hour, but it was also 10 PM!! We made friends with the bartender who was a really cool, down to Earth girl who shared stories of celeb sightings and poured plenty of alcohol in our drinks to make them worth $15 (she also told us about the bizarre rules that Tao had for their staff, only to be expected at a hot Vegas spot). By the time we got seated it was clear that our waitress was either exhausted or could not handle the amount of tables she had because frankly - she sucked. She forgot drinks, forgot to put in orders, took 20 minutes to bring over the check, and wasn't even friendly or apologetic. I sampled a few things - the duck spring rolls which were ok, the coconut shrimp which were decent but nothing to write home about, and some sushi and sashimi which was again - just OK. Anything else we had was not memorable. Like I said at the beginning, the drinks were fabulous but obviously pricey - hey it is Vegas! But I could've drank the "Geisha Girl" martini all night. I definitely won't be back there to eat but would consider going for a few cocktails or hitting the nightclub.

Best. Asian Fusion. Restaurant. Of. My. Life. ( ! )

Tao Restaurant is located inside Venetian and has such a decadent interior, with red and dark hues and Buddha statues everywhere. I find absolute culinary perfection at Tao Restaurant, and I will be more than happy to explain why.

My three girl friends and I decided to spend New Years Eve together. But what can we do when NYE is in less than 36 hours? Where we go that isn't too far from home, yet not so close? Where can we party til the sunrises? 

SIN CITY! 

*Ding, ding, ding, DING!*

Who would have known the four of us were locked, loaded, and ready to go within 12 hours after saying yes. After three and a half hours of driving, we finally arrived.  we made managed to sweep dinner reservations just a few hours beforehand. After we finished dolling up for the big night, we spent the next hour finding parking at the Venetian parking lot. The staff was kind enough to hold our reservations, even though we were 30 minutes late. 

When we got to the restarant, we were greeted by a female hostess, who seated us immediately. She was HAWT (full blown double dees and a badonkadonk). We were given warm towels to wipe our hands and given menus. We started off with a Satay of Chicken with Peanut Sauce ($10) as an appetizer.

Please do yourself a great favor and order these two items:

- Crispy Filet of Red Snapper with Spicy Thai Peanut Sauce ($29)
- Miso Glazed Chilean Sea Bass with Wok Vegetables ($34)

Both plates were cleaned completely. If I was home alone, I would have licked the plates off. 

Shame on you if you don't try these two dishes out!

In my 23  years of existence, I have never EVER ordered fish from a restaurant because I was born a lean, mean, meat-eating machine. However, after my wonderful experience at Tao, I've opened up my palete and ventured into fish entrees.

One of my friends ordered the Wasabi Crusted Filet Mignon with Tempura of Onion Rings ($36), which is just okay, but not nearly as delectable as the sea bass and red snapper. I'd have to delete one star for that because at that price, I would expect it to taste better. 

All of the cocktails are $12.5. Try the Blue Zen (Cruzan Citrus, Malibu Rum, Blue Curacao, Pineapple Juice).

The desserts range from $9-12. Our waiter highly recommended the Giant Fortune Cookie (filled with white and dark chocolate mousse). Four people can share this. 

Every bite of the red snapper, sea bass, and giant fortune cookie were sensually pleasing to the palette. The only words we can utter were "mmms" and "ahhhs" throughout the entire meal. 

I have yet to try the sushi the next time I come here again. Hopefully, it will be soon.

Not worth it for the money. This was basically a upscale Chilis. It was over crowed and loud for dinner. The service was okay at best. I made a reservation for a birthday dinner a week in advance and when we arrived we were given a beeper and asked to wait. Really??? What was the point of the reservation then? I also find places that have bathroom attendants to be tacky. The decor was nice but that's about it. Good wasn't anything special , don't spend your money going here it's better spent else where

I have dined at Tao in New York on several occasions.  This is not the same experience.  The food was reminiscent of what you could expect at a mid-level chain with higher end pricing.

I ordered a filet and my wife had scallops.  The steak was way overcooked and so salty I could barely eat a few bites.

The table behind me knocked a glass of red wine onto the floor with glass and wine flying everywhere.  I had to tell a manager that cleaning up the broken glass would be a good idea.  I had to clean the glass off my table.

Avoid this one...

Last year we came here for my boyfriend's birthday dinner.
It was perfect! The waiter was great, our food was excellent and they did read on our reservation that we were coming for a birthday dinner so we got a birthday fortune cookie for dessert.

 We got the spicy tuna roll, two miso soups with clams, salmon udon, and kung pao chicken, everything was delicious.

No complaints here. $120 check plus, 20 tip.

I really liked the decor. Fresh rose petals, buddhas, candlelights, dim, very romantic. We had the soft shell crab roll, shrimp tempura roll, and dragon roll with eels. They were all better than average, though a bit small - not unexpected.Kids wanted the lobster wonton soup and shrimp tempura. The soup was better than the tempura - too thick and oily. We tried the duck spring roll, it was pretty good, don't mind ordering again. The eight of us shared the kobe beef with scallons, XO shrimp,Pad thai,lo mein, kung pao chicken, assorted sashimi, and the lobster dish that I totally hate my friend for ordering .... just kidding about the hate part.....  Every entree was very salty, and the worst part was it tasted like the same sauce was used for every dish. with all the food we ordered and consumed, I actually still had room for dessert, I must say this is probably the best part of the meal. The chocolate parfait with Godiva liquer was nice, balances out the saltiness lingering in my mouth. Tried hubby's lychee sorbet - refreshing, kid's mousse fortune cookie, so-so, but they found it amusing. I actually could eat more, the portions were just too small. we did not see Paris Hilton, but did see Robin Leach with a couple young blonds. :)

Wouldn't rush back. The team member who took our reservation was curt, and our server when we arrived was covered in tattoos with the personality of a rock. 

As for the food, some of it was very good (especially the eggplant), but the XO green beans were tasteless. Overall, the service was a 7/10 and the food was in the same range. 

To add, the place was quite loud which I found extremely annoying and some of the tables feel cramped. 

It's really for tourists.....and even if I was a tourist, I probably still would not return. 

Would probably not return anytime soon.

Overall rating: 6.5/10

The food was great tasting, not the most filling but flavorful. The service however was not the best, they seemed very understaffed servers. Our server seemed overwhelmed and not a happy camper, the hosts/bussers were friendly.

Some impressive points, but overall inconsistent.  

Where were all the 'naked' ladies in the tub?  Only one on Friday night.

Made reservations on OT 11:45pm, showed up at 11:50pm, and was not seated till 12:30am.  No biggie I guess, we just dranks a few cocktails and people watched at the bar.  

The more attitude you give the people at the host's podium, the better they will treat you.  

The prices of the specialty cocktails were $10-12.  I think that's a bargain in a luxury resort on the strip.  Bartenders were great, they were honest about the flavors of the drinks and warned us not to order certain ones.  

Tried:
Tao-tini, Saketini, Love Potion #9, Lychee Martini, Tiger Lily, & Orange Dragon.  

Portions are pretty tiny here.  So be prepared to spend.  

The yum:
Onion Stuffed salmon sashimi-we ordered a SECOND round.  
Crispy lobster & shrimp dumplings, light & full of crustaceans!!!

The aiight:
Yellowtail sashimi w/jalapeno & ponzu, lacking in fresh flavor
Spicy salmon roll, dull
Assorted Nigiri

The ugh:
Spicy Lobster roll w/shiso & black caviar, faux TOUGH lobster, ick!!!

End of the meal: 
FREE chocolate flavored fortune cookies.

Preferential club treatment:
Maybe mid-week.  They just give you a stamp, but you still have to stand in line outside AND pay the cover charge.  I say just stand at the foot of the stairs and wait until the bouncer is preoccupied and mosey on upstairs.

Two orders on their menu that I highly recommend. Order their Sea Bass and Chinese Sausage fried rice with egg. Their Sea Bass was so tasteful it literally melted in my mouth.  It was so good. Their Chinese Sausage fried rice reminded me of a province in Southern China where I spent some time called Taisan; where almost everyone eats this for breakfast.  It was surprisingly very close to being authentic and yet Asian fusion style. But, regardless what you order, everything is going to be flavorful. Their service was fantastic, and they are able to split your bill individually especially if you are traveling on business with a large group.  This is one place to dine in Las Vegas that is not to be missed!
We ordered a tasting, which is a 4 course meal, chef's choice. It was pricy, but well worth it. Every dish was soooo delicious and flavorful. I would defiantly do it again. It really fills you up.
One of my favorite Sushi places. Long waits, but it's Tao, so it's to be expected. Great service once seated, great music, and amazing food. Def a must.

I went to Tao Asian Bistro today with a group. The decor outside looks like it lures in people. We inside around 5, it wasn't crowded yet. I didn't except it to be dark and the ac was on full blast. The music was really noisy. We got the 3 course meals where there are 5 dishes in each course.  I didn't like half the food they served us; they were either too dry or there was too much seasoning. Chinese Sausage Fried Rice was decent. Wok-seared New York Sirloin was ok... alittle bit charred. After we were waiting for the bill, it was like 30 mins later they arrived with the bill. When we were leaving the exit was filled with people at the bar. I don't understand why the bar is so close to the front... My experience was horrible. I will not be going there again.
2.5/10

This is my 2nd time at Tao ... And it's better than I remembered! 

For a cocktail I had "Bubbles and berries" which is served on the rocks with veuve yellow label, belvedere, St. Germain and strawberries!!!! It was a hit!!

We had a feast served family style!!!

Shishito pepper- a little spice, cooked and marinated!

Sushi - eel avocado roll and tuna roll were the best!

Edamame- nothing special. 

Egg rolls- huge! Cut in half great for sharing! 

Tofu lettuce wraps- tasty. Good even got those that do eat meat. 

BBQ pork- not a fan. Not marinated enough... Just taste like pork with no flavor. 

Chicken fried rice- light and tasty! 

Giant fortune cookie- not the tastiest, but s great concept of fortune cookies for the table!

All in all... I would definitely come back!

Had a great time with my family. It was a bit dark to read the menus, but your eyes adjust . Food was good, four of us shared different menu items along with some drinks. I would come back, if I happened to stay at the Venetian. That's just because there are so many options in Vegas it does take some work to make your way here.

Made reservations 2 months in advance, still waited 40 minutes to be seated. Front desk staff were short and not very informative. Main dining room felt like a cafeteria, loud, crowded and overbooked. The environment ruined the experience. Unfortunately, I would not book here again.

I love fusion food so this restaurant was perfect for my taste buds. Ambiance was modern, romantic, and dim. Food was great. I ordered the lobster with potatoes(about $40) and my husband got the preset meal for $50. With his meal he got the spicy tuna sushi(pretty good, rice was lightly burnt at the bottom), egg plant dish(sweet and juicy), and fillet Mignon(decent) and it also came with variety scoops of ice cream(flavors:  green tea, passion fruit, and ginger) for dessert. The ice cream flavors were delicious and unique.   My lobster dish was great.  Full of Asians flavors, just how I like it. Our waitress was attentive and polite. Overall, I would definitely come back during my next visit to Vegas.

The food was delicious but service failed. Slow to take initial drink order and then the manager said they would make it right. We are still trying to figure out what he meant as nothing special was done for us nor was any discount made on our bill. Service continued to be lackluster. Meal should have been served in 3 courses but was served in 2 courses, not as we were told. I was going to order dessert but they took so long to come and ask if we wanted to order dessert I just gave up and asked for the check. 

Later note: I have been contacted by the manager and he has graciously offered to address my concerns. We look forward to giving Tao another try the next time we are in town.

The food and ambiance is excellent!!  The sushi is delicious and fresh, the buns were amazing, and the lobster wonton in the miso broth was particularly amazing!!!  The cocktails and service were on point too!!

I went to Tao for my birthday, I have always wanted to go, and they really lived up to my expectations. Even though we sat by the sushi bar we received great service.  The boneless spare ribs (a commendation from the server) were some of the best pieces of meat I have ever eaten.

Best place I ate while in Vegas, got the peppered filet mignon and it was just delicious. And had a beautiful dessert for my birthday. The atmosphere is absolutely amazing, would recommend this place to anyone.

Tao is completely over hyped. It's nicely decorated and the people working at Tao are all very pretty. The DJ is even great. But the food is awful and the entire meal felt rushed. I felt like the waiters were really trying to turn the tables over quickly. The waiter even took my cocktail and didn't ask if I wanted another. This also happened with the food. But that's not even the worst part. The worst part was the actual food. Maybe I'm spoiled, living in the Bay Area. We have so much great Asian food. Tao just couldn't compare. Not even close. I understand it's Asian fusion, but it just did not taste good.

The appetizers were OK. We had lobster wontons, the tuna tartar, and the chicken dumplings. Of course these were fine, how can you screw up a dumpling. For dinner we had sushi and it was some of the fishiest we've ever had. Just awful. We also had the miso glazed Chilean Sea Bass and it was tasty but I think it was undercooked. About a half hour after eating it, I got really sick. We kicked down like $150+ for dinner and it was as if I hadn't even eaten it. It honestly could have been anything I ate there that made me sick, but I really think it was the sea bass. 

We even had plans to go to the nightclub afterwards but we had such a terrible dinner we wanted to get the hell out of there. We ended up at the Palms. Avoid Tao. It's just not worth it.

This is my second year coming to Tao and they dd not disappoint.  started with the spicy shrimp and crab roll.- awesome...Wife and I both had the rice and noodles- fantastic, and then Chilean Sea Bass- phoenominal.  Service was outstanding and the ambiance was just lovely.  I forgot my credit card and the mgr tracked down my reservation and called my cell to let him know he had the card.  Thank you

Friggin awesome...So what do you do when you are over buffet's and eating junk in Vegas? You eat at one of the "FINE" dining establishments in your hotel. And when they mean fine they mean FINE! This place is awesome and also gets you front of line status if you want to go to Tao nightclub.

Since we had such a large party (8) we couldn't get a reservation until 1045. A little late for dinner....but its Vegas....I woke up at 5PM so it's not that late ;-)

We were seated and our server was very helpful in explaining the menu and the items on it and mentioning the special of the night. 

So I had the 8oz wasabi encrusted filet mignon. BEST STEAK ever!!! I have eaten at most of the "Fine" steak houses in San Diego and one other steak house in Vegas but this one takes the cake. It was so tender and beautifully cooked (medium rare). My friends also had the special of the night (a 12oz Rib Eye) this was also very good and cooked perfectly. We also had the beef shabu shabu pot....it was good but I wish we could have tried the kobe beef...that would have been awesome. Either way I could have eaten the broth by itself. The other thing that stood out was the kobe beef carpaccio. EXCELLENT!! Marinated and cut exquisitely.

All in all the best restaurant I have eaten at so far in my 27 years.

I don't what to make of this resturant.  This restaurant really did whored out East Asian culture with all the Buddhist figures, it almost seems ironic in the heart of Sin City.  This is another level of whorentialism by whites.

We recently came here for a quick dinner celebrating a coed bachelor/ette party. We strictly ate sushi/sashimi and everything was good! We had the spicy tuna over crispy rice, yellowtail hamachi, toro, tempura, and a couple of specialty rolls. No complaints here! The decor is buddha themed and bit dim, too dim where I saw couples break out their cell phone lights to read the menu. Service was great and they even ended our dinner with a sweet treat for the soon to be bride & groom! They gave them a huge complimentary fortune cookie dessert! Overall, it was a good experience and a good spot for celebratory dinners!

Never been to this place before but what energy.Staff was keen on making the evening special and it showed.From the moment we went it , welcomed with smiles and shown to the lounge area.Bar staff was only too happy to accommodate and answered any inquiries we had.Just wandering around upstairs (there is so much to see) we met Joey P.He took us about and showed us the Koi and statues,  photographed us  and was such a pleasure to speak with. Did I mention the dj was kickin it? Oh yeah, it was on. Just one of those nights where everything fell in to place, thank you TAO, we loved it.

The atmosphere sexy and loungy. Perfect place for date or friend gathering. The meals  size is huge and excellent for sharing. If you have any diet restrictions of salt or high fat make sure that the waiter aware of it. We ordered spring veggie rolls, beef  appetizer and for the main course we picked the sired tuna, with "over salted" spinach and "overly"  fried coconut-shrimp with the side dish salad. The mochi desert was impressively tasty. Also the cocktails list was nice.

You don't really eat at Tao for the food, more of the cool factor. Its fun for what it is a place to see and be seen. 

The food is ok, not great not bad, ok.

Warning for those who come here for a hosted event:

We had a company event here recently and a part of the service included an open bar from 7:30 - 10:00 PM (along with a mediocre hosted buffet dinner).  

There was only *ONE* bartender to serve 70 people AND the bartender (and support staff) started ignoring everyone's orders approximately 15 minutes before the end of open bar --- she made herself look like she was busy by tidying the bar.  

It was SO obvious that it was a ploy by Tao to not serve us any more drinks as they were being cheap on the alcohol.  This left a bad taste in our mouths.
Amazing atmosphere, great music, Beutiful people great Dj and funky music. The night club is the best and the food is off he chart!

We had heard good things about Tao restaurant so we were excited to go. However, we were severely disappointed. First, they messed up our reservation and we had to wait 45 minutes to sit down. When we finally did sit down, our waiter was not very helpful and seemed annoyed that he 1. had to help us and 2. we didn't take his recommendations upon ordering. We ended up ordering several small plates, dumplings and sushi. They brought out all our food at once -- and the sushi was NOT freshly made at all and had no flavor and kept falling apart. The only highlight of the meal was the fact we got into the TAO club upstairs for free. $107 later..... I think this place is extremely over-rated and not worth waiting on line for.

Myself and two friends had dinner at 6:30 on 5/27 and it was great! Our waiter was friendly and attentive, I dubbed him the "soda ninja", got refills before realizing I even needed one. The food was excellent! We shared various rolls and couldn't figure out which was my favorite. The decor was really cool! We want to check out the nightclub part next time. I will definitely go again next year on my vacation. I will also recommend it to friends that plan on going to Vegas.

Be sure to open your fortune cookie for a cheeky fortune ;)

Absolutely BEAUTIFUL inside.   Statues, scented ponds filled with fresh rose petals, candles galore, dark, red, stone, Japanese calligraphy... gorgeous.     *gorgeous*...

HOWEVER.   The music and crowd on a Friday night was obnoxious as hell.   The food is great and our server was helpful, BUT only eat here if you like dining in a nightclub.  

Ridiculously loud, crowded and intense.   Not what I was hoping for.   I would only come back if it was lunchtime and the atmosphere was more serene.   

I don't mind going to nightclubs, I'm a professional dancer and I love a good cocktail, people watching et al...   I just don't wanna eat in the middle of one where I can't have a conversation without yelling.    

My dining companion had a splitting headache before we were done with our entree. 

Expect to be seated a full half hour late at least, even if you have a reservation.

TAO restaurant is breathtakingly delightful.

Every dish they have here is delectable and soothes your tastebuds like you won't believe.

I have been here a few times, and each time I have been pleasantly surprised with the amount of delicious food they have here. 

Here are a few suggestions:
*The halibut on a skewer. I don't even like cooked fish, but this was salty and so yummy!
*Kobe beef tempura roll. Exactly how it sounds. Pair it with some great wasabi and soy sauce, and you get a bit of a carpaccio feel.
*Pork potstickers. These potstickers melt in your MOUTH!!!
*Pad Thai. Very tasty with a subtle hint of peanut.

TAO is a bit pricey, but they have a full bar and a great menu. The chefs are also very courteous about allergies and specific requests. 

Go here! Your tastebuds will be dancing!

I ate at Tao last night with a girlfriend.  I think it's been 3 years since I last ate there.  The quality of the food is great, I'd definitely recommend the sashimi plates; we had both the salmon and yellowtail (the salmon was definitely my favorite!).  I also recently became a fan of uni but I have to admit at $8 a pop for 1 piece, it can become a pricey addiction. =\ But it was a very large piece, and very fresh!

Also had their signature tapas dish -- sea bass with asparagus.  It was a bit salty; we needed to eat it with the roast duck fried rice we ordered to tone it down.  That was the only negative of the meal.

We did not order a main entree but what we did order was the perfect amount for the two of us.  Bill came out to be about $100 and we didn't order any cocktails, which seems about average for a restaurant like this. 

Good service and a nice ambience.  Extremely busy on weekends so without a reservation you may be waiting a while to get seated.

Overall a pleasurable dining experience. =)

Tao is fantastic!!! My favorite dish is the Miso Glazed Chilean Sea Bass, but everything I tried was delicious... Roasted Shishito Peppers, Chicken Pad Thai, Fried Rice, Roasted Thai Buddha Chicken. One of our friends had a chef's choice option which included three or four smaller dishes picked by the chef. He liked it a lot. The sake bombs were fun too. Lisa O. served our party of 13 the other night and she was excellent! She spent a lot of time explaining dinner options to our group. The atmosphere is always enjoyable at Tao!
I had the seabass and my wife had the orange chicken, also a noodle dish. The ambiance and scene is great but the food wasnt worth it. I have had better orange chicken from chinese take out.

Pretty much all you need to do as a white person to determine if an Asian or Asian fusion type restaurant is worthwhile is to simply glance around the room at your fellow restaurant goers. Are they mostly Asian? If so, the food will be delicious at an appropriate dollar-per-dollar rate. If not, you are either probably getting crappy take out or are about to get food-fleeced.

Don't get me wrong: the cuisine my fellow Bachelor Party-Goers and I had here, from the admirable sea bass to the wasabi crusted filet mignon was incredibly well-executed and tasty. But while I still enjoyed actually eating the meal in a flawlessly decorated room with its truly hip atmosphere, the ever-present knowledge that I could have had everything we ordered for a fraction of the price at many places in the San Gabriel Valley still sunk the experience.

That's just me though. I think if you're keen on unloading a boatload of money and you also happen to want Asian food in a super-cool environment, Tao could fit the bill. If you want something that's just as special and more reasonably calibrated, price-wise, there are a ton of other places in LV you might want to visit instead.

This isn't my kind of scene.  Super loud.  Lots of glitz and glamor.  Bling bling all over the place.  Not my style.

But I was there for a family birthday party.  This meant tasting menu for everyone.  Last minute they found out I was a pescetariann and made accommodation.  They were super knowledgeable about foods that contained meat and were awfully sweet.  The fish dishes were perfectly cooked.  Loads of flavor.

Get take out from Tao.  Or go deaf and blind while dining.  (Re-reading my review I feel as if I'm clearly getting old or too mommy-ish).

TAO restaurant is always the highlight of my visits to Vegas.  Love the atmosphere, although a bit unnerving to have big Buddha staring at you while you down delicious shots of premium sake!  Always a fun night of celeb spotting as JayZ or Mariah come through with their posses.  LOL.

Nice large restaurant with plenty of servers and bussers so you never have to go looking for someone or wait long before someone walks by.  

I have been to this location several times.  The food is always spot on and despite being in the desert, the sushi is as fresh as I've ever tasted, anywhere in the world.  Seriously, they have to have it flown in daily right from the harbor!  

My favorite entrees are the sea bass and the steak dish.  Sorry, don't remember what they're called on the menu.
Food was phenomenal. A+++, everything we ordered was delicious. Service was amazing.

We had a reservation for 7:15, and we were not seated until 8:05. I had to repeatedly ask when we would be seated. They said that they had a private party on the second floor & that is where our table was. Why make a reservation if you will not be able to seat the party within 5-10 minutes? It was also dark in the restaurant and very hard to see the menu. The music was great, but so loud that you could barley have a conversation at the table. The food was great, but I probably won't be back.
Tao is is indeed delish. I particularly enjoyed the Kobe beef that you cook yourself in a ginger scallion broth. The decor is fantastic and true to Vegas style, the music is hot!

5 stars for the food.  -1 star for the sushi chefs ignoring the bar and relying on the waiters entirely, even when the bar was almost deserted.

The food here was so very good.  My sister and I went in for a light snack and barely managed to not order a 3rd helping of the chicken potstickers after we decided we'd had enough sushi.  The place also has a very nice look and friendly wait staff who know their tea.

I'd been wanting to try Tao and we decided to stop around 6pm since we had been shopping at the canal shops for the past few hours. Great food! We started off with tempura asparagus which was delicious! I had the pepper steak and my friend had the sausage fried rice. The asparagus was phenomenal with the sweet chili sauce and the pepper steak was so good! My friend also has some smoked salmon. Bill with tip came to about $100. Loved the atmosphere too. Michael was our server and he and his crew did a great job. We even had two managers stop to check on us. They invited us to the nightclub and would get us in for free too. 

***i must mention that i LOVED how allergy conscious they were. They asked if we had any allergies so i told them yes to seafood. Every time they brought a dish they let me know if i could eat it. For someone with food allergies this is amazing-I've never seen a wait staff be so attentive.

This place is great if you're a 19 year old bachelorette and your posse of girlfriends is outfitted in tiaras and feather boas. If, however, you're on a family vacation in Sin City (what? Reserve your judgments, please) then you'll have to contend with terrible service and fairly mediocre food. My favorite dish was the wasabi-crusted filet with onion ring tempura, not because the meat was silky and tender (which it was - credit where credit is due) but because the onion ring tempura resembled an insane alien pod ship. But otherwise it took us half an hour for our tea to arrive, and I know it doesn't take half an hour to boil water. Or to steep tea. Or both. And the desserts were a royal disappointment - I mean people, Godiva chocolate should not be listed on a menu. It's not impressive, nor is it good, and - dare I say it - it's not even chocolate. I'd skip the dinner in favor of drinks where you can enjoy the real reason for going - bachelorette party watching.

Celebrated my 25th birthday here and I enjoyed every second! 1st of all....this place is beautiful! From the decor, to the vibes. It was amazing. You should probably definitely make a reservation so you can have a good spot to sit at with no wait. I got the filet mignon pepper steak. It was delicious, and cooked to perfection. I only wish the portion was a little larger but nonetheless I enjoyed every bite. After dinner they brought out a huge fortune cookie w/ ice-cream with fortunes for the whole table and sung happy birthday! it was so cute. I really enjoyed myself and the waiter was on point too. I definitely want to come back and check out their happy hour I hear its great!!
Favorite restaurant! Such great service and even better food. Ordered the Crab cakes, Steak with peppers, jumbo fried shrimp, & pad tai noodles... no complaints

Good place for groups since it's dark, trendy music, and colorful drinks.  Not so much for a romantic night.  

I've been to Tao New York few years ago and was not so impressed by fancy expensive Chinese food.  It was just a place that I can say "Yeah, I've been there" and not return again.  Somehow I found myself here in the deviation also known as Las Vegas' version.  The best way I can describe Las Vegas spun versions restaurants (ie Mesa Grill, Delmonico, David Burke, Koi, etc etc) is large productions, lacking heart and character in its food.  Mass production?

We ordered the miso glazed salmon which was fine, the size of the fish was beyond my expectations (insert my mass production epiphany), spicy toro tartar on crispy rice.... a nice attempt at copying Koi's signature dish but fell short on the crispy rice, it was too thick so the crispyness did not stick together but fell all over my plate.... some Filet Mignon yaki udon dish that really made me miss Oh! Taisho's kimchi yakiudon but I digress.

It was a very bland dining experience.  The only good thing - we were able to receive comps to Tao Nightclub.

Food was outstanding. We had a party of 15 and they did everything to accommodate us. Service was outstanding as was the food. I ate everything they served us and wanted more OMG this place is the bomb. The talent is also outstanding for you single guys.
I can't understand how this place gets a 3.5 stars.. This place it's just unbelievable with great food and fun atmosphere ...

The BEST food I've ever had in Vegas.

I got a sushi roll (was advised against anything with salmon in it by our waiter) & it was divine. Just enough for me. My boyfriend got the Thai peanut sauce shrimp & it was AMAZING. Light, delicate, spicy, lemongrass....i still dream of it!! We also split tempura scallops which was $10 for 2 (our waiter kindly advised us) & delicious.

Our friends also loved their food, including sushi rolls. People devoured the short ribs.

Our waiter communicated well with us as the sushi was made in one spot & other food in the kitchen. The waiter felt the ribs wouldn't be enough for 2 people but our friends got stuffed & ended up sharing.

We also got a free desert (with naughty fortunes) for our friends birthday.

Everyone was SHOCKED by how much we actually paid - it seemed so little for the quality!!!

PROS: Selection, food, waitstaff, speed, decor
CONS: the guys next to us trying to hit on every girl that would sit down.

PROTIP: apparently the bathrooms aren't labeled....

an awesome experience! we've been to the vegas & new york locations & both phenomenal! beautiful surroundings! amazing food. fabulous drinks,a bit pricey some say but soooo worth it. staff amazing!need to go at least once!unique place! don't be in a rush! enjoy!

Had a comp dinner here with friends and it was absolutely fabulous.  We got to try a bunch of cocktails too, and they were all very creative and well mixed.  The food itself was delicious and I woudln't have changed a thing! Even though we were a comp dinner I didn't feel rushed at all and we sat for awhile enjoying our drinks after dinner.  Go here!

Fun atmosphere and great food. I was unsure what to expect when we got there because it took them almost 20 minutes after our scheduled reservation to get seated. However, the staff was very apologetic and got the three of us a round of drinks to make up for the delay. Once we were seated everything was amazing. Our server Jon was very knowledgeable and the food was amazing and came out quickly. The sea bass was the best I have ever had and the eggplant was also extremely delicious. Furthermore, the manager made a point to come in and check in on us throughout the meal to make sure we were enjoying everything and to apologize again for the delay, at the end he even sent us a giant fortune cookie for dessert that was heavenly. The manager and the staff did an amazing job turning our experience around and making sure we were truly happy and enjoying everything. I would definitely done here again.

Third time at Tao. 6 years ago, it was fantastic. Now, it is over-hyped. 

Expect to spend some time waiting for your table, surrounded by giant bachelor and bachelorette parties, convention groups, etc. I'd say it's a great place to see and be seen, but not really...it's more of a place to gawk at the bad choices people made before leaving their hotel rooms. "Oh no, she did NOT just wear that sweater as a dress. Oh no, this guy does NOT have a moustache minus the irony..." You get the idea.

Still, it's certainly over the top and will wow newbies to Vegas. And if you are as much about getting your drink on as getting your eat on, this is the perfect choice. However, if you are focused on the finery of your food, you will probably be disappointed by the excessive use of salt in everything that drowns out flavors and creates one TAO taste.

Bottom line: know what you are getting into. If you do, you may love it!

If you like the one in NY, you will like this one. 

What I like about it is that the service is great, the ambience is awesome & the food is good. This is a place to go, not just because you want to eat, but because you want to indulge all of your senses. 

The hubby & I went here after a show to share a small meal & enjoy the place.
Everything was great.
The only thing I can complain about is that the NY location has (or had .. I don't know anymore because I haven't been in a long time) a bigger cocktail menu which included a mojito menu. I specifically remember a blackberry mojito which was amazing. Unfortunately, they don't have a mojito menu at this location.

The best dining experience ever. We waited forever to get seated for a party of 7 but it was all worth the wait. 
A lot of the dishes we ate was recommended from our waiter and our waiter did a really good job making those recommendations. Every dish we had was mouth watering. My favorite was the lobster dumbling (interesting right?) and the sea bass. A lot of their sushi rolls were really delicious also. Everyone should definitely give this place a try at least once when you're in Vegas. It would be worth the experience =) I would definitely come back here

This Review is way overdue. My husband and i decided to have a little getaway to Vegas for 4th of July and ofcourse we had to come here and have dinner. This was our second time coming and it never disapoints, we seriously crave our favorite dishes everyday.

Kinda on the pricey side but what do you expect it's Vegas and the food is bomb.

Our go to dishes:

* Glazed Salmon
* Roasted Thai Buddah Chicken

Now let's see if Tao in Hollywood is just as good.

Amazing food, flawless service. A huge win all around. We dined early on a Friday night - no reservations, just walked in about 5:30 pm and the place was mostly empty (just the way we like it). Gorgeous place, great atmosphere. We had the Chilean Sea Bass skewers to start, and we nearly fought each other for the right to eat more than our one skewer share. It was heaven. Then we shared the Wagyu beef entree and the sausage fried rice - both were truly excellent. The beef was fork tender and perfectly cooked medium rare. I had only really heard of the nightclub - not for me, but I would go over and over again to the Asian Bistro to eat.

Grossly over priced Chinese food that is mediocre at best. The pepper filet was ok. The orange chicken was downright bad. 

The pros are the dumplings and the atmosphere is nice.

Do not waste your time or money!

service was terrible!  the girl was as sweet as could be but they cater to large groups which meant that my special evening celebrating my anniversary with my husband came second to ANYTHING ELSE in that restaurant.   It took 30 minutes just to get her over to give her our drink order,  then another 15 to get our food order, then 40 minutes to get our food in front of us. the food was cold once we did get it.  When the party next to us returned 2 plates we should have known!  we ordered Pad Tai and it was nothing more than something you could get at a drive thru.  the sushi was tiny and rubbery. when the waitress asked if we were enjoying our food i said no it was cold.  she apologized and that was it.
our bill came to $112.00 before a tip.  
we wish we had saved our money and gone to a much nicer restaurant where our romantic weekend would have been more appreciated by the business taking our money.

Helpful hint: if you eat there on a Friday or Saturday night, make sure you stay for the club/lounge part and you won't have to pay the $40 to get in. I've been there twice and the food is good, nothing I'd rave about. But the place is very trendy and the ambiance and service is up to par. 

They sometime have  celebrities and high profile guest djs. The first I had been Benny Benassi was the dj. The mor recent second time I've been back, I just went to eat (it was during the week)then headed over to XS.
In love Tao! Great food and nice ambience. Love the shrimp appetizer and the sea bass.

Yep, be prepare to wait.  Our dinner reservation was at 9:30pm but didn't get in till like 40 min. after.  Once we get in, it's worth it in my opinion, the food was delievered shortly after we place the order.  The track playing inside were so cool that one of my friend decide to buy the CD off them.  There were 5 guy of us that we each order a dish & there was plenty to share, all reasonable priced.  My favorite got to be their cooked Samon on the menu, just a bit suprise me, really good dish!  Lastly, the decor was really amazing they got this giant budda statue at first floor, there was some birthday party next to us that there were a guy working there hitting the traditional Japanese drum to celebrate for them, really cool.  
Oh & if you're lucky like us to get in to the club afterward, the waitress stops by your table to take u upstair personally, which consider the crazy, busy amount of people they have, I have to say they did a really good job.  Just try it yourself, you won't be disappoint doing both the dinner & the clubbing there, in my opinion.

I read the reviews, went with trepidation based on my friend's obsession with the place. He's all about looks and that's what you get. It's pretty (although the Buddha Bar thing is a bit "done" now). The food, however, is consistent with other Panda Express reviews. I figured that it would be more P.F. Chang's but I was wrong. PFC is not really Chinese either, it's Amero-chinese and they do a good job of it. TAO is totally mall Chinese. I can be OK with mall Chinese. Two meats, a veg and some noodles for $10? Great! One meat for $25? Not so much. To make matters worse, it's generally pretty bland for the sugared-up type of Chinese food that this tries to be.

If you're into the Buddha Bar looks of the early 2000's, this is great. Otherwise, go elsewhere if you care about food.

Some of you people are ridiculous.  Let me point out a couple of things-

I saw someone who gave this restaurant 2 stars say that, "I've never eating here, but I'm reviewing their service."  Then don't even bother posting your review- save us the time and save Yelp's bandwidth.

And to people complaining about the loud music.
Why, did you bring your family there to celebrate your granddaughter's baptism?  Nice, real nice.

Oh, and stop comparing Asian restaurants to Panda Express- it's getting old.

First off, you can obviously tell that I love this place.  Let me tell you why.

Even during the first time I ate at Tao, I didn't expect it to be a quaint and gentle dinner made by a world-renowned chef.  Tao's advertisements have a naked woman with "Always a happy ending" tatooed to her back in Chinese.  Seriously, what did you expect?  If you think that kind of lewd advertisement says, "Bob and Daisy's Kosher Garden Cafe," I'll fly myself to your city to slap you.

I came there and got what I expected and a bit more.  Stunning interior design by a NY firm whose design philosophy is heavily based on catering to the audience.  From the dramatic lighting, the 2-story buddha, and the naked girls in the bathtubs at the tunnel entrance- if you think you can take your grandma on her tennis-ball walker to this restaurant, you deserve a second slap.

As far as the food goes, it was fine.  Yes, I could've gotten better food at an off-strip restaurant, but was I there mainly to have the ultimate epicurean experience?  Absolutely not, I was there to eat, enjoy the energy of the restaurant and most importantly, to have fun with my friends.

What, you're gonna give a restaurant who serves amazing food 5 stars even when the food is served on paper plates and they're located in a rat-infested hole in the wall with horrible servers?  Don't be ridiculous.

As far as the service goes, I'll admit- it's not flawless.  They do know a lot about the menu and about Japanese and pan-Asian cuisine, and they're quite attentive.  But the hostesses could be a bit more polite.  You know why they're ticked off by the end of the night?

Imagine yourself as a tall blonde girl with 32C's, getting drunk calls at all hours of the night, getting hit on and gropped by the occasional stranger.. and hassled by the idiot who decided to bring their 3 year old child and needs a baby seat.

Of course, this is no excuse for the management to hire more enduring hostesses, but they don't care.  The money is coming, and they still remain as one of the most highest earning on the strip in terms of annual revenue.

Anyways, you've heard it all.  I love this place because it's a place I can enjoy inexpensive food (seriously, $12 pad thai isn't that much on the Vegas strip), amazing interior, decent service, with people I know who can enjoy it with me.

You want amazing food, go to Joel Robuchon.  But be prepared- I don't think Joel himself will come out to thank your granddaughter for eating at his place on her baptism day since obviously, that's what you expect of Tao.
AMAZING flavors! Had dinner with my family last weekend while in Las Vegas. We ordered several dishes and had a "family style" dinner. Everything was to die for... Lobster dim sum is a must!

The first time I saw this place, I couldn't wait to try it out. It looked so fancy and beautiful, reminiscent of the Buddha Bar in Washington D.C.  Being a local, I don't really get out much to the strip unless visitors come into town. When some girlfriends of mine came into town, we were very excited about trying Tao. 

Our reservations were for 10pm on a Friday night. We didn't get seated until 10:40pm. That wasn't so bad, since the wait staff was very attentive. Finally seated, the three of us ordered right away and then the wait began. During this time, three other tables around us, got seated, served and left, while we kept waiting. The gracious waitress kept coming by to apologize and the faithful water attendant never let our glasses get less than 3/4 full. We definitely got re hydrated, but were starving. 

Finally, we requested to speak to the manager. When he finally showed up, he didn't have much to say, and didn't seem at all apologetic. The saddest and most ridiculous part was that he blamed the 90 minute wait on The Wok!! Seriously?!! 

This huge establishment should have more than one wok. What kind of excuse it's that? He didn't offer us any appetizers for our trouble and we finally suggested maybe a dessert would be nice.  So, our food finally arrived and I ordered the Duck Fried Rice. I love duck and I'm a kind of a salt-aholic usually, but my dish was just meh, greasy and salty even beyond my ability to tolerate. My friend's dishes were also just ok, but NOT worth the hour and a half wait. 

What if we had tickets to a show or had to catch a flight? Anyway, we hoped the desert would be better, but 30 minutes after finishing our meal, dessert still hadn't arrived. A woman came by offering us stamps to get into the night club, which we wanted to try, so we still had hope. Another 15 minutes passed by, still no dessert, we finally decided it was time to leave.

Then it was time for the night club. What a let down! First of all, much like the restaurant, a lot of people weren't even dressed nice. Packed to the gills, as expected, but the dancers looked bored and were barely trying. Then there were these sad, mopey girls sitting in the cement bath tubs. Seriously? 

The dancers at Hard Rock are so much more entertaining. I was sad. Sad that my great expectations were crushed, sad that my girlfriends had this same lame experience on their first night in Vegas. 

Maybe you need to be blind drunk in order to look passed all these short comings and hoot at the top of your lungs. Maybe that was were we went wrong or maybe Tao jumped the shark.?

The ONLY reason I am giving 2 stars instead of 1 is because they do have pretty good sushi.  HOWEVER - the hype about this place is so overdone that the staff has a huge attitude and they do not know how to treat guests.  

My husband and I went around 7:30 on a Thursday night.  We were staying at the Venetian (the hotel connected to the restaurant), made reservations for both the restaurant and the nightclub.  After waiting an HOUR we finally got a table.  The place was dark, loud, and the layout made you feel very crowded.  It was difficult to see what we were eating, let alone have a conversation.  We dropped about $400 on dinner (we were celebrating and had a bottle of Veuve).  

After dinner was over, we said we had reservations for the nightclub, the entrance to the club was literally 20 feet from our table.  Well, we had to get up, go outside the club, stand in a long "special line" and then wait in another "special line" in order to pay a $20 cover to go back through the restaurant we just left, back up the stairs we just came down, in order to get in.  

Pathetic.

Having been to TAO on two previous occasions and loving it I decided to return with 6 other friends last week . It was a DISASTER. The waiter was rude, and seemed bothered when we asked for something( like sugar for our tea) My fish and two others was raw and he proceeded to shine a flashlight to it and said " that's the way it's cooked" I had the same meal before and it was excellent. I can't help but think that if the gratuity has not been included( for a large party) that he would have been a little nicer. I will never return to this restaurant and regret having paid the gratuity. Good luck to large parties!!
Only been here for drinks - of course Chris is the BEST BARTENDER EVER!  Love the lounge... Looking forward to trying the food (hear it is AMAZING!!!) -- most probably when I win the lottery :)

I was EXTREMELY disappointed by this place. I went out to dinner here with a friend before a night out in the club upstairs and received awful service from the start. The hostess suggested we sit at the sushi bar to avoid a wait for a table and then failed to walk us to the back to seat us. We awkwardly wandered through the restaurant until we reached the sushi bar in the back and there we not even any open seat there. Once we were finally seated our waiter brought us water and took our order. We said we wanted to hold off on ordering drinks until we got our food.

A different waiter than or original one brought out our food and we were never checked on. Didn't have the chance to order drinks, no one asked how our food was or if we needed anything...we were totally ignored. I ended up asking a third staff member in passing to bring me a drink. A man who appeared to have a managerial position based on the way he was dressed was wandering around our area for awhile and never even picked up on the fact that we were not being helped. About an hour later we had to ask him where our server was just to get our bill and neither apologized to us.

I had high expectations for this place based on the prices and reputation but was extremely disappointed and will not be back next time I'm in town.

So who goes to eat at a night club and expects great tasting food and customer service? Not me, that's for sure. Well Tao (the restaurant) was a pleasant surprise. They were able to accommodate about 20-25 of us for dinner (though our reservations were for 11:30pm, but we made them at 4pm).

I would say majority of us ordered the sea bass and majority of us would say, it was damn good! We also ordered a family style dish of some fried rice and that was good too. I was amazed at how good the food was. Quality of the fish was excellent. My only gripe is the portion we all got. It's not a big portion. If you come here hungry, you won't leave full, I'll tell you that. 

The service here is excellent, great staff brought everyone what they ordered, cups were never empty, the brought us everything we needed... all while being in the dark. I have no idea how they got everyone their order without being able to see, but they did... and the fish  (sea bass) was cooked to perfection. 

WAIT... there's more! So we recently just found out that if you eat here you get entrance to the Tao night club too... without waiting! On top of all that, they gave us a free pass to Tao Beach the next day. What a deal! What would have cost us about 80 bucks (dinner, club entrance, beach entrance)... cost us the price of dinner.

We had an amazing time here. Our waiter TJ was very attentive, and was extremely helpful with his suggestions of what we should try. My partner and I ate at TAO in NY and it was a great experience, but TJ really made this bday dinner unforgettable. The food was amazing, the atmosphere was infectious and the surprise bday desert that they gave us on a whim was HUGE and delicious. We ran into Jermaine Dupree on our way out, so that was an awesome surprise!!! I wish I could give them 10 stars!!!

If you're in Vegas & you don't visit Tao, you are missing out! 

Ask for Geoffrey to be your waiter, if he is available. He recommends the most delicious dishes and describes them down to the very last detail. He truly made our dining experience one to remember. 

The sushi and rolls were alright, nothing crazy. The spicy tuna on crispy rice is very delicious. I had a stir fry vegetable dish with noodles. It was very filling. My boyfriend had the Kobe beef carpaccio topped by a baby arugula salad. I am not a fan of raw meat, yet I tried it and it was unbelievably fresh. 

The dessert plate included edible chopsticks and the fortune cookies had very interesting messages inside. 

Keep in mind, this restaurant is very dark and has a nightclub and lounge within the three story premise.

I came to Tao as a side trip for EDC, and about half way through the meal, I felt like I came to Vegas for Tao, and EDC was just a side trip. 

I ate at Tao with a group of 8 people - family and friends, all a bunch of young adults in our twenties. We ordered family style (many plates in the center of the table to share), and in total, we destroyed 8 delicious dishes and a beautiful dessert smorgasbord. Every single thing we tried was delicious. I am spoiled in that my parents take me to nice places on occasion, and Tao is at the top 5 of my list of best meals I've ever eaten. One friend who ate with us said - and I quote, "This is probably the best meal I will ever eat in my life." I am going to New York this fall or winter and plan to eat at the Tao restaurant in New York with my boyfriend. You can expect to hear another review on that restaurant soon. 

My favorite dishes of the meal we had include: 
- The flavorful 28 days aged new york steak which melted in my mouth
- The miso glazed Chilean Sea Bass which tasted like it was injected with the best sauce ever created. Every bite gave you a gush of flavor, and it was cooked just right.
- The Crispy Tuna Sashimi Roll with Edamame which came with a not-too-spicy wasabi dipping sauce.
- The delicious mixed sashimi platter which had a wide variety of sashimi including fatty tuna. 
- The gorgeous display of desserts (also ordered family style) which came with a hilarious and delicious giant fortune cookie and sweet dipping cream. The fortunes were Vegas-themed and made us laugh. 

The atmosphere was nice and our server, Jeffery, was amazing. He always came at the right time, promptly filled our glasses, and was extremely helpful with the ordering process. He was absolutely hilarious, and super friendly. His language is what puts him over the top. The way he described the food as we were ordering was something from a movie or commercial. He used 2-3 descriptive - and one would even say seductive - adjectives for each dish. It's hard not to order them when he describes them that way. My brother put it best when he asked Jeffery, "Could you please describe the food to me like that as I'm eating it?" About a quarter of the way into our meal, the manager even came out to make sure we were all enjoying our food. 

All in all, it was a perfect dinner, and a fantastic way to start our crazy night at the Electric Daisy Carnival.

We live in NY and never been to the NY location. However, we heard the Vegas location was 10x better then NY. Everything was just amazing from when you first step foot in the hotel. The restaurant was located on the second floor. The night club was closed that day however they still had soft music and people dancing on the 2nd Floor of the restaurant. The waitress was nice and once your drink runs low someone from no where comes to refill it. The food did taste like really good Asian Thai food just very fresh and a good amount. Pretty pricey but worth it. I ordered the coconut shrimps they was really big and thickly breaded couldn't finish it all. My bf ordered the Mango Chicken. We also shared  Shrimp Tai Fried Rice. We are heavy eaters but we got full fast. Next time we are in Vegas we will definitely be eating from here again and exploring the menu. We also order some beef which was that nights special. Don't remember the name of it but I loved it, my bf thought it wasn't cooked good. They did however leave some pieces of fat on it.

Went with group while in tow for convention.  We had no reservation but were able to get a table in less than 15 mins during dinner on a very busy night.

The food was all great.  We had red curry scallops, glazed salmon and the lobster seafood mix in black bean sauce.

The food was all excellent.  Came quickly well made.  A bit more seasoning with the seafood blackbean dish would have helped.

Our big complaint here was that it was hard to have a conversation due to the speakers literally 3 feet from our table pumping out mad beats.  I thought we were at the restraunt not club.

Nothing like Tao NYC. We are a big fan of Tao and every time we are in nyc we eat at Tao which is our favorite restaurant. So when we were in Vegas we decided to stop by. The lychee martini was nothing like the one I have tasted in New York I couldn't even drink it all. And the service here was awful. We felt as we were being rushed the whole time and we asked for more salt for the edamame and it never came. The food was very good but that's about it. The experience was not great, and dining out is not just about the food but the experience in general. Super disappointed.

I cannot praise this place highly enough. Order the pork potstickers appetizer and then order more of them. All food was excellent and also had a delicious whisky/cherry cocktail. I cannot stress how good the pork potstickers were. Also pepper steak very good. Friend had the beef that you cook in a pot in front of you and was also very good but some people might turn their nose up at having to cook their own food. But ended up tasting amazing. 5 stars, would highly recommend, make a reservation very well in advance.
Solid meal and good environment but pretty loud.

we had my quarter of a century bash dinner here and had the most amazing time. I am already trying to arrange my next trip back and will be eating again at this restaurant. The Lychee martini is amazing. The place is always busy and after dinner if you plan to dance the night away- Tao club is a fun one too- though it gets crowded and hard to move, which gave me a claustrophobic feeling- but still fun. The newest hotspot is Tao beach, where the cabanas are extremely expensive- but awesome for chicks- the guys always want chicks in their cabanas, right!

A year later , sitting at the bar. Service is not nearly as good as it was sitting at a table last year. Ordered a cocktail only to find out after it was served the bartender thought about telling me the happy hour special.. (comped drink with app) my drink was over the $16 limit. She didn't tell me this before I ordered and after I asked about happy hour.and I wondered why since my martini looked comparable to the specialty drinks on the menu. Ordered a few apps , lobster wontons and spicy tuna sushi. Both very good. Drinks were fine. Bar not busy but bartender seemed preoccupied, socializing with her coworkers seemed to take precedence over being super attentive to bar patrons. She was not rude, she did her job at the bare minimum and that was it nothing above. I loved this place a year ago and I will go again based on that visit.

Went here with some friends for dinner.  It's a nice fusion spot and the food is tasty and has a good variety.  It's expensive and our waiter said a lot of VIP's show up there.  It was convienent for us because we were staying in the Venetian.  I'd go back.  They have some crazy drinks.

Came here with 3 other people, we made our reservations for 7:30, and were seated immediatly after we checked in with the hostess. 

THe interior is very dark, and the atmosphere was fun, our waiter was really great and attentive.

We ordered a few different maki rolls, some veggie tempura and the kimchi/lobster fried rice. All of the food was phenomenal. I have to do minus one star because the service was slow. Over 20 minutes for our drinks, after our plates were cleared over 15 minutes for our check.

I was pleasantly surprised!  Much less pretentious than I thought, but the waitor was a little on the pushy side.  I suppose with the economy, Vegas is hurting too so he's gotta "make it work".  Other than that, here's the rundown:

-Sushi:  We shared a few rolls for appetizers and they were good, but definitely $$ for the portion.  We had a spicy, crunchy tuna roll and something else with yellowtail; like I said, good, but I've had better at Sushi Wabi in Chicago.  

-Drinks:  Sake martini, waaaaay too heavy on the vodka.  Left a stinging sensation in my mouth and not in a good way.  The other tini's were on the sweet side.  

-Dinner:  We had peking duck for two...MUST try.  It was tender, flavorful and a great portion size.  Friends had chicken curry, nice and spicy and chilean sea bass, also delicious.  I thought the entrees were all reasonably priced, especially for Vegas.  

-Atmosphere:  Lots of typical d-bags yelling "Vegas Baby!!" and lots of typical chippees in slutty outfits (us included).  But overall, no complaints.  We were seated on time, the service was efficient (our food came out really fast!) and $110 per person (dinner for six, split 5 ways for b-day girl) seemed like a pretty good deal for as much as we ate and drank.
The food is to die for. We had the Chilean sea bass (a must) and sushi- AMAZING!  Drinks were great too. Waitress Lisa was great and a lot of fun too. Definitely will be back!

Tao did not not disappoint. The atmosphere was wonderful, but more importantly- the food was phenomenal. We ordered a bunch of appetizers so that we could have a taste of everything. The most memorable food items consisted of: 
-The shishito peppers and mustard sauce. Amazing taste and not overly spicy. 
-The chicken satay and peanut sauce. They were so good that we ordered a second plate. 
-The veggie rolls. They were big and very filling. Definitely not a standard small egg roll that you find at a PF Chang's. 
-The molten cake and salted caramel. The caramel ice cream definitely made this desert worth it. 

The restaurant was also kind enough to bring out a huge fortune cookie dessert in honor of my birthday which was also amazing. It was filled with a chocolate and vanilla mousse.

In terms of the service, our server was extremely friendly and attentive. He helped us pick out our alcoholic beverages, which again were beyond our expectations. 

Everything was great except the following:  

1.) There was a man (possibly the manager or some wannabe security guard) who went around with a microphone/headpiece giving updates on table availability. He made us feel extremely uncomfortable and rushed. I understand that this restaurant is in high demand and busy. However, we felt like the experience wasn't enjoyable because we were being pushed out so another party could sit down. This gentleman AKA wannabe security guard approached our table and asked us how our food was, BUT he didn't do it in a way that made it sound like he actually cared about us or the food. He constantly kept hovering over our table and I found myself annoyed. Also, keep in mind that we were only at the restaurant for one hour. 

2.) The bus boys kept sweeping up food remnants off the floor every five minutes (when honestly there was nothing to even clean up). It was excessive and made sitting down unpleasant. No offense, but when I'm eating, I really don't want someone sweeping next to me or even underneath me. If you want to get technical, those dust particles are traveling in the air each time you sweep. Therefore, they could have quite possibly made it onto our plate. From a sanitary perspective, wait until people leave the table. 
On top of that, the bus boys kept clearing our table when we weren't even finished with our food.  At one point, we snapped at one of the guys as he was about to take our plate that we weren't finished with. 

A word to management, stop having your guys go around rushing people to finish their food. I really liked the food, but quite frankly- the constant hovering, sweeping and clearing of the table made me not want to revisit this location. It shouldn't be about how many people you can cram into your restaurant. If we wanted fast food, we would have gone to McDonald's.

This is really neat place! The food is totally fabulous, and the food is out of this world. The service was excellent, and the wine delicious. I would highly recommend it. Make sure you make reservations.

Tao is definitely not the place to go if you want good Asian cuisine. 

I ordered the curry noodles and they were salty and the noodles are way too thin, not to mention it was extremely over priced (along with pretty much everything on the menu) I mean c'mon 26$ for a little bowl of curry noodles? 

Super dark and SUPER LOUD. It's pretty much like eating in a night club. You have to yell at the person across from you for conversation. 

I went with a large party maybe 15 or so people. When the check came out we simply asked for it to be split up. The waiter literally looked at us as if we were asking him to juggle chainsaws on fire while unicycling on a tight rope. 

He said it would take some time to split it up, pretty much trying to convince us not to. He took roughly 35-40 minutes to split the check. Seriously? C'mon. If the local Denny's can split a 15 person check with no issue why can't your hip modern upscale Asian restaurant do so too? 

In conclusion, avoid Tao unless you enjoy mediocre over priced food and shitty customer service.
