Sea bass and scallops were okay but nothing special and I would pass on the pork belly rice, it was pretty salty. My friend ordered the hotpot and she disliked it so much she only ate about 1/4 of it. I wouldn't say the food here was bad, it just wasn't worth it.

Food and service was phenomenal! 
Loved the short ribs, the tempura scallops were the best I've ever had. 
Prepare to wait unless you have a reservation. 
It's pretty loud in there but to be expected you are in Vegas :)

When we called to make the reservation, they told us that you only need to order $5 + appetizers to get a stamp to get into the club for free and bypass the long line. However, when we arrived there, we were informed by our server that we must each order 1 entree from The Sea, The Land, or The Sky, or 2 rolls, which would be 25+ for each. Didn't turn out to be a big deal because everyone was pretty hungry. 

I would definitely recommend the miso glazed sea bass. It was delicious! But be sure to order a side or rice because it'd be too sweet without it. 
The orange chicken doesn't resemble anything from Panda Express and comes in a large portion with a side of rice. Not bad, but I'd prefer the sea bass. 
Thai Buddha Chicken is a mystery. I am not quite sure what it is exactly, but it was juicy and tasty nontheless. 

And we got our stamps and got into the club with no troubles for the rest of the night. The dinner average out to about $40 / person.

I was impressed with my meal - I ordered the Chilean sea bass and it was cooked so perfectly- I think my only disappointment was it came with some veggies but there were not too many (for the price IMO). But luckily my boyfriend ordered a dish that was hugely generous so I was able to nab some veggies off his plate.  Over all - I think it was a great Vegas experience and I think if you are going for a romantic dinner and want to enjoy a very nice presentation and impress your date this is for sure a great place to go to.

4.5 stars!
We're from the East coast and have been searching all over Vegas for East coast style peking duck (with pancakes), so we checked out Tao.

We had to wait 1/2 hr past our reservation time...

Lobster Wontons  - very good
Sea Bass - awesome! melts in your mouth
Peking Duck - good, but not worth $70 (hoisen had to much vinegar and the quantity of meat was small)
Fortune Cookie dessert - good, very unique

The highlight is the sea bass and I would order that again.

I am IN LOVE with this place! The service was superb, the food was amazing, my overall experience was just the best ever! Their food is so delicious and their teas are yummy as well. I love the atmosphere and everything... a must go!

We loved everything about this restaurant! The large floating Buddha over the infinity pool and d√©cor create a great ambiance that is inviting and appealing. We celebrated my husband's birthday and had a group of 9. The restaurant was busy as is expected on a Saturday night but once we were seated, the staff treated us as if we were the only client in the restaurant which made the night special. 

Daniel waited on our party and he was extremely kind and accommodating, especially with dietary needs/ allergies of one person in our party. Being our first time at Tao, I asked for suggestions and he was very knowledgeable on the menu. He made fantastic recommendations throughout the night. Amongst our favorites were the Spicy Tuna Tartare on Crispy Rice which combines the soft tuna with the crispy rice which work very well together; lobster wontons which had a welcomed complexity in flavor; and the miso glazed sea bass which was light, flaky, moist and so flavorful. I should also point out that the plates are family style portions for sharing which allows for interaction and great conversation. We had several dishes throughout our meal, wait staff were constantly removing empty plates, so our table never felt crowded or tight, our glasses were never low and they were there when we were ready for the next course. 

Food was outstanding, presentation was memorable and the service, superb!  The GM, Matt was beyond attentive and came by several times to make sure everything was perfect. He was very friendly and charismatic and treated us like family. Nick also stopped by during the latter part of our dinner to check on us, introduce himself, and let us know that he would be escorting us to the club upstairs once dinner was over. Nick treated us like a longtime friend and escorted us to the club to finish off the night with a bang! 

I definitely recommend Tao and I am already looking forward to our next visit! Thanks for making our celebration one for the books!

Great atmosphere! I went on a Saturday night around 8pm with a friend. The restaurant was busy but we were able to get some seats by the sushi bar. We ordered 4 maki rolls which were really good but be prepared to pay quite a bit for them. We also got a drink, coffee and shared a dessert. The total bill came to $130 USD plus tax and tip. However, the service is amazing and if you go on a club night, having dinner at Tao means you don't have to wait in line or pay cover at their club which is a bonus!

Food: 6/10 lobster wonton - not bad. The sea bass was decent and the filet mignon was pretty damn good. the presentation of dishes needs to be more detail oriented and creative. 

Sake: 10/10 great sake! one of the best collections i've experienced outside of japan

Service: 6/10 slow service. nonetheless friendly staff. 

Atmosphere: 8/10 a lot of buzz ... cool decor. 

Very underwhelmed on the whole as I had high expectations. One of the places I would recommend going to in vegas. 

un abrazo ;)
Lobster Kim Chee fried rice is one of the best things on the menu in my opinion.

Pros: Decoration is amazing! Miso soup, dumplings, fortune cookie desert, I wanted to eat the whole thing, is half vanilla and half chocolate. Server was very nice and was smiling all the time (you don't want a flat server).
Cons: sushi did not taste like sushi at all, too much rice and no flavor.

Our first night in Vegas for our Gal Vacai led us to get all dressed up and walk over to Tao for drinks, dinner, and dancing. 

We walked right in got a table pager and grabbed drinks at the bar. We sat at the cute little booth and chatted for less than 5 minutes when our pager started to buzz. 

We were seated next to the giant Buddha water fountain. Very nice decor! I ordered the Crispy Orange Chicken which was delish and my gal ordered the Black Pepper Filet Mignon with those yummy Udon Noodles add a side of rice and call me satisfied cause I liked it! 

We asked our waiter what time the party started and he said sorry ladies no party on Tuesdays. Boo! But he was nice enough to offer stamps to their sister club at the Palazzo Lavo (more on that later). 

After we ordered our server kinda disappeared and then we got a new guy who brought out our food and then the bill. We had to ask about the Lavo pass again. The manager came over and stamped our hands and that was it. This server weirdness is minus one star in my book. 

Okay about the bathrooms- they are not labeled male and female. Be warned ladies your yangs...I think. Remember I did go after a few drinks so I could be wrong.

Came to Tao twice in one week. Got lucky enough to have Zander as my waiter each time. Such a wonderful gentleman and took great care of the table each time.

Told him to just order for the table, everything he picked was fabulous. Best dining experience I have ever had in Vegas. 

Thank you Zander, thank you Tao
Not worth the cost.  Food was not prepared well and service was second rate. Would not recommend you waste your money here.

The reason I'm not giving this place a 5 is because we waited about 45 minutes with reservations. However, they made it up to us with free shots for the whole table. I had the seabass which completely just melted in my mouth, it was perfect. I also tried some stuff from friends and everything was delicious (wasabi steak, the filet mignon, and the sushi).
One of my favorite stops in Vegas. The Sea Bass is the by far the best thing on the menu. The coconut shrimp is good.  Don't get the Orange chicken...just not worth it.

I've been planning my birthday for the past 2 months and Tao restaurant was my destination.  Reservations were for Friday night 8:45pm. Note: Your required to confirm the day of the reservation before Noon.  Checked in with the matre' D was pleased to be escorted directly to our table.  It was already crowded with people at the lounge having drink while waiting for their own table?? There was 3 of us for dinner-2 guys and myself.  We were lead toward the back and seated at a table close to the sushi bar. Before you read any further this review is truly dedicated the service and to our waiter vs. the food.  In celebration of my birthday we ordered a bottle of the yellow label and Voss Sparkling water. After reviewing the menu, I asked the waiter what recommendations he had, and even though we ended up not getting anything that was mentioned, I thought it was great that he had extensive knowledge about the food.  We ordered:  Satay of chilean sea Bass with grilled asparas, Wasabe crusted filet mignon with tempura onion rings, Duck friend rice,Noodles and Short-ribs.  The food honestly was mediocre for the price that you are paying.  There are so much more comparable quality food here in SF  that don't cost and arm and a leg.  Needless to say I wasn't too disappointed as my expectations weren't that high, and I was paying to be part of the scene.  Now Kudos for the service, the waiter was extremely courteous, came at the right times to offer service,and always made sure that glasses were always filled.  I'm a lightweight and only drank a glass of champagne, I thought it was wonderful  that he was so observant and only filled up my companions glasses and only towards the end of dinner did he offer me more.  and lastly because there was a male to female Ratio at the clubs, even with a $300 dollar dinner I still wouldn't have been able to get in, he worked the magic and got all 3 of us line passes for the club because it was my birthday.  Above and Beyond.  
In summary: Tao Restaurant is a place to see and be seen, just don't have too hight expectations about the food.  Especially for those of you who live here in SF.

It was my first time going here and I really loved the Asian decor. Went here for our bachelorette's "last supper." We made reservations for 15 ladies and we got to sit in a private room. (Everyone in your party has to be there in order to get seated.) The room overlooked the first floor next to the giant Buddha and had the option of closing the curtains.

We got 2 private waiters who were very attentive. They gave us the option of doing separate entrees or doing family style for a set price. Either way, we'd get free entry to their club. We chose the family style and just had the waiter create our menu. He asked us if anyone was allergic to anything, which I thought was nice of him. Everything we  had was delicious!

Had a great experience here! Left with a delightfully full stomach =)

God, I am so irritated it's not even worth the energy and time to get all pissed off again telling you why I will probably never come back here.  Maybe if I was younger again and coudl deal with it - or if i was from somewhere where what they offer at Tao is "new" or "interesting".  

The waiter was an A-HOLE big time.  Before we ordered he YELLED AT US that he REFUSED TO DELIVER ANY FOOD UNTIL THE MENUS WERE ALL REMOVED FROM THE TABLE - basiclaly that means we can't get appetizers and order more later...Jerk?  Seriously?

Second of all, the food tastes like either Panda F**king Express (all noodle dishes) or it's completely covered in Sesame Oil.  Don't get me wrong - I LOVES me some sesame oil - but not when you can't taste what is is cooked with?

Finally, I think our bill was like $700, probably because we had 8 heavy drinkers there.  But it really felt like a rip - I paid $70 for drinks, one egg roll, and a bite of some Mall court noodles. 

no thanks!  Denny's is across the street and at least there you know what you're going to get.

Very intimate restaurant, decoration is beautiful and food was amazing. The portions are really big and everything is tasty and worth the price.

We had a reservation but they gave us the table 30 minutes later, they offered us 4 drinks for the inconvenience which was really appreciated.

We will definitely come back !

Ich berichte √ºber das Restaurant und nicht √ºber den Night-Club. Das super Stylische Ambiente ist wirklich einmalig und das Essen steht dem um nichts nach. Gute asiatische K√ºche, manchmal nicht allzu authentisch aber dennoch sehr schmackhaft wird hier serviert. 
Es kann durchaus etwas lauter werden, was Freude auf de Night Club macht !

Aside from the overhype that comes from being associated with a Kardashian, Tao does serve decent Asian food that is actually priced pretty well.The atmosphere and decor at the restaurant is really interesting and definitely blends the theme together.  I ordered Buddha's Harmonized Vegetable Feast and had a taste of my friend's Pad Thai as well.  Both dishes were delicious.  The vegetables were cooked just right and so tasty, and the Pad Thai had just enough peanut and spice in it.  I also enjoyed the Tao-Tini off of their specialty cocktails menu. It's a little sweet, so one drink was enough for me.  Be sure to make a reservation because the restaurant is very popular and will fill up very quickly.  If you'd like to go to the night club (which I definitely recommend!) ask your waiter to stamp you. You get free entry to the night club if you eat dinner at the restaurant.

Honestly, I wasn't too impressed with Tao.  
At least they serve late night dinners but the food and decor really didn't impress me.  

My BF actually found the big Buddha offensive, arguing that Americans would be appalled to walk into a American restaurant in China that had a huge Jesus towering over the dining room -- which totally makes sense [though I can't say I was bothered by the Buddha].

We ordered several things two of which the waitress recommended some sort of spicy chicken, which was not good -- how can you recommend this?! And the kobe beef appetizer -- which was one of the better items.  We ordered a couple more items to satisy our drunken appetites but I can't say all and all it was any good.

Really with all the hype around it, I expected something more, anything more than what we got and it wasn't cheap either. 

I wouldn't go back with so many good dining destinations in Vegas, don't waste your time eating here -- maybe just hit up the club.

i love the food but so pricey, long wait (even with reservation).  my fave dish is the small plate (sea bass).  small portions, so you can leave hungry unless you spend a fortune.

loud on weekends (dj and lots of people).  can get crowded/tight space.

After a hellacious road trip here, I decided to spoil myself for dinner. Ordered the sand pot lobster, shrimp, and scallop for 42$. Not impress. Mainly because I was expecting it to come out on sand. The name is a bit of a deceptive creative concept for alluring the diner to a more upscale price point. What came out was a clay pot. Something I can get in Chinatown for a fraction of the charge. Ordering rice? Upcharge. You mean steam rice does not come with my food? I am not a tight spender by any means, but 5$ for a bowl of steam rice that customary accompanies an Asian dish? 

Since I was myself, I had to take a seat at the bar. That means if you, like myself, wanted the Wagyu or Filet Mignon Shabu Shabu...it will be an impossiblity. Understandable. 

Ordered a sake flight and it was probably the best thing there. 

Outside of the ambiance, I'm not sure what the appeal is to dine here. I mean, unless you like your dining environment so loud, you can hardly hear yourself think...feel free. Probably going to come back and experience the night club scene. Oh, as one of the other Yelper suggests, I felt rushed to finish my food at the bar so they can seat more people.

Good Asian. From sushi to Chinese,Thai, and Korean dishes. Pricey but it's Vegas.
Wish I could remember our waiter he was awesome. Very enthusiastic and helpful. Young thin black guy. Excellent service from the gentleman.

The appetizer and main course was wonderful... Dessert is lacking. XO Hong Kong shrimp was amazing!!! Bottle up the sauce. Service was efficient but not very friendly. The place was too loud I couldn't hear my own conversation across our little table. Nice place but no romantic ambiance due to noise level and sitting on top of people next to us.

Best sushi we've ever had. Atmosphere, food and the waiter (Sam) were AMAZING. Because we ate there we got free entrance into the night club afterwards, which was also amazing. 

I usually hate sushi, but this sushi was very smooth and exceeded all of my expectations. Everyone I was with said that my sushi expectations are going to be extremely high after eating at Tao. Thanks for a great night!!!

The waiters and the employes have horrible attitude. i do not think they want to work.One thing you ask them they talk back with you wi h horrible attitude. one of them rolled there eyes because i asked what desert do you recommend and he said i won't recommend ill bring you a menu. they do not want to pour you water they don not want to talk or work. one of the waitresses was sweeping the floors and then grabbed my food and brought it to my table. i told my waitress he said he'll look in to that and i did not hear from him. and he kept on taking forever to tell me if he looked into it or not. overall this one star is probably for the food. i won't be back. hire some new waitresses maybe i will. they do not know how to work.

Been to several of these including one in Paris. The Las Vegas one is by far the worst one. The hosts are rude and condescending. We had a reservation and they did not seat us for an hour after our reservation time. Seriously? How do you run a restaurant like that. Obviously they rely on the tourists and conventioneers coming through. This location would be out of business if it were not for conventioneers.

Pleasantly surprised by the food. I wanted to experience a trendy Vegas restaurant and heard mixed reviews on Tao (NY and Vegas). However, I really enjoyed my dinner here.

First of all, the decor is beautiful, albeit ridiculous. A restaurant called Tao, filled with numerous Buddha statues including the nearly twenty feet tall one in the main room, large photographs of sumo wrestlers in one dining area, and large color photographs of Buddhist priests of varying ages decorating the hallway to the restroom, and the overall opulent decor? Not to mention the crowd of tourists and revealingly dressed beautiful and less beautiful people. Not sure this is what Buddha intended but overall a very beautiful lounge and restaurant.

We had a reservation (thank goodness; the place was packed) but had to wait about a half and hour. We got a drink at the bar. Yes, well drinks were expensive but not surprising for Vegas. Once we were seated, we had a nice view of the gigantic Buddha. Our server was very friendly and informative. I felt in general the waitstaff was attentive, even though the restaurant was so busy.

As appetizers, we ordered the lobster dumplings in shitake mushroom broth, spicy ahi tuna on top of crispy white rice (basically like nigiri) and the toro toro roll. The dumplings and broth were excellent but the skin of the won tons were a little thick. The spicy ahi tuna was yuuummmy. The toro toro roll was the weakest dish. The fish was not very prominent, which was disappointing since I love toro. This roll was also topped with some sort of crunchy, sweet cracker-like topping that I did not love. 

We also had two entrees: the black pepper flank steak and udon noodles, and miso-glazed sea bass. The steak and udon noodles were okay; nothing special. The miso-glazed sea bass was delicious and perfectly cooked. The vegetables it came with were somewhat of an afterthought but the sea bass was so beautifully cooked that I didn't care too much.

Definitely a fun, vibrant, LOUD environment. Overall, I was impressed by the quality and flavor of the food and I enjoyed the atmosphere.
The l.a location is so much better than here. The portion size of the dishes and the price for it isn't worth it. The sushi wasn't bad but it really wasn't  anything special. This place is overhyped.
Pad Thai was just ok. Service was not so great. Nice looking place though.  Wouldn't go back. The seating was cramped since we were on a bench next to another couple.

Being that I've been to the location in NY I had expectations. Place runs like a well oiled machine and even though we went with a large group they were very accommodating. Some people may take this as a negative (think it's too loud) but I love the fact they play music during their dinner service. Place is very dimly lit so if your one of those people that reads off a menu with your glasses and phone light you may want to go somewhere else to eat in the casino. Lobster Wontons, Miso Sea Bass, Wagyu Beef....Dim Sum menu worth a try as well.

The place was packed, busy and with Vegas energy. Not too long of a wait and when the food came, it was soooooooooooo worth it. My friend and I were blown away y all the flavors that worked so well with each other excellently. 
The food was A+++

I have been to Tao before, though usually earlier in the evening and we liked it enough to go back. Well, that is the last time I will be going there and also the last time I will recommend that anyone else go either. 

Like many of the other reviewers I had made a dinner reservation (far in advance) for a Sat night dinner. The best time we could get was 10:15. After waiting in line for the "reservation check-in" we were told they would call us when our table was ready and they gave us a pager. Well wait we did. We didn't get seated until and hour later! What kind of restaurant operation takes reservations and then makes you wait an hour anyway? That is really poor front of the house operation. 

FOOD: The Shabu-Shabu Filet was terrible. It tasted like they had left the raw meat sitting out for hours. The green beans we all ordered tasted like they drenched them in fish sauce, and I could tell that they had not changed the oil in their fryer in quite some time as the spring rolls (both appetizer and dessert kind) tasted like rancid oil and were too hard to bite through! Not one person at our table commented on liking their food. 

The wait staff seemed to be attentive but that was only the first time our waiter came to the table. After that time we had to try and find our waiter to flag him down. When it came time to pay and we were obviously done for quite some time, he was nowhere to be found. Even worse, three of us paid to have sparkling water instead of just tap water and when we were about half way done with our glasses, someone actually came around and refilled them with with tap water! If you are going to hire people who can pay attention or at least ask the question, then maybe you should serve your waters in different glasses since there are three options.

After our mediocre and ridiculously overpriced meal we went to go to the club upstairs. They came around and gave us stamps at the table that would allow us access without waiting in the long line and without paying. When the first person got to the front of the smaller line he was charged entry for two to get in ($50!!). Immediately we said, "wait we don't have to pay" Instead of being able to credit him back for the charge or just giving him cash, the manager came over and gave him drink tickets instead. He acted like he was being soooo nice by giving him and the girl he paid for a ticket and then a second one each. What, 4 drinks for $50, not including tip?? Geee, thanks so much for the generosity. To top it all off, the club sucks. Cheesy, bad flow and really bad air flow. We decided to go up the Tao Beach instead to get outside and that was better as far as being able to move around and breath, but the cockroaches running around were a bit of a turnoff.

With all of the choices in Vegas now, this place needs to step up their service and food quality or be replaced.

I appreciate a fine dining experience as much as the next guy and am certainly not opposed to dropping the kind of coin it cost for such an experience. However, Tao in the Venetian in Las Vegas was nothing short of a major disappointment. Our dinner consisted of two people, one drink each, two apps, two entres (I had the wasabi Filet Mignon) and one dessert. Tab with tip was just short of $180.

The service was exceptional as expected but the food, our primary reason for booking this visit, was just average. I would suggest RA as I have eaten there a number of times and it never disappoints.

I'm going to give 5 stars. I want to explain it all from start to finish. I made a boo boo on open table but Dru was so nice and since we arrived early he said peak would not be for another 30 min so we sat down immediately.  my reservation was made for the one in New Jersey! Oops. So bad. I was just sitting there like omg "I never do this". Then up pops Jeffrey at table and he's so nice and chipper.  He made me feel at home and un rushed!  For making boo boo on my reservation I think I may have got the best server in the house. He's so awesome. 

I also met one of the managers, Kong, he came by to check on me and he was very informative. I'll remember his name like "King Kong" lol. Anyway so I'm eating and everything is delicious. Service is beyond great. I'm going to TAO nightclub again but Just to see what's up. I'll provide pics as I go but 5 stars for how they treated me and how delicious the food and service are. 

I'm

Eh, Hard time choosing between 3 and 4 on this place.  

Drinks: Asian Beers- nothing special but the price. come on, its vegas. I can hop on a table and get fed free beer all night. No reason to charge me 9 dollars a beer. Also beer is the only beverages without prices in the drink menu. Wonder why??? -1

Appetizer- Sushi- The sushi was tasty, but for this scale of restaurant (not to mention price) it should have been better......actually i have had better sushi in Reno in a dump of a casino.  -1

Food- Wasabai crusted Filet with onion rings. Cooked really well exactly as ordered . +2. 

Desert- skipped it, nothing looked good. Ordered beer instead. 


Do yourself a favor, go to one of the other thousands of great restaurants other than here if your in Vegas and reading this.

Not often do I give 5 stars, but the food, fun and service was exceptional. I came here because Kim K had her birthday party here and couldn't have been more happy! Shanna provide excellent service to my party of 7 and we had an amazing dinner. We dined at 6pm, so there was not too long of a wait and the host even chatted with us while we did. This customer service from host to waitresses will definitely have me bring back my service here! Also, they do professional cakes right after your dinner!

Absolutely incredible food and service. The Miso glazed Sea bass tasted as moist as cake. It is indescribable! My husband had the Ahi tuna , the wasabi sauce was unreal. The layers of flavors in that sauce were like nothing I have ever tried. We could have drunk it! Service was impeccable.. We will for sure come back. I am tempted to go back tonight!

food was not bad, chicken dumplings and a tempura mushroom pot thing was pretty good. 
we just sat at the bar they offered a full menu, no reservation needed just walk in early,
if you eat there they give you a priority stamp so you dont have to wait in the tao line, which is hella long, girls are free guys were $30.

overall not bad, but not the best food I have had.
Amazing dining experience! The service was excellent and the food was delicious. I forget our servers name but wow, he was so warm and welcoming.

What can I say, I love TAO! I have been to the one in NYC by central park and loved it. Have to say I loved this one too! The entrance is located inside the Venetian near the entrance to the gondola shops. They also have a cute little TAO gift shop. The entrance to TAO is a dark tunnel with pools with rose petals, so purdy! We sat on the main floor in front of the budda. 

I was pleased to see they have a couple of my favorites. The dragon tail spare ribs, and the sandpot! The waiter asked if we have ever been to TAO before, which I responded of course! I asked if he had any favorites, and he liked the coconut shrimp. Like a creature of habit I went for my favorites. The coconut shrimp is an entre√© but we ordered it as an appetizer. It was so good! The shrimp was perfectly cooked and the coating was crispy. Next we got the dragon tail ribs! They were so good and meaty! They were so tender you can eat them with a fork! When we were received our sandpot I noticed something strange, no lobster?! I asked the waiter and they prepare it a little different then in NYC. They de-shell the lobster and let it saut√© in the garlic sauce. Either way it was still delicious. It was also a plus not to have to work at my food LoL.  So in good TAO fashion, its dessert time! You can not go to TAO and NOT get the fortune cookie! So good! It's a giant fortune cookie filled with vanilla mousse on one side and vlchocolate mousse on the other, and served with fresh fruits. All in all a good time was had by many! This place should be a must on your next visit!

We came with a party of 6 and left after over an hour of waiting with reservations. The ma√Ætre'd was perhaps the most obnoxious person I've ever experienced on this planet. Even with the reservations, we were told that we could expect to wait about a half hour. When our buzzer rang 20 minutes later that ma√Ætre'd angrily told us that it had only been 20 minutes and that our signal had certainly not gone off or went off in error.

I hang with a pretty yuppie crowd back home and I'm typically prepared for dealing with the posh and pretentious crowd that frequents Tao and places like it. What I was not prepared for was dining in a night club with staff that was even more pretentious than its already pretentious clientele (and I fairly count myself amongst them).

Tone down the music and fire half the staff (our cocktail waitress was great), and I think Tao would be something special. As it stands, the ma√Ætre'd spoiled my dinner long before it had arrived.

The first time I came was about 4 years ago for a comp dinner with a few friends. I don't remember the food exactly, but I so remember myself saying that I would have been upset if I had paid for my meal. 

Fast forward 4 years to October 24, 2013. I was invited to dinner for someone's "birthday." I wasn't too thrilled it was being celebrated here since I don't remember having an awesome experience before. Restaurant is a bit cramped, but they do cater to very large parties. I wasn't too bothered by the lighting being dark, but I could see how it would bother other people who actually want to see their food. As for the noise level, it's located in a club, so expect it to be above normal. None of this really bothered me, it's the actual food that gets to me.

If I'm going to dish out $$$ for food, it better be spectacular. And Tao did not deliver. I ordered the sizzling rice with Peking duck. For the price I paid, I could have just made that myself. I also got to sample the other dishes my friends ordered, and I was not impressed by any of them. The highlight of the night was the dessert platter which I thought was yummy. There are so many other good places to eat in Vegas for way less money. I know for sure I won't be back.

My coworker had heard about the miso glazed chilean sea bass via some Food Network show and said he had to stop by. "Oh why not", was my thought process. 

I'm sure glad I did. Sit at the bar and give it a try. You won't be disappointed.

Beautifully decorated!  

I dined here with a group of 8 and we never waited for anything, which was great but also expected at the level of restaurant that this was not to mention it's in Las Vegas and goes with the territory.  

I ordered the Black Pepper Filet with Udon Noodles it had a great strong flavor, I liked it for the most part however later on I burped pepper steak all night which is not very sexy when you're partying.

The Chilean Sea Bass was a popular dish at our table (aka Patagonian Toothfish which is currently over fished and should be avoided by all chefs and consumers!)

My husband ordered the Wasabi Steak it was surprisingly mild, but good.  Additionally ordered was the Shabu-Shabu, the presentation was quite nice and after eating this multiple times recently in Japan I felt that it was translated nicely. 

The Chef's Roll was a great starter as well as the Lobster Dumplings.

Came here for a business dinner. The club scene here must be really good - otherwise, I don't know why it has the reputation it has. The food was so-so. It's ultra dark and loud in there. It was kind of weird to dine upstairs and see part of the place roped off and empty. I was expecting a cooler vibe.

Ambiance is outstanding at Tao in the Venetian hotel. I had one meal of choice during my work trip to Vegas and I chose Tao. The Open Table reservation was easy, and Tao even called ME the day before to confirm, nice!

Our party of three enjoyed the sexy stylings of Tao- in one room you've got a 16-foot Buddha with a wall of white votives, in another you've got a wall of eye popping multicolored squares with objects embedded, they've got an upstairs as well. Everything is just gorgeous.

The short rib appetizer special melted in your mouth, and service was on point all night, explaining the specials and checking in on us frequently. I had their specialty sea bass in a miso reduction over braised vegetables. At first it didn't wow me, but the more I ate it, the better it got! Very good dish. 

Everything our table ordered was outstanding, and I would love to come back to try their sushi and specialty rolls. I think my only complaint is that Tao advertises a dress code, but then you do see LV tourists traipsing in with their shorts and sandles. I guess it's inevitable, but wish Tao would keep to the code, as it's a nice place that deserves nicer dress.
Great food and the service was supreme. The entire staff was extremely helpful, and professional.

This was some of the best Asian food we've ever had. The service was outstanding and the food equal. I highly recommend the Chilean Seabass and the Shobu Shobu. Also, the giant fortune cookie dessert was excellent! It was busy but we never felt ignored and the quality of the food didn't suffer.  I'm not usually comfortable with a bathroom attendant but it' s a nice touch.
Amazing food and great atmosphere! We were comp'ed our dinner prior to the club as a bonus and everything we had was delicious

The service is great, ambience interesting, and giant fortune cookie dessert was delicious. However, the noise was so loud that it was very difficult to hear my husband from across the table, there were few truly vegetarian dishes, since most were made with a fish base (all but 2 sides were, and only the 2 least appetising noodle dishes could be customised this way). The service was pretty spectacular, but he lack of options, high cost, and noise made me give this only a moderate score.

Perfect atmosphere! Great food, delicious cocktails, attentive waiter! A great experience in dining!
Dragonberry punch was splendid! Crab cakes were yummy and appropriately spicy, the shrimp and lobster rolls divine! Kobe beef was so flavorful and delicious!
Highly recommend this restaurant! It's a high end Asian restaurant! Quite a few steps up from your traditional asian place.

My plane was leaving and I had reservations at Le Cirque because of their strict dress policy of wearing pants in 110 degree weather, I would have to go back to the hotel, change my clothes in the restroom, come back to the restaurant... change my clothes again... anyway I decided to go here because I could wear dress shorts and still eat.

The entrance is dark and romantic with pools of rose water and candles. The interior is ancient sheik.

My waiter was helpful and I chose some sushi, The Spring Mountain roll. It was beautiful, fresh and well made but I have had better tasting sushi.

My entree was the Miso Glazed Chilean Sea bass which I tried for the first time in Vegas and liked.

This is a very hip sheik, expensive restaurant will beautiful Asian decorations. My plane was leaving so I didn't know about their attached night club which I could have gotten into for FREE!!!!!

I've always HATED Vegas...until this last trip.  Unfortunately, Tao was the one blight on the trip.  The food was ok and the bill wasn't outrageous, which can be a typical Vegas pitfall.

We ate family-style and had a roll that I'm fairly certain is an exact rendition of fish-food., which was partly our fault for eating sushi on a Sunday.  The food came out so quickly that we didn't really have much time to enjoy our meal.  That is not to say that they were trying to turn the table over though, it took about 45 minutes to receive our bill and pay for it.

Bottom-line: the food was mostly edible and the service was alright.

We went here on a recommendation from professional Vegas vacationer and we had our best meal here during our trip to Sin City.  

The server was very attentive and made suggestions for all our courses and he was spot on.  We had a tuna appetizer that still melts in my mouth.  I believe I ordered salmon for dinner and my friend ordered some sort of fish and we both found them excellent and perfect portions. 

Our cocktails were inventive and upscale.  The restaurant, just like most places in Vegas, was something to view in and of itself with a gigantic Buddha in the middle of the restaurant.  

Can't wait to visit Tao in NY.  My only pet peeve?  No one knew they were supposed to pronounce the place "Dow".

This is a really fun place to go with a group of friends and the food was well-liked by everyone in our 10-person group - especially the ladies. A bit pricey, but quite enjoyable nonetheless. 

When you have a large group, as we did, I would advise getting a lot of plates to share. You can always get more of anything you love. We started with sushi and moved on to Squab Lettuce Wraps and Satay Chicken, all of which was very tasty. Personally, I love dim sum and I felt the Crispy Pork Bao Buns to be about my favorite dish of the night. The Miso Glazed Chilean Sea Bass was probably the most popular dish among the group. Tao also has several Wagyu beef offerings and I haven't found too much fault with any of them.

All in all, a great dinner in a great venue with plenty of ambiance. If the girls are having a good time, then I'm having a good time!
The best Peking duck we have ever had, delicious , crispy  ,perfect. Fabulous service. The restaurant decor and atmosphere beyond excellent.

Good food but pretty damn expensive.   Really you go here for the experience.   Lots of sexy people here so dress your best.    I had the Salmon which was delicious.  You'll easily spend over $100 if you take a date here.   I wouldn't order drinks though, as they are WAY overpriced.  ($17 for a shot of Patron).

We had:
- Spicy Tuna Tartare on crispy rice
- Salmon sashimi with avocado, crispy onions and sweet and spicy sesame sauce
- Yellowtail sashimi with jalapeno and ponzu sauce
- dragon tail spareribs
- Steamed snapper with scallion oil and dashi-soy

The best thing of the night was the salmon sashimi, everything else was just blah. In fact, we took a bite out of the spareribs and decided not to eat it. It had a really strong sweet honey flavor that was just off-putting. Giving it a three star because the rest of the food is ok.

We did the tasting menu here, and it blew my mind!

I loved everything they brought out, and it was so nice not having to order. I would definitely come back here and suggest this to friends.

My friends have been coming her on Thursday or Wednesday night's as a group, but my first time here was Thursday night for a friend's going away party. 

Upon entry, we waited at the lounge area, which was very nicely decorated and close in proximity to the restaurant diners. Within 10 minutes with our reservation, we were seated. Apparently there are deals in which you can bring a group of people and pay a certain amount for a variety of dishes that are served to you.

Thankfully, great price for the amount of food we got (7 girls paying about $15 each for the many plates of food, plus a cocktail and shot, & still had food left over), atmosphere and decor were beautiful, service was fast and friendly, and the food was delicious! I will definitely be back again! 

The only thing: it is pretty loud in there so it may be hard to hear your server or what type of food they are putting on your table. Don't be afraid to ask!
**yes, there were vegetarian options with the variety of foods they put down. And they ask in advance if anyone is allergic to anything!
Great apps and dinner. Pushy waiters though smh.

Amazing food and service ! Great ambiance ! Every time I go to Vegas I make sure to come here . We started with my usual the spicy tuna on the crispy rice . Then the chicken pad Thai noodles and the shrimp friend rice and then two special sushi rolls . And too top it off got the special fortune cookie. Def recommend coming here !

I'll be fair in saying that it's not the worst I've had because it wasn't, but please, for a restaurant in Vegas... 

My friends took me here because we would get entry to the club if we ate at the restaurant - now, I'm not big on spending loads of money on food, I prefer the simple yet delicious; but I thought, hell, it's a Vegas joint so it's bound to hit the spot.

I was disappointed. My friend got sushi, it was really good. My other friend got swordfish it was good. I got chicken and while it was good (you can't mess up chicken), it wasn't worth $25. For $25 I got a thigh and half a breast of chicken and... and what? That's it. Fine dining at it's best... I don't get a side of veggies or rice or tates, just chicken. 

Maybe I don't understand the whole realm of fine dining, but why would I pay $25 for a piece of chicken that I could definitely cook better at home and not get anything to compliment it? 

The decor was nice and all but honestly, it's a little too dim in their for me. Sure, it sets a mood blah blah blah, but I'm not going to be in any mood but seeing an optometrist after I have to strain my eyes looking at the menu in dusk-like light.

As much as I enjoyed a piece of my friends sushi, I'm confident in saying that I will not be returning here in the near future. If I come up at the tables, I might stop by for a roll or two, but don't count on it.

Wonderful and extremely helpful waiter. If you don't get the sea bass you're wrong! I only wish the music was softer so I could enjoy a nice conversation with my husband for our anniversary. 
Everyone must experience TAO when they come to Vegas!

The food is over priced and decadently displayed, but hey it's Vegas and I expect no less. I must say the service is great and the ambiance and decor is really really interesting to look at. With an RSVP we did not have to wait, and there is also a cool lounge area for those without reservations. I recommend the lobster won tons, veggie dumplings, and the fish. The drinks are good as well. I would come back just for the experience of eating next to a giant Buddha.

The big Buddha in the restaurant was watching as we devoured sushi, sashimi and a few rolls between 3 very hungry people. This was excellent sushi and we were able to walk in with a reservation made 5 minutes in advance---at the concierge desk. The atmosphere is wonderful and service was excellent. I look forward to trying again.

local friend took us for dinner here on our first night in LV, a popular place and can get crowded. The ambiance is really nice as their decorations create a really nice atmosphere. we enjoyed the variety of food, server was extremely nice

Super sexy vibe - Check (the rose-petal filled tubs at the entrance; the music; the Eastern inspired decor; and the giant Buddha in the room's center really set the scene). 

Good food - Check (I highly recommend the sake-infused mushrooms; the yellow-tail roll with fried scallions; the roasted shisito peppers; and the spicy tuna tartare atop crispy rice) 

Good drink - Check (if you're in the mood to experiment, the mango tamarind martini's fabulous). 

Good service - Check. 

All in all, a great place to have a night special on the Strip..... but get ready to shell out some pretty pennies 'cause this place ain't cheap!

had dinner at TAO couple of times now.  service has always been outstanding (literally on point) lol 
Food DELISSHHH, outstanding texture and flavor!  lobster dumplings and the typhoon lobster my fav!! crispy orange chicken is also great..sashimi is excellent..
loud lounge type of environment makes dinner fun! haha

First of all my favorite thing to do in Vegas is eat. Tao makes no exception to please. First course Lobster Wontons, super delish and Sashimi Lobe Beef just melted in your mouth. All the entrees we shared were amazing, cocktails superb. The decor was great but to be expected from all over the top Vegas restaurants. I only wish there was one in Chicago.
Great service, great food and beautiful people! Sea Bass app is the best and the duck for two great entree. We went to the club upstairs afterwords and had a blast. Great Job Tao!

For Valentines day me and wife stayed in Las Vegas and decided to eat at Tao. When you first walk in the place looks great and we were really excited. That is the only good thing I can say about this place is the ambiance. 

When we were seated are waiter seemed more like a used car salesman then a waiter. We told him what we wanted to order and he seemed to be pushing the more expensive meals on us. We decided to go off his recommendation and we paid $40 just a one small peace of slimy sea bass. The shrimp was 2 pieces for $8. My local sushi spot gives you like 5 or 6 and it tastes way better.

It's a little loud for quiet conversation, which is a shame because you certainly will want to talk about the food! We shared the creamiest potstickers I have ever had! We also shared perfectly cooked tempura and fried rice with Chinese Sausage and Egg as well as a spicy crispy coconut shrimp that smelled of Thai basil and the ocean! We topped it off with the surprising Mango Rice Pudding, which I would come back for again and again! Creamy rice in a mango custard, with mango sorbet and topped with a melted sugar coating that proved crispy and chewy for a great mouth feel! Yes, drinks are super pricey and nothing special, so spend your money on dinner and save room for dessert!

I've been to the club here before, which will be reserved for a seperate review.  Dining at Tao is one of those Vegas experiences that you will remember.  Located at the Venetian, which is like a LEGO-land comprised of the Gritti Palace and the Royal Danieli with St. Mark's and the Grand Canal thrown in for good measure, Tao is a Buddhist temple amid this garbled baroque mess.  

You will need reservations here and expect to have a drink at the bar, which isn't all too bad considering the loads of eye candy hanging around, as if they are apart of the scenery, so you will be sure to see something that you like.  Take the opportunity to order a Grey Goose and soda, sit on one of the couches, and look at all the hot Asian broads w/their raven tresses and wasp-thin waists, and the European bitches in their Milanese high heels and tossed-boob salad exploding out of their wrap-dresses.  Yes, yes, tres chic, I know. 

The dining room is dim, crowded, and there's a thousand conversations going on at one and the same time.  Not sure if I'd come here for a "special occasion" type of dinner, as in ask your girl to marry you or to tell your mistress you're married.  Our waiter was cool, reminded me of a SoCal dude, like he'd hang out in Venice Beach.  

For dinner we started off with the spicy tuna tartare and kobe beef shashimi - both were to die for (the tuna was crisp and crunchy, and the kobe beef was like eating Kobe Tai, go figure).  With our main course (we both got the miso glazed Chilean sea bass) we paired it up with the lobster and kimchi rice (again, an excellent choice). 

I'm a sake novice and was open to suggestion: we started off with the sake sampler, and with our dessert got the sake dessert sampler, I believe, and me and my bud both agreed that the cloudy Voices in the Mist was our least favorite - I walked out of here a bit rocked.  For dessert we opted for the giant fortune cookie.  

In the end, $244.00 for two before tip, which, in my opinion, isn't bad at all considering what we got.  Will definitely make it here again and do our best to revitalize the economy.

We had a truly fantastic dining experience here until the very end.( I will get to that point in a minute. ) We were sat right next to the big Buddha which made for a fun dining experience. Our waitress was fantastic and everything was spot on. My girlfriend and I ordered a round of Sushi and split one of their small plate entrees of the sea bass. We liked everything so much, we ordered a second round. We truly enjoyed our experience at Tao!!!!!!!

The only negative: We were there at about 10:30 pm and as we were finishing, we were asked if we were interested in going up to the nightclub. We said sure and they stamped our hands. When we walked up, the guy told us we still needed to go outside and stand in line . . . even though we had dined there. I thought for sure I misunderstood, so asked him again and he was extremely rude. At that point I asked the hostess and she showed us the line. Sorry Tao . . . we had better things to do than stand in your line after we just dined at your restaurant. So . . . off to the next place!!! Way to take an enjoyable experience to a ticked off experience in a matter of minutes.

Im going to start off by saying how ANGRY I am about how amazing this food was. I walked out of here wondering why I haven't had this place before. Went with a group of friends, and i was the least hungriest, but once the food came out, I was the one that ate the most. Everything from the vibe to the service and the food especially is PERFECT!

First of all this is one of our favorite restaurants in vegas, whether we're just eating dinner or celebrating a special occasion.  Everything on the menu is delicous and the cocktails  hands down are some of the best that I've ever had.  Dont forget to order the giant fortune cookie for dessert, it doesnt dissapoint.

Lets start with the arrival. We had a reservation Friday at 9 PM. Granted, it is a Friday and reservations are not an exact science - but this restaurant was certainly well overbooked. It would appear they are more concerned about making sure the restaurant is at capacity than customer experience. 

We were seated around 9:35 PM. After complaining that this was unacceptable, the host picked up our first round of drinks. 

Once seated, the noise level in the restaurant makes talking next to impossible. I felt myself yelling to communicate, which I am sure perpetuates into an even louder restaurant. 

We had ordered a king crab roll. It was mediocre at best. I have had thicker crab meat at the buffet across the street. And for this price ($18 if I recall correctly), I am sure 50% of the price was paying for where I was eating. 

The highlight of the meal was the dessert. We had the yazu trio donuts. They were delicious. 

The lounge was nice. Ample seating space for you to lounge after eating. Drinks are the same price as you would expect on the strip in any top scale lounge/club.

Whenever someone asks me what my most favorite food is, I always say the Honey Miso Glazed Chilean Sea Bass at the Tao Restaurant. This is one of those dishes that when you taste it, your eyes roll backwards and all you can say is Oh.... My God. It is that good.... No lie. I like the restaurants d√©cor with its upscale/trendy/Asian style. High ceilings that create a feel of openness. Interesting art, sculptures and artifacts that adorn the walls. This place offers everything you would expect to find in a 5 star restaurant. Excellent service,innovative gourmet food and fine dining. Expect to spend a lot of moola.
Food poisoning. When you spend 250 bucks on a meal you'd expect a certain level of sanitary conditions. I feel more confident about the hole in the wall cat hunters. Gf was throwing up all day.

Decor is great and the service was nice overall, especially considering it was a nightlife venue. The food was nothing spectacular, but in defense of the restaurant I thought my group ordered poorly. Got Spicy Lobster Roll, Angry Dragon Roll , Satay of Chilean Sea Bass, Pad Thai Noodles, and a bunch of drinks. I ordered a round of drink for some friends at another table, but one got drunk and they all left, so we have to drink them. I drank so much, I forgot to order the large fortune cookie for dessert. The drinks were ok to good. We got the Mango Tamarind Martini, Xi Gua Tini, Lychee Martini, TAO Love Potion #9, TAO-tini, and some Patron. Og, the Miso Sea Bass (appetizer or entree) was great. Miso fish usually is.

Tao is an excellent choice for Asian cuisine! The establishment is very chic with a modern/sexy decor & design elements. 

Staff was eager to sell menu features and made strong suggestions on what to order based on what your party was in the mood for. 

Items ordered: Shrimp Lettuce Wraps, Sea Bass, Chinese Fried Rice, Coconut Shrimp, Filet, and Chicken Lo Mein

Tao takes reservations and has dining available up and downstairs. The establishment is a nightclub and restaurant all in one. If you want to dine to impress your friends, or yourself- this is the place to be! Recommend to all.

Thanks Yelpers, I am quite impressed with the consensus on Tao!  It's not NYC, but it puts its best foot or food forward.  If you read my last review on Alex I had to chastise you guys a little bit, but fret not, you have been redeemed.  After an amazing "evening with Cher" @ Caesars palace, my friend and I fell through Tao and had an extraordinary time.  Details:

Arrival was swift, I anticipated a wait based on prior Yelpers experience, and received the Olive Garden style beeper then shown to the well decorated and seductively lit lounge with quite a view of the gussied up Vegas party-goers.  

After about twenty minutes, my dining companion and I received our table with a round of drinks on the house due to the wait.  Way to go on the customer service Tao.  I had the Tao-tini--A+ my friend the Tao Cosmo.  Both smooth and easy.  

The food--ordered in portions and had wonderful dishes:
Spicy Lobster/Crab roll excellent
Steamed Veggie Dumplings--needs extra dunking sauce yum yum
Dragon Tail ribs--ok could have done without
Crispy Rice Tuna Tartar--OMG, could have 2 of these
Hot Edamame--fav.

Dessert was over the top:  
Giant Fortune Cookie exploding w/ chocolate mousse VERY rich, so be warned
Rice Pudding Creme Brule w/ extra scoop of ginger ice cream!  Just like mom used to make back south--right.  

Our waiter was helpful, but a bit stuffy--otherwise an overall stellar performance by Tao.  Be careful not to trip on the way out over the eager Tao nightclub revelers.
Not too many veggie options...but good ambience and positive vibe....crowd is awesome...

Food was delicious, service was great. Our server was Dawn and she was great and really sweet. My fianc√© had the Scallops and loved it. My sea bass was delicious as well. We were celebrating our anniversary and Dawn brought out dessert with "Happy Anniversary" written on it. We aren't from the area, but would definitely come back if we come back into do. Definitely recommend!

Service was fast and friendly. The food was excellent I had the v give fried rice and honestly it's probably the best I've ever had. Can't wait to return and this time i don't even need the menu I know what I want it was that good

Went here expecting a delicious meal, but the food is considerably better at P.F. Changs and the stuffy borderline outright snobby attitude of every single staff member encountered terribly disappointed me. About the only thing I would go here for is the sake selection. Other than that, skip the restaurant, and maybe check out the nightclub.

Great food and outstanding service. Both the nightclub and the restaurant offer excellent service. At Tao you do get what you pay for. 
Keep up the good work guys.

One of the sexiest places to eat on the strip!

I visit LV once a year from Australia and my vacation isn't complete without a night out at Tao. I've also dined at the New York location but prefer this venue at the Venetian.

I book via OpenTable and reservations are a must. If you plan to hit up a club I recommend having a late dinner around 9:30pm and moving upstairs to the club straight after. 

This saves a painful wait in line (otherwise be prepared for selective entry) and the bonus of not having to pay a cover charge.

This restaurant was phenomenal, as was our waiter, Lars. We let the chef select our meal choices for us and split family style amongst 4 people. In doing so, we were able to determine a budget of $60 per person and were treated to a huge array of stuff. I never would have picked a $50 New York beef dish on my own, or a $34 coconut shrimp, but both were completely worth it. Best coconut shrimp I've ever had. Sushi was also incredible. They were courteous about timing as well and made sure our 3 course meal still left plenty of time to get to our evening show.

Ok you have to try the $85 steak AMAZING!!! The best steak I ever had. A bit salty for me BUT you can ask for no salt. The crab cakes with mango sauce are very good also! The lobster fried rice was way way too salty!

As a nightclub that serves food, this is really up there in terms of flavor and quality. I don't know if comparing this to other "club food" is setting the bar too low, but this place definitely delivered.

We had Tao reserved for a company function and the food was top notch, the staff friendly and the alcohol mixing excellent. Each table got a huge plate of delicious sea bass (among other dishes) and everything was gone at the end of the night. I realize its hard to screw up sea bass since it usually comes out shiny and melts in your mouth like a stick of butter, but w/e. It was awesome.

There is a decent amount of presentation involved as well, both in the setting and the actual dishes. I wish I had more details but the open bar slowly made the entire evening blurry and dark. Fun of course....but like...what happened again..? Go eat here, dont expect like 5 star restaurant experience but its fun. If social house was still open at TI then I'd rather eat there but its closed now.

Book this place in advance and place it in your calendar on your iPhone one day before you want to go to,  The sure way to get to TAO night club is by going here and getting a food stamp. Drinks are usually 20$ a pop without tip and great selections before they find you a table.

Dinner is really awesome and good portions and amazing art work on the ceiling and a giant Buddha.

We celebrated at the restaurant for my birthday.  The food our party ordered was absolutely delicious.  Granted, I was a tad bit wasted by then.. But I remember thinking how great everything tasted.  I ordered the lobster kimchi fried rice, others ordered the sea bass, filet mignon noodles, and I forgot the rest.  In any case, I tasted all the dishes and have nothing negative to say.  At the end, the waiter brought me a giant fortune cookie which was scrumptious!  We had made reservations, but ended up waiting way too long.  Besides the wait, I highly recommend Tao.  Great Asian food and awesome ambiance.

Not sure if this restaurant even deserves one star. We had to wait over an hour for a table and never got seated and ended up leaving the restaurant. Keep in mind we did have reservations! It was so crowded we couldn't even walk or find a place to sit. There were constantly employees telling you to move so they could escort people up to the nightclub. I would not waste my time here. There are plenty of other great places in the area with less people.

Thanks to Derrick Runtas for recommending this restaurant to us - we had a group of 10 people place is beautiful staff is friendly . Waiter offered us $75 course which pretty much has everything on the menu. For that price in vegas is great def coming back :)

Not worth the price tag. The hot and sour soup was bland. The lobster pad Thai lacked the requisite tang of fish sauce and tamarind. The 4-spice short ribs were too wet and on the bland side. Asparagus was tasty as was the edamame. Portions were hefty but size doesn't make up for overall lackluster flavor.
The place is very dark and filled with Asian tchotchkes and photos. Disney meets China. It had a manufactured vibe, similar to a PF CHANGS. Not really good but good enough.
Not recommended if you're a person of epicurean quality.

Sausage fried rice was recommended by our server, honestly sounded gross but it was one of the most memorable meals I've ever had. So flavorful. Also had the filet pepper steak and it was excellent as well. Really enjoyable experience people watching but the highlight was the food. Wasn't expecting a lot, thought Tao was all hype but its worth the visit for the sausage friend rice alone.

I'm honestly surprised this isn't rated higher - I had a wonderful experience and my food was delicious. We made a reservation ahead of time so we were sat immediately and had a perfect view of the giant buddha statue in the center of the restaurant. I had never tried sake before so I got their flight and enjoyed the different flavors. The edamame was our stater - always a good choice - and my shrimp pad thai was unreal. I would definitely go back here.

The actual restaurant is wonderful, but the bathroom is from out of a nightmare. First there are no clear markers for women and men bathroom. once you figure out the right bathroom, there is a MASSIVE hole under the mirror 6ft long and 1 ft wide that allows men from the men's bathroom to taunt and harass you while you wait to use the stalls and wash your hands. This is not a safe place for women and I want to warn people about this bathroom before you go because it was horrible and violating. I am calling management today to make a complaint and will be calling the police to notify them of what is clearly a violation of bathroom safety law. I also will be contacting my lawyer.

The most delicious sushi I've ever had! My partner and I loved every second of our time spent at Tao! The setting is so enticing and dramatic, I'm daydreaming about coming back here for a romantic anniversary dinner! When in Vegas, Tao is a must! Share as much as you can. Satay, tempura, sushi, filet mignon, giant fortune cookie... all unbelievably yummy!

Janurary 22nd-it was my Mommy's Bday(i'm such an awesome daughter, I know) so I decided to treat her(and dad and brother-once again I'm awesome) to a nice restaurant to celebrate. I had already been before, but it had been a while and it was for clubbing purposes only, so i had forgotten how pretty (and DARK) it was inside. There was a slight line, but i had reservations so i didn't have to wait for a table. It was pretty crowded (but it was a Friday in Las Vegas so duh). so our table was slightly cramped but no big deal. 
I ordered shrimp tempura, and california rolls. My mother also ordered some sushi(can't remember which ones) but everything was good,  My dad had some spare ribs that were extremely tender(i got a piece off his plate) and my brother ordered the Thai Duck fried rice-which was so good, he ordered another and I ordered one for myself. 

So because I checked into Tao via Yelp I received a free ginormous fortune cookie for dessert. It was filled with chocolate and vanilla mousse and very yummy. And because our waiter was so nice, he brought a second one free of charge with candles to celebrate my mom's birthday. Very cool. She enjoyed it and it made her bday memorable-and solidified my position as her coolest child.

I didn't know it was open so late which is def a bonus in vegas.  After a certain time its hard to find exactly what your looking for and my boy was craving asian fusion.  so we headed down to try it out.  The pan seared pot stickers were amazing and the rest of the food we tried was just ok.  It did hit the spot though and you never know we could end up here again some late night.  Glad we tried it out

I went to dinner on a Thursday night with a group of 9 fellow Yelpers to celebrate a special occasion. Glad we had reservations because the place got packed in just a few minutes. It was very dark and very loud. We spent most of the night yelling, "WHAT?"  across the table. Some even ended up texting each other during dinner. Our service was pleasant and all of our food came out in under 10 minutes. I ordered the hot and spicy soup and the veggie dumplings. Everyone at our table was pleased with their orders. The drinks were typical Vegas Strip prices, but I heard that they were delicious. Our waiter brought us a HUGE dessert tray to share in honor of the special occasion. I think the dessert plate may have been the highlight of the evening.

Another great night at Tao. As always the food and service were on point. If you can request Jeffrey's section, he is the best! Super knowledgeable about the menu and the perfect blend of entertainment and great service!

Beautiful. Relaxing. Fragrant. These are a few words to describe the overall experience at Tao's in the Venetian. If anyone is looking for excellent food at well rounded prices, then this is the place for you.

Nestled in the corner of the Venetian, a little ways from the indoor gondola ride area, Tao is an Asian food experience that is certain to make you want more. Not only is their service impeccable, but their food creations are sensational, beautifully balanced, and light. We went there to experience the hotel Asian cuisine a few weeks back, and I have to say that Tao was one of the best we've had in our lifetime.

After ordering tempura to start, we followed with a kobe steak, kung pao chicken, and lobster gyoza in a mushroom truffle miso sauce to die for. The tempura was light, flaky, and melted in my mouth. The winner appetizer, however, were the lobster gyozas. The sauce was incredible, the lobster was sweet and the dumpling part was so soft and perfectly chewy. The entire dish was well balanced to the point where I wanted to drink the broth! The steak was so soft that a knife was unncessary, and the chicken was juicy and perfectly cooked. Our server was quick to refill at every turn, and there was so much to eat, dessert was not an option.

Although our dinner cost well over 180 dollars, it was well worth the experience. Not only is Tao restaurant a genius at Asian flavors, but a visual beauty. I honestly cannot say anything about this place except--exquisite.

Wow - this place is packed!  In a crazy way!

I was not a fan of the long lines outside the restaurant that included people who already had reservations.  That's a little bizarre to me, but then again, Vegas in itself is pretty bizarre.

Tao wins in the arenas of drinks and appetizers - seriously their Taotini is the most delicious drink I have ever sipped.  And the Chilean sea bass skewers were truly incredible.  

This is a good place to start your night in Vegas, but make sure to leave plenty of time to wait in line even with a reservation.  And prepare to speak loudly to your dining partners because the music is bumpin!

Hands-down the best meal we had in Vegas!

I had the miso-glazed Chilean sea bass and my wife had the orange chicken. Both dishes were recommended by our server (Jeff), who was excellent. We shared a side of pork fried rice. My wife hates fish and after tasting mine when it first came, she wanted more during the course of the meal.

To finish, we had the giant fortune cookie, which was delicious and cool.

The restaurant itself had a really nice decor, and was pretty packed for a Monday night.

Wife and I spent our second to last night dining here and was worth it. My wife had the Sea Bass which was the non menu special that night and it was amazing. I don't even typically like fish and I was still enjoying the occasional bites from her plate. I got the filet mignon and again was amazing. Great cook but the sauce and veggies mixed in is what really put it all together. The boneless ribs was so tender as well. Champagne was a bit expensive but that's what you expect I guess ordering glasses of champagne so no complains about it. And lastly our server was amazing. A little mad at myself for forgetting her name because I'd love to name drop her amazing service on here. Super friendly and was always checking up on us. Overall I'd definitely recommend but just be prepared for the cost.

How many people will get fooled coming here thinking it's great Asian food? The duck was OK. It's just not worth it.  Took 2 hours to get our regular order. Other tables got up and left. Our party of 10 stayed and roughed it out. When the food finally came it was cold and we were too tired to enjoy it. So they write a few Chinese words on the ceiling and throw in some asian looking statues. Ok looks like a Chinese restaurant now. Lol. To sum it up the food sucked and the service sucker. We went to the club and it was packed. They didn't count how many just let everyone in. I think the fire Marshalls came. Am I a complainer? No! This whole facility is poorly managed. Who is the GM and where were they 1.1.2015? Fire them asap. BTW. Who serves duck with Tortillas?? Its supposed to be with Steam buns. You don't see Asians in here which means it's an expensive version of PF Changs at most. You don't see Asians at Panda Express either.  Hint hint  I dont mind spending $1000.00 for food but it better be a decent experience.  So now they can take some of that money to put into marketing and lure in more suckers. Save your money and TIME because this place will take them both from you.

My colleagues and I went to this restaurant during a conference. We lucked out and got a reservation because someone just cancelled as one of my colleagues called in. We checked in for our reservation time but it took another 45 minutes or so to be seated even though we had reservations. We sat at the lounge and waited. 

Finally we were seated at a table of 8 and were served. We ended up doing the family style dining which was about $75 USD per person. We thought this would be the best way to taste as many different types of food. 

Each of the dishes were quite exotic and very tasty. The service was great. They served most of the dishes at once and continued to clear the table as plates were emptied. It felt like they weren't going to stop serving us. There was so much food. The variety of the food was sufficient - dishes from the land, from the sky, from the sea (ie. meat, veggies, seafood).

They offered us free entry to the TAO nightclub because we were pretty big spenders that evening. Food and service was awesome. Ambiance was a little dark and the wait was a little disappointing despite the reservation. 

But overall a great place to go.

This place is absolutely amazing! It is high priced... And believe me I mean high priced, but the quality of food doesn't get better. The drinks were very strong and the atmosphere was great but those paled in comparison to the food. We shared the sausage Chinese fried rice and My wife had the coconut shrimp and I had the Chilean sea bass, it was a TON of food way more than we could finish and my sea bass literally fell apart in my mouth it was so tender. The coconut shrimp was very crunchy on the outside but cooked perfectly on the inside and everything had amazing flavor. Literally the only things I would change if I could is the price.... Even thou I obviously understand why it is as expensive as it is, and the fact that the restrooms don't say "men's" and "women's" or have any type of sign on them besides "ying" and "yang".. So if you don't know which is male or female you basically stand outside until someone walks out...(I noticed a large amount of people doing this at it made for some interesting conversation outside the restroom).

Nice ambiance (went for a friend's birthday dinner before going out, restaurant was playing top 40 hits) Food is a bit overpriced for the quantity and quality, although the spicy tuna rolls were pretty good! If you are looking to go to dancing later, you get free admission to Tao the lounge upstairs so that's a nice bonus.
Shame on the server for soliciting a tip after already getting 20% ! Great food and atmosphere... Your tactics might get by tourists but not locals.

The only reason to eat here is to avoid the long lines waiting to gain access to Tao Nightclub. 
Once you've finished dining, your waiter will usher you past all the line-losers to gain your rightful spot amongst the beautiful people.

It's there you'll wonder why, after six vodka and Red Bulls, your 'buzz' more resembles a Sunday afternoon on the couch than the dance party you'd hoped for.
Well duh, you just ate enough food for a small village in the Sudan.
On the bright side, you didn't have to wait in line.

Avoid the 'family' meal experience. The bill was a stack before the tip for 8 of us. 
Stick with the sake bombers instead. 
Tao has a unique device that cleverly drops six shots into six beers simultaneously. It's so fascinating, you'll want to try this at least a dozen or so times.
Don't forget to shout out some Asian babble as you salute the Emperor or else the bombers have very little effect.

The sea bass was a triumph. The beef was like butter - I'm guessing it was Kobe, and if it wasn't, it was likely from a bull who'd had his nuts cupped daily by some half wit.

I visited Tao with my wife for dinner.  She made a reservation, so we had no trouble getting in right away on a Saturday night.   I do not each fish, but I had the chicken dish, which was very good.  My wife had the salmon, which she enjoyed.  They had these pork bun appetizers, I enjoyed very very much.

The place does get loud, due to the fact it attracts a lot of bdays and bachelorette partys.

Been here a number of times and have always been pleased. The Shabu shabu is great as is the Chilean Sea Bass. Place can get pricey but it helps when you know some of the management staff and get a little love. Service has always been on par as well which is a feat in itself as the place can do over 1000 covers in an evening.

I went here on a recommendation of a friend. I really enjoyed the atmosphere and our waiter was great. We were very happy with the recommendations made from our waiter. The sea bass was wonderful. The sashimi plate had a great selection; the toro toro roll and the Chef roll were all delicious.

We sat at the sushi bar. Something we always enjoy, however, at Tao there was no interaction between the itamae (sushi chef) and the patrons which we found disappointing, especially because it seemed they had a lot of down time. 

Because this is Vegas, people watching is always at its' best. There was another couple sitting at the sushi bar who clearly had a lot to drink, so that made for some entertaining conversation over dinner. 

Overall, the food was good and the wait staff attentive; however, I would probably try somewhere else for sushi when we go back next year.

I thought it was over-hyped for what  I spent and received service wise. I was overall very disappointed. i went there to celebrate my BF's birthday and told the hostess it was his birthday, then told the waitress, and even told the water guy....and my BF still DID NOT receive the birthday dessert. :( I ordered sweet potato tempura and a king crab California roll and could not believe how dry the rice was. I get a better California roll at my local place back home for a quarter of the price. When we finished eating, it took them 30 mins to bring us the check!? I was so annoyed at this point. I always tip, but in this instance i did not. I did explain on the receipt why I didn't tip too. For how much hype this place gets I am sad to say I was not impressed.
Fantastic ambiance! Staff was incredible. We got a must have appetizer which was the lobster wontons. Pure genius! We then shared the lobster pad Thai. Plenty to share. Lots of lobster.

Food is excellent and its awesome to be dining, while listening to a techno DJ and looking at a giant Buddha statue.  It is a bit pricey, but you have to pay for quality in Vegas.

Hint, this is actually the best way to get into the nightclub...dine for dinner and then you're automatically allowed in.  Also, it is pretty cool going there and being able to see the hot models in the bathtubs, wearing little more than rose petals.

I am writing this review after visiting in December for our company Christmas party and dining out there. Not only was the food OUT OF THIS WORLD, but what was 10 million times better was our service. Literally THE best server I have ever had in my entire life was Jeffery. He was SO NICE, no on EVERYTHING, so helpful. We were all honestly in SHOCK of this guy because he was that good, and we had a huge party. None of us have had service like that in a LONG LONG time. HIGHLY recommend.

Must try the Miso glazed chilean sea bass!!!! Amazing!!!!
 Everything was fresh and exciting!!! I can't wait to go back!

The loudest over spiced unsubtle misnamed place I have ever eaten at.
I toke my daughter and fiance  their for their pre-wedding dinner. Yes they had a pond and a Buddha and opium pipes for decor but everything on the menu was so over spiced that they must cater to people whose senses are jaded from over-stimulation. The music was so loud It was IMPOSSIBLE to have a conversation even with the person next to you much less across the table. (It reminded me of a Deep Purple concert I went to where my ears rang for 4 weeks).

So the best meal of the whole vacation goes to... Tao. What do you think of when you think of Tao, besides Winnie-the Pooh, maybe a pathway or a philosophy of the true nature of the world? Tao restaurant located in the Venetian has found their "pathway" through their food. 

Unbeknownst to me, Tao is one of the hottest places on the strip. Not only is it a restaurant but a lounge, banquet hall, a club, and celeb hot spot. I guess I know how to pick them! What I like is that the service treats everyone like royalty. The service here is insanely fast and they have more then enough staff on hand. We met one host and then got seated by another, then our server, a water guy, a guy that brings out food, and then a guy that takes it all away. The decor was insane too, dark rich colors, all kinds of fabrics, very bold and very detailed. Of course the 16 foot tall Buddha stands out just a little. 

The most impressive attribute about Tao is their food. Tao specializes in Hong Kong Chinese, Japanese, and Thai cuisines. I know it's a lot but this location is huge so they room for it all.
