Here's the kicker: If you're hosting a large Bachelor party (10+ guys), and don't want to drop thousands of dollars on bottle service (face it, some people in your party don't mind spending, but others want to keep $$$ to a minimum), this is your place.  If everyone in your party orders an "entree" (which range from $30-$45), you get free admission into the club.  The best part is that you can bypass the ridiculous line altogether!  It's a win-win situation...considering the entrance fee would have been $40 for guys.  Keep in mind the club opens at 10pm, so schedule your dinner upwards of 8pm.  

Going back to the food, my expectations were pretty low.  I was expecting extremely sub-par PF chang's style food, but I actually came out decently impressed.  I ordered the Pepper beef filet Mignon and it had quite a bit of meat and decent flavor.  The beef was tender and cooked pretty well.  The Sea bass would probably be the star entree here.  I got to try some of it and it was actually pretty good (think Yardhouse Sea Bass).

Long story short, if you're looking into getting 10 guys into a club and don't want to wait in line, Tao Asian Bistro should definitely be at the top of your list.  The food here is just a perk of getting into the club, but don't be surprised if you enjoy the food (stick with the pepper filet mignon, sea bass, or scallops and you'll be fine) . 4 stars.

Excellent pre-show prix fixe menu, wasabi encrusted filet mignon was worth the whole $38 price just by itself, and there are three more courses. Chocolate spring rolls for dessert -- amazing flavors.  This is both a club and a restaurant, so be prepared to dine to a DJ in a somewhat frenetic environment.  Tao has beautiful prize-winning decor, from the row of tubs filled with rose petals in the vestibule (where I understand scantily-clad women welcome in the later hours) to the wall of antique opium pipes and massive Buddha serenely presiding over all.  There was a line waiting when we exited, no surprise.

This place was great! Its in the heart of The Venetian and had club music pumping as soon as you walk in. It has a completely different ambiance then the one in NYC.Tables are a little closer together then I had expected but it made for interesting side conversation. 

Had a tree of sake tastings with some random people from Texas next to us. Didn't realized how messed up you could get off of rice! Food was good and music was great. Place is pricey but what do you expect for Vegas.

If you think you are getting in to the late night lounge on your meal ticket think again. Surprisingly you had to still pay a $20 cover to get upstairs into the lounge even if you just spent $200 on dinner there! Sooo be prepared for that :)

Fantastic looking club with awesome Asian and Zen decor and vibe. Didn't eat at Tao nor go clubbing upstairs but had drinks here. 

To enter, you walk through this tunnel with bathtubs of water and flower petals - we didn't see any women in these tubs despite the many reports of them. You then enter a super cool-looking big lounge area with dim lighting where you can get a drink and watch all the pretty people and wannabe's walk by. Past the lounge is the restaurant area where you are greeted by this ginormous buddha statue with candles all around it.

Bottom line: Probably one of the most cool and happening places in Vegas to grab drinks with some friends and people-watch in a hip Asian atmosphere . But come early to secure a booth as it can become a madhouse with lines of ppl out front when the club opens.

The food is so good! The atmosphere is really cool you get to listen to some fun music in a party up beat tone. The food is so good you can't go wrong with anything and the bread pudding is honestly the best! Just wow!

Great ambience, good service, and upbeat staff. I played it safe and ordered the crispy orange chicken, edamame, miso soup with tofu and manila clams, vegetable fried brown rice, crunchy spicy yellowtail roll. Crispy orange chicken was not good & did not have any flavor, just bland. My favorite was the crunchy spicy yellowtail roll.

I've been here twice, the first time awhile back and I remember loving it. But as my taste have changed I wondered if it would be as good the second time around. We started off with a couple drinks, all of which were delicious. We then had the duck spring rolls that came with a delicious sauce. The next course we had was a mix of raw fish. I enjoyed this dish as well it was very fresh. For the main course we ordered the chicken sausage fried rice and the Chilean Seabass.

The fried rice was really really good. They even put a fried egg on top and then the server mixed it. I had Chilean Seabass previously and remember it being delicious. It did not disappoint. It was just as good as I remembered it it was totally succulent. I will dream of that sea bass!

Our server was great and the atmosphere was really great. Overall I enjoyed the meal and would try it again!

This was so close to 5 stars!
First the good:

They confirmed my reservation and at that time I mentioned a special event we were dining for, ended up with questionably the best table right above and directly in front of the giant Buddha. 
Cocktail waiter was fabulous and the food menu was also explained really well. We ordered 4 starters (dim sum, satay, egg rolls) between 2 and didn't need a main course. 
Also were asked if we were in any rush for a show etc which I thought was a nice touch! 
The bad:

The waiter seemed to be displeased at being asked to take a picture for us, I appreciate its a common request but a bit of grace would be nice.
The food tastes amazing but is VERY salty, it tastes amazing but if salt effects you be aware!
It's not the cheapest option but it is beautiful and the food and presentation is lovely!
Loved all the Vegetarian options. Highly recommend getting the Vegetable Dumplings!

Great ambiance and convenient location on the second floor in the Venetian. I really enjoyed my crispy tuna sashimi roll and friends were happy with the pad Thai (and theirs were pretty good sized portions).

The food here was horrible and EXPENSIVE!!! How the hell did our bill, three rather thin chicks, come up to $300?????? I was baffled, maybe we didn't pay attention to what we ordered but I know for a fact that we did not have that many (alcoholic) drinks to amount to $300. The food was rather bland and felt as if it had been prepared in a rush, and mind you we were starving. We all know that food while in the starving stage tastes amazing!!! Oh no, not at TAO. The decor is fancy, very nice, but it's a cover-up for their nasty food. The waiter was really cool, attentive, and friendly. Plus he was from Compton! Heeeeey, I'm from LA.
NO WORDS TO EXPLAIN-the yellowtail, red snapper, ahi tuna sushi & pork rice.  Twice in a month & I live on Long Beach Ca

Dined at this restaurant one night this week with the crew.  Exotic ambience, cool Asian decors, friendly staff, nice lighting mix, excellent food and drink selections .  Their sushi selections are excellent - we tried it along with some Sake.  This place is high in my list for dining, & clubbing as well.

Came here for a birthday dinner with a couple girlfriends on a saturday night.  We had made reservations that morning and was able to get a reservation with no problems.... we ended up showing up an hour earlier than our reserved time, dunno how that happened and why ... but i guess in vegas ALL people lose track of time... i guess we were too excited to just stay in the room...... any hoot, we show up and we were able to get seated 45 mins earlier than our reservation. We were totally surprised and delighted at the same time. This was my first time to the restaurant part... and honestly wasn't expecting much to begin with, based on all the negative things that i've heard about the food and the service. 

But honestly.... i had a great time.  The ambiance was nice, i could've gone for lowering the volume to hear my friend sitting across from me, but i didn't mind yelling. =P The food was absolutely delicious. We had all ordered fish ~~~ there was the Miso Glazed Chilean Bass, Soy-ginger glazed Salmon, and the Yellowfin Tuna. All were cooked perfectly and seasoned well.  I would definitely come back to try their other dishes.  

Service was decent for what it was worth. The place was crazy busy and we had plenty of libations at our table so we didn't really notice any lack of service... we were enjoying each others complany wayyyy too much. =)

I hope i don't ever experience what people have written about this place.... HAPPY EATINGS!

Great atmosphere! My husband and I came here right after we landed in Vegas and arrived at our hotel (Venetian). Our flight was delayed and they were very amenable to delaying our reservation. The ambience is very loungy though the nightclub is upstairs which has a very different feel (you would never know though!). 

Our food was excellent. My husband got the coconut shrimp, I got Chilean sea bass and we shared shrimp fried rice they were all very good. But the start of the show surprisingly was the maki roll we ordered for our appetizer, crispy spicy tuna with avocado. We love sushi and this was one of the best sushi experiences we have ever had. We're considering going back for just sushi. It was so fresh and tasty. 

Lastly, if you eat at Tao restaurant, you get free admission into the nightclub which was a little intense for me but worth checking out! Overall great experience. Would definitely go back on my next visit to Vegas.

This was my first visit here, for my birthday, definitely felt like a celebrity, seeing as though all the celebrities do eat here.  My girls made reservations for us, they did so good.  We were a tad bit late, but the hostess was nice enough to seat us within a good 15 minutes.  That was really sweet of her, because the place was packed, and I'm sure that's nothing new.

Once we were seated, our waiter, I hate that I forgot his name, greeted all of the ladies with a smile, told us all about the specials, what's popular, all that good stuff to help us decide.  The restaurant was very dim, very dark, very sexy.  Honestly, it was a little too dark, made it very difficult to read the menu, but that was nothing big to complain about.  Because it was a group of girls, we all made the executive decision to order 3 or 4 appetizers, 3 or 4 dinner entrees, make it like family style.  Pass everything around the table, everyone gets to taste everything.  Now, I don't know if I got my hopes too high up for Tao, but the overall meal, it was...good. Not great, but good.  I wasn't disappointed, but I guess I was expecting out-of-this World cuisine.  

Honestly, the best things, were the Thai Crab Cakes and the Pork Potstickers.  Full of flavor, full of filling, the mango chili sauce on the crab cakes was really good, so was the chili sesame glaze on the potstickers.  That was my favorite.  Now, the entrees, it's not like they were bad, but I wasn't blown away.  If I had to pick one of my favorites, it would have to be the Wasabi Crusted Filet Mignon.  Cooked perfectly, tender, flavor was awesome and the tower of onion rings were a great match. A fun match.  I ordered the Miso Glazed Sea Bass, which melted in my mouth like butter, tender and flaky, but the seasoning was a little off.  It's like there wasn't enough.  But the quality was top notch.

It was so sweet that they did bring me this giant fortune cookie, with a giant fortune on the inside, filled with sweet, smooth, velvety vanilla and chocolate mouse.  I mean it was so good and the cookie was just the cutest and so delicious.  The fresh fruit with the chocolate, I mean it was literally a sweet ending.

Overall, I would definitely recommend Tao, it is definitely the place to be, always jumpin', always poppin' and it's really just a pretty cool place!

This place has mediocre food.  I will not go back.  I like spending money, but we spent a ton of money for dinner and when it came to getting into the club, their doorman was a complete jerk.  He was wearing a $79 JC Penny suit and he told me we couldn't get in b/c I wasn't wearing a collared shirt.  The problem was that he was a big a-hole about it.  Additionally, why is the restaurant staff telling me to go up to the club, just to block me at the door.  

If you want to spend a lot of money and then get shit on, go here.

In Chicago, their sushi wouldn't even break the top five.  This place is so shallow that all the 5-star reviews are probably from people that work here.  Notice all the 1-star reviews.  There are a lot of tools working here.  Congratulations, you make $10 an hour.  I'm on vacation and I have to deal w/ these losers.  Great!

So, if you're 21 and think it's cool to wait in line and get into a club, go for it.  I hope you get laid.

A not so knock off of PF Changs.   The service was slow. The tables were to cramped and the food was simply put just ok.  The music was too loud.  I suggest go to Changs at plant Hollywood  and save some money

Ok when I think about restaurants on the strip I generally don't think I'm going to have any sort of meal that is satisfying, tastes out of this world and is not pretentious. Tao has really taught me a lesson in that department. Don't judge until you've tried. 

I've come to Tao two times to eat and both times my socks have been blown off. Not really...cos both times I wore heels that were way too high and uncomfortable and ended the night walking around without shoes. Note to self: DO NOT wear ridiculous shoes when you intend to walk more than 3 steps. 

I digress...I digress...back to Tao. Contrary to popular belief, both times I was here (once with 8 people and once with 4), we were able to get tables (the first time we called the night before and the next time we just walked in) on Saturday nights. As you enter Tao, there are these flower-petal filled mini earthen bath tubs...haha...if I had a couple of their super strong lychee martinis I would go take plonk myself in one of these. They look that zen and inviting. 

This latest visit I made to Tao started with drinks at the bar while waiting for our table. Lychee Martinis...I made sure to ask for "extra strong" martinis and that was delivered. A great start to the night. The waiter we had was very knowledgeable about the food. He knew exactly what went in each dish. Tao is also very vegetarian friendly. They can substitute tofu in many dishes and there are many veggie options. Ok now to the dishes:

1. Shishito Peppers - Yum Yum...very nice and interesting. Never had these before. I probably wouldn't order these if I didn't have more than 4 people in my party. Rather large portion and the taste is interesting only the first couple of bites

2. Sake Infused Mushrooms - OK I am going to go insane right now. This was soooo good....i HATE sake and I'm salivating all over my laptop right now. I can't even describe this dish. You just need to get it. NEED TO I tell you

3. Steamed Veggie Dumplings - The dumplings itself were pretty normal. Nothing out of the regular dumpling world. Don't get me wrong, they were good...just nothing to write a paragraph about (although I guess I already have). Now, the dumplings came with this AMAZING crunchy cucumber side. Ok...seriously...cooked cucumbers. Sounds icky but Yum Yum Yum. Very very nice...

4. Fried Brown Rice with Veggies - Wow. Crispy lettuce, perfectly cooked tofu, simple flavors and you wouldn't even know you are eating brown rice (I don't like brown rice). Tastes sooo good. This is literally the best fried rice I've had outside of Asia. And I've eaten many a fried rice

5. Mango Tamarind Martini - This one tasted sooooo good. Masked the taste of alcohol (i can't stand the taste of alcohol) and tasted interesting with just a hint of tamarind. A perfect complement to the meal. The drink still packed a good punch even though you couldn't taste the "punch."

We ended the meal with the 4 of us sharing a chocolate cake of some sort. I'm not a fan of chocolate cakes in general so I can't really remember how it tasted. The girls seemed to like it though. 

We even got our hands stamped to get into Tao (the club area) after we ate. Totally worth the price!

If you are in Vegas and up for a nice dinner on the strip I would suggest Tao for sure. Great food, amazing drinks, good service and the ambiance is of course wonderful.

Like: 
-Reservation process was easy and when we wanted to change time, they were really flexible (but it was a Tuesday night)
-Our waiter was nice and professional. He suggested a lobster wonton appetizer that we really liked. 
-I like people watching so the atmosphere was great for me.
-The bathtubs lining along the entrance are pretty cool. I'd totally have my dinner in there if they let me.

Didn't like so much:
-Umm....there's a bathroom lady/attendant. I always think it's unnecessary to have someone handing me a towel after washing my hands. I didn't bring my purse in there so I had no money to put in the tip jar, which made the whole thing quite uncomfortable.
-The decor was a little too "fusion", like they try to do everything Asian but don't do anything that well. I expected a bit more from such a fancy place. 

We enjoyed our time here but probably won't come back because it wasn't impressive enough, and strong impression is what people expect in Vegas.

We came for my best friend birthday dinner! Let me just say it was amazing. From the moment you walk in just the place is amazing!! The service there is exceptional! I wish I knew my server name she was amazing! Her hospitality and her attentiveness was just so great! Everyone was friendly.. the food is just delicious, the drinks were good also!! I would deficiently come here again and recommend the place. Thank you to my serve your hospitality I was awesome!! We just love the fortune dessert!!

After Jersey Boys, we needed a light dinner. Tao delivered in a big way. We were blown away by the decor. Candles, lighting, glass, wood, tile, sculptures... A very cool place. 

We started with a sake sampler. The waitress really took good care of us with her suggestions.  The three sakes were delicious all in their own way.  Lobster wonton in a yummy broth with mushrooms and onion came first. Unbelievable. Just delicious. Next came a Chilean seabass with a miso glaze, fried rice with duck, and spicy eggplant. The fried rice was so so but the seabass and eggplant dishes were amazing.  We thoroughly enjoyed ourselves.  
This was every bit as good as Nobu but in a better, warmer atmosphere.

Came here for a friend's birthday dinner back in October. I don't have anything against Asian fusion, as long as it's done right. And I just wasn't impressed with this place. The food was so-so. The help was... well..  I don't even know. The decor is cool, but that may be it's only redeeming quality. That, and the dessert platter (chocolate Buddhas almost seem blasphemous, but oh wells). I probably wouldn't come back to eat here for dinner (unless, of course, it's for someone else's birthday... then it's whatever they want to do).

VISUALLY STUNNING. Without a doubt, this is the most beautiful restaurant I have ever eaten in.

The food was very good.. although it was way too expensive and the portion sizes were tiny! I guess this is to be expected in a place like this.. but  honestly, for asian fusion flavor you might as well go to P.F. Changs. The atmosphere is not nearly as good, but you get your moneys worth.

The drinks were even more outrageous than the food. I had a Grey Goose and Cranberry... $16. Seriously.. for one little drink with more ice than booze. 

Our server was a complete... a-hem. She was covertly and outwardly hostile the entire meal. We were pleasant, not demanding, ordered lots of food, drinks, etc... she should have been happy to have our table!

Long story shortish, if you want to be in a visually appealing, trendy place and you don't mind paying for it. Then, definitely go.  But watch out for snotty serving people.

The food has gotten better.  It's an Asian Bistro so if you're not into Asian Fusion this place is not for you.  They are good with seperating the shellfish for those who have allergies.

Biggest downside.  We had 9pm reservations arrived at 8:50 but got seated at 9:30.  Not sure what happened and I don't think they knew either.  Others were seated before us who arrived after us.

It's an ok place but not a must.

The Cons:
-We had a long wait(over an hour atleast) even though we had late night reservations, but it wasn't so bad. We had some drinks at the bar, talked to the bartender a bit and people watched. 
-When we were seated, I have to admit, I was a little disappointed with our table. It was one of those where you are right next to the neighboring table and share a booth with the stranger next to you. Not that big of a deal really.
-My husband had the Wasabi Crusted Filet Mignon w/ Onion Rings. He was pretty disappointed. I felt bad bc I had talked him into getting this dish due to all the great reviews.

The Pros:
-My dish alone is the reason I would go back to Tao and the reason I gave it 4 stars... the Miso Glazed Chilean Sea Bass was outstanding! Best fish I've ever eaten. Just the perfect amount of sweetness and it melted in your mouth like butter. 


Somewhere in the Middle:
-For an app. we had the Spicy Tuna on Crispy Rice- good, not great. I was hoping it would taste like a similar dish I had once at Katsuya in Hollywood and it just didn't stack up. 


Will we be going back? Doubtful. Maybe if I go to Vegas with some girlfriends in the future I'll have a chance to eat some more of that delicious fish, but I will not likely be going back with the husband.

I got a craving for Asian food last time I was in Vegas and Yelp led me to this place... The food was delicious. The restaurant was very busy with people waiting for tables, yet I never felt rushed. Our server was kind and didn't seem bothered by the fact that I took my time deciding what I wanted to order. The cocktails were not the best, I sent back my "geisha" drink twice before they got it within an acceptable range.

I came here for a friend's birthday expecting the worst, but was actually pleasantly surprised.

I didn't even know Tao had a restaurant until the night I ate here. The restaurant is huge and surprisingly busy for dinner. The service was impeccable, with knowledgable and attentive servers. The food is expensive, but you're in the wrong city if that is a deal breaker. I definitely recommend the Chilean sea bass, order it and everyone at the table will be stealing bites. 

If you come here for dinner be sure to get your hand stamped so that you can get into Tao nightclub for free.

I sat at the bar for dinner, service was awesome and food was severed quickly. I ordered the hot and sour soup which came with shrimp toast, the soup was good although the toast was a little too greasy. I also had the spicy tuna roll which was great.

What a great place. Service was awesome, the waiter was really incredible. Even shook my hand and wished us a nice evening. We chose to order small plates to try a variety of things and it was a good choice. The lollipop wings and wontons were the best choice.  The Lobster and Kim Chi rice was one of the best rice dishes I have ever had.  This is a must stop in Vegas, and I would come back with a large group to share dishes with.

Loved the food here. Chilean seabass was to die for! This place was soo good I went back there the second night in LV! I ordered the NY steak and it was equally good. The steak is nicely sliced up for you, i.e. ez to eat. Loved the asian fusion sauce they drizzled over it with a bed of shitake mushrooms. Mmmhhmmm.
Wish there was a TAO here in SF... /sigh.

This place has very good food but the rest of the experience kinda sucks. Now, it is LV and everything is large but Tao is too large. Too many people. Extremely loud to the point that it made my ears ring like I was at a Who concert and throat soar from screaming to my dinner mate. Crammed in the bar area, waiters flying around left and right, yelling conversation, I really didn't enjoy my dinning experience. In fact, I was dying to get out of there. Mainly it's the factors listed above and not the food nor the service. Go confidently if you like this as you won't be let down by the sushi. I really did like the dishes.

Accepting the fact that everything on the strip is really expensive and unavoidable, Tao's got some pretty good food. It's a bit loud, but dimly lit and always packed with ppl.

4 stars because the Gyoza, chicken and dessert were tasty and would go back for it. Plus, lots of potentially good looking dishes I saw (fried rice, pad Thai, chicken skewers and more)

The food (ps the highlight was the cauliflower omg)
- CHICKEN GYOZA (3.5 stars): choice of steamed or fried, wrongly opted for the steamed - mushy exterior but a tasty filling and soy dipping sauce. Served with pretty much raw bean sprouts.
- CRISPY TUNA ROLL (2 stars): fresh fish, but overly heavy handed on the wasabi and ginger. Tasted a little too oily for me as well. Served on a bed of ton of edamame with grated ginger
- CHILEAN SEABASS (3 stars): very flavorful, very fresh, served with veggies but a bit too buttery tasting for me.
- ROASTED THAI CHICKEN (4 stars): a bit dry, but otherwise good. 
- CAULIFLOWER (5 stars): imagine Kung pao chicken but cauliflower. Perfectly roasted, super firm yet cooked, doused in a delectable sweet and sour sauce. A bit sweet, but seriously could not stop eating this
- FORTUNE COOKIE & MOUSSE (5 stars): didn't really taste like a fortune cookie, so much as like a vanilla crisp or something, but the killer part about this was the little bit of dark chocolate it's dipped in and the delicious both chocolate and vanilla mousse that it's served with. Also, it comes with fruit / so it's healthy right?

TLDR: based on price, good for business dinners or if you're okay with spending. Lots of good potential dishes, you just have to know what to order.

My husband surprised me and got reservations here for my birthday.  The only thing was the reservation was a tad early at 5:30p.  Great dining experience and great cocktails.  I got the wasabi encrusted filet mignon and it was delicious!

Beautiful elegant enterence with Rose Petals and Candle Lights floating in water guiding you through the dim light enterance as I have been here before to celebrate birthdays I finally would like to share my experience.

As the sitting host  takes you to your table you will be enchanted by The Buddah siting in a lit temple of water within the resturant which is quite spectacular. 

The service as always is great we orderd steamed Vegatble Dumplings along with fried Chicken Gyoza and King Crab California Roll which arrive at the table beautifully presented with Red Caviar and for our main course Filet Mignon Pepper Steak filled with asparagus, mushrooms, and carrots slightly glazed in a wonderful asian bistro sauce. 

Tao is dramatically beautiful food is very delicious and as I said well presented I personally will take my guests to enjoy a wonderful dining experience here when they arrive out of town.

Tao is always exceptional. The restaurant churns smoothly and the staff is extremely accommodating. We last minute had to double our reservation size, then when we arrived shrunk it back down and they never had an issue accommodating us. Kudos to the staff for this.

The food is equally as well done. In particular, the lobster wontons are amazing - must order as an appetizer. For a main course, the menu in general is good, but the stand out is the crispy orange chicken (with brown rice). The flavor & texture is perfect. I could eat this dish daily.

We wanted to try this place out upon visiting Vegas because I loved all the Buddhist statues.  

When we talked in, the place didn't the seem crowded at all. The place was dimly lit with ponds full of water and rose petals. Quite nice. The restaurant was actually huge andbreally crowded upin walking further in. We were greeted by a very friendly staff and quickly seated. 

Since I both weren't too hungry due to going for dessert before hand at Serendipity, we just ordered the duck fried rice and chow mein noodles. They were both delicious and extremely filling. The ingredients were fresh and although the food was greasy, it didn't make me feel all disgusting like most restaurants. The rice was my favorite. Tons of duck meat and vegetables. The noodles weren't bad at all, but nothing too special. 

Although the food was quite delicious, my favorite thing about Tao was the atmosphere. The Buddhist theme was present throughout the restaurant. There was a huge Buddha statue in the middle of the restaurant with other Buddhist statues along the walls and pillars. Even the table set up was awesome. I loved the entrance and the lighting. 

When I return to Vegas, I will definitely come back here with much more of an appetite. The other dishes looked amazing as well.

We went to TAO to start my girlfriend's bachelorette celebration. She had been talking up Tao's menu for weeks. Let me say it didn't disappoint. For starters both managers checked on us and when we offered one s sucker from my girlfriends bouquet and he was so happy he comped our drinks. The Chilean sea bass really is the best fish meal ever. When our desserts took longer than we hoped, another manager made sure we didn't pay for our desserts. We didn't even have to ask. I have to say if you are lucky enough to have Lars for a waiter, know you are in great hands!
Really, really good! I had been to the nightclub before but not the restaurant. I had lo mein and sushi plus several appetizers with my party and everything was amazing. Will be back.

Came here with a group of friends last week. The good: great service, ordered appetizers of dim sum and sushi which were good proportions and tasty, ambience is trendy. The bad: our main courses - ex. spicy Chicken, lobster pad thai, rare tuna, all were bland and remained uneaten at end of night.  We regret not sticking with apps and stopping there. For the price, big disappointment.

We went here last night with a birthday party of 14. We arrived early but had to wait 45 minutes after our reservation to be seated which really made a lot of us cranky and frustrated.  When they sat us on the main floor we noticed an empty elevated long table section near us that was totally empty and could have accommodated us. The energy of the birthday girl was off at this point but we tried to cheer up the mood. We ordered the $75 per person family style menu because everyone was so hungry and agitated we knew if we all ordered individually it would further throw the party into a black hole.  Some guests were just saying bring out food, anything will do. 

The line for the night club portion was piling up and packing the staircase which was horrible because it became a major task just to get to the restroom on the 2nd floor.  Security initially told the girls that was the only one while we were initially waiting to be seated so we did not know any better that there was a restroom on the main floor. 

A girl came around and stamped our wrists and told us this is to get into the club upstairs after we finish dinner which seemed like a cool option that the restaurant seemed to give patrons and we decided that we would stay for the club after dinner instead of hesding out to Ballagio.  This later became a ridiculous ordeal because as we went up the packed staircase with our entire party the bouncer at the top stated that the stamp now did not give us admission but got us past the line outside. He told us to all go to the front door. 

The look of disgust on the birthday girls face summed it up and trying to patronize the place further would just lead to further aggravation. 

The only reason I gave this place one star is because the food was really good but I can't be really sure because when you are starving anything tastes good and some of the girls last meal was around noon so we were pretty hungry.

Since we were staying at the Venetian, we chose Tao for our dinner destination the last night of our Vegas weekend... My dad made the reservation in advance and let them know we were celebrating a birthday.  There were six of us in the party, and we actually all arrived right on time!  The hostess said it would be a few minutes, so we sat at a table in the lounge area, ordered some drinks, and snacked on some of the wasabi peas.  The waitress that took our cocktail orders was sweet, and she made some great Taojitos for the group!  At 8:30, we were wondering why we had to wait so long and getting a bit ansy... we finally were taken to our table around 8:40.

Dinner was amazing once we were seated.  Chris was our server and took great care of us.  We enjoyed a round of appetizers including lobster dumplings, crispy tuna tataki, edamame, duck spring rolls, and eggplant tempura.  We also did dinner family style and shared wasabi steak, pad thai with shrimp, crispy snapper, seafood in black bean sauce, spicy eggplant, curry shrimp tempura maki, and pork fired rice.  It's two days later, and I am writing this all from memory - it was that good!  (Usually I would have to look back at the menu to remember what we ordered, but it all made a lasting impression in this case).  We literally cleaned all of the plates - everything was great, and quick too!

Luckily, even with all of that food, we saved room for dessert.  Chris brought out a beautiful birthday cake for the birthday girl and boy (my bro and sis are twins).  I'm talking really quality, beautiful gourmet cake (like AJ's in AZ).  It had "Happy Birthday A & Z" written on it in chocolate and it was a vanilla layer cake of sorts.  

I didn't pay the bill, and I'm sure it was expensive, but this was by far the best meal we had on the trip, and I'm sure it was worth it!  The only reason I'm giving 4 stars instead of 5 is because of the wait we had upon arrival - other than that, Tao was amazing!  Beautiful ambiance too - I'll have to go back next time to check out the nightclub!

I've only been here for dinner and not the night club, so I cannot comment on the night club part of Tao.

While the ambiance here is spacious with a cool decor, the food here is overpriced and not worth it.  Sure, you may see celebrities here, but really, who cares?  I care more about the taste of my food.

And when you ask for water, they ask you if you want plain tap water or bottled water.  They almost make you feel like a schmuck for drinking ordinary tap water.  They serve Voss water in a big bottle here.

We got the usual sushi rolls and steak entree.  The food is okay, about what you expect from this kind of place.  The people are gorgeous so if you're into people watching, you'll probably like this place.  But otherwise, it's a one time experience for me.
Save your money. Go to panda express on the strip. Youll get more food and it'll taste better.
excellent service this time and wasabi crusted steaks are a must try. bummed out that kobe beef carpacio is no longer on the menu. must make a reservation.

Currently waiting to be seated for an 8:45 reservation for a party of 5. A party larger than ours with a reservation for 9pm was seated before us. The hostess said we would be seated shortly and that there were only a few people ahead of us. The 8:30 reservation had already been waiting 30 minutes. What's the point of making a reservation if they don't seat you for the time you're supposed to be seated? And why seat reservation times ahead of us?

First off, let me say that you can get better food in other restaurants.  But when you are in Vegas, it's often more about the atmosphere and the experience.  Want a celebrity sighting?  Want to visit a Vegas hotspot?  Tao is definitely a great choice at the moment in the fickle and ever-changing Vegas scene.

The food takes a number of dishes from Southeast Asia and moderates the taste for a Western palate.  Spices are generally mild, the ingredients are less exotic, and anyone who has eaten at a P.F. Chang's will feel very comfortable.  You really can't go wrong if you choose a number of small plates and share them family-style.

I'd also highly recommend the sake flights, which give you a sampling for some very fine wines.  Oddly enough, you can't tell which is which, but does it really matter?

This is a great location for those large groups, although getting a reservation can be difficult.  It's a good thing that they have late-night seating up to 10:30 or 11:00pm.

A note for those bachelor/ette parties - eating dinner at the restaurant does NOT get you into the club automatically, so plan accordingly.  It's still a good choice to eat downstairs and go clubbing upstairs afterwards (because you avoid an extra taxi ride in between dinner and partying), but you need to make reservations at both locations BEFORE coming out, otherwise you risk having to wait in line.

This is a great dining option on the strip, especially if you've got a show nearby.  We went as a group of 4 on a Tuesday, with reservations at 7pm and it wasn't crowded, so we had the server all to our self.  When we left about an hour later, it was absolutely packed and the servers were running around from table to table.  So, go early and enjoy yourself!  The food is awesome and the ambience is even better.  Not sure what you want?!  Your waiter will defintely help you make a decision.  For vegetarians, they can replace the meat with tofu on most dishes (although, you'll still pay the meat price), so you have plenty of options.  For dessert, defintely get the jumbo fortune cookie!  The prices are a tad high, but you defintely won't leave the place starving.

Perhaps because Kim Kardashian, her mom, & co. were to the table to my right, and David Spade and Colin Firth of SNL were to the table to my left, Tao failed to give me one thing I would have needed - a lobster bib.

That is the ONLY thing that my Tao Restaurant dining experience lacked and who knows, had I asked, maybe they would have had one on hand. We had reservations for Saturday night for 8:30pm to celebrate my 30th birthday. Friends were gathered from Chicago, NYC, and San Francisco. We had a 45 minute delay in being seated at our table but that came as no surprise given the busy night. We were seated in the first floor dining area near the majestic two-story tall Buddha statue. Our server was courteous, attentive, and knowledgeable on the menu items.

The standouts for me appetizer-wise were the vegetable dumplings and egg rolls (i'm pescatarian and do not eat meat). My carnivore friends seem to enjoy the dragon tail spare ribs and meat potstickers. Through it all, the wine kept pouring.

Our entrees came and I was dazzled by my Typhoon Lobster with Fingerling Potatoes and Spicy Stir Fry. This is when the bib would have come in handy because when I was done it looked like I had massacred an aquatic beast! Fine food, great conv, surrounded by top notch friends -  this was an evening to be remembered. 

I will mention that the pair who ordered the Peking Duck for 2 were indifferent to it. The description had sounded amazing but did NOT live up to their expectations. Everyone else enjoyed their food immensely though. Then came what would make for buzz that this meal was a contender for best meal ever - the dessert platter.

Over the off-key singing of 'happy birthday' came the mother of all dessert platters. It included a scoop of ice cream, sorbet, molton chocolate cake, fruit, and a giant fortune cookie filled with white and dark chocolate mousse and chocolate buddhas. Simply incredible and I am not generally a dessert person. 

From the moment you walk in to the moment you leave Tao you feel as though you are experiencing something unique, exotic, and daring. The decor is chic and sexy, the vibe hip and happening. Thank you Tao for making my birthday dinner one I will never forget.

What a pretentious yet tasteful dungeon this was ! I got the feeling that the reason this place is so pricey besides the fact that it is in Vegas, and in the Venetian, is because they are still trying to profit and pay off whoever did their decor. It was unique, but I was not impressed because I see this stuff around all the time (hey, I AM from Los Angeles, the cultural enclave of the west coast).
The decor is the highlight of eating here, not the food or the service. It is definitely no bargain. The selection of food is not sufficient. There is no description of the special rolls, which confused my companions and made me have to explain the differences to them -__-. The sushi was not well wrapped, or proportioned well. I did like the idea of a seaweed salad sampler plate for a measly $10, but the dipping sauce was bland and watery, and they just didn't go well together or alone. I'd rather go to a white box with windows for good food rather than try and fill my stomach through looking at cool things, but that is just me.
I had a Love Potion #9 cocktail, and though it was good, it was a ripoff. Maybe I hit the bad bartender who gives too much ice and not enough of anything else, but it was a necessary gamble. 
The service was fine, no complaints here. I actually ended up waiting less time than I thought I would have to. I also got the feeling that you have to be less than a size 6 to work at this place, including the men. Abercrombie/Fitch style lawsuit, anyone? 
The music the DJ was spinning from ITUNES wasn't hip or amazing, it was just typical background music. I wouldn't dance to it, nope. 
At least you can look around at other places you should have eaten after you eat here, since the Grand Canal shopping area is right here.

Went here for a birthday dinner.  It's my second time here and it was much like the first, fun because both times were celebrations and I enjoyed the company I was with but other then that this place is beyond OVERRATED and I wouldn't come here on my own accord.  I had the orange chicken which honestly could have come from PF Changs where I would have gotten more and paid much less.  Didn't bother with drinks because I'm just not willing to spend $14 for a drink.  Waitress also tried to overcharge us for something that was her mistake and acted like she would try and fix it.  She did but acted like it was big deal.  I thought the large fortune cookie dessert was the best part of the evening.  Very creative and shared with a group of seven.  Some would recommend this place for date night but I probably wouldn't unless you like yelling to be heard.

Vegas ain't cheap anymore.  This place fits that new style.  but damn if the sushi ain't nummy.  each visit to town, we hit this place at least once.  Cool atmosphere, chill DJ, and waitresses in the lounge with skirts up to hee-yah.

another bathroom perv story - but after you tip the attendent, peek down at faucet level and see the girlies primping on the other side.

better than the buddha chocolate desserts, that

I was desperately hungry and was in here for a corporate event so decided to sit in the bistro. The service was mostly okay but $40 for a bowl of pineapple chicken loaded with salt and close to inedible was really poor. The real killer though was $16 fgor a bottle of chilled tap water. I had two bottlers because I was so thirsty after the salty chicken. $32. I complained and it was taken off my bill after the manager argued with me about the fact that it was filtered. Terriblle

This place is really really busy. The food is good but not great. The food feels like its made on an assembly line....a good one that's well crafted but still an assembly line nonetheless. The restaurant is quite large and it can be very busy so it's often difficult to hear your fellow diners.

With a 9pm reservation, we finally got seated at 9:35pm.  Hostess and waiter were amazing. Lots of flashes from foodies, so very much like a nightclub. PACKED, be ready to maneuver around in tight spaces. Sushi was great, Pad Thai was sweet.  Overall, not my most ideal experience.

I totally get it.  The promoters/owners lure you into Tao Restaurant, ply you with yummy food and drink, and then convince you that Tao Nightclub is just as upscale and well-done.  Don't fall for it!  Just eat the food, drink the booze, and leave!  You'll have a better night for it.

Tao Restaurant is amazing.  I loved the decor, the service, the short wait, and of course the food.  This behemoth of a restaurant does Asian fusion right.  I had the Tao-tini (after my requisite dirty Grey Goose on the rocks).  Fruity, strong as all hell, and delicious.  My PIC and I started with the lobster wontons.  Best.  Dish.  Ever.  Next time I go back, that's all I'm ordering.  We also had the lobster dumplings to start.  Good.  But definitely not the lobster wontons.

We then ordered the Thai fish hot pot, which had a very strong sauce, overpowering on its own, but perfect with steamed rice.  We made the mistake of ordering veggie fried brown rice.  Why were we trying to be healthy? Anyway, what came was a plate of veggies + mush.  Ugh.  Panda Express makes a better fried rice than that!

Upon leaving the Venetian, my PIC and I decided that next time, we're just ordering 6 servings of the lobster wontons.  And then heading to Jet to shake it all off!

P.S.  One of my students told me that her group of friends was offered free dinner + drinks + Tao admission the same weekend.  So if you have a group of 10+ cute Asian girls, you may get dinner for free!  Otherwise, expect to spend about $50/person, not including drinks.

Tao restaurant is like PF Chang's with tighter skirts, louder music and higher prices. (In case you didn't pick up on it - I didn't use PF Chang's as a positive reference). 

I went with the fixed price menu and had the salmon which was okay. Definitely had better for half the price. 

I did REALLY like their filet mignon. We subbed out the wasabi that it comes with but it was a damn good filet mignon. 

I know Tao nightclub is upstairs but DAMN it was loud in the restaurant and I'm one of those people who always tell others to relax when they say a place is too loud. It really was way too loud. 

Fixed price menu is $55. 

Honestly, it was only worth it so we could get stamped to get into the nightclub.
Tao had an event and we didn't know. The security guard just chased us out. Very rude!

My friend and I dined at Tao on a Saturday night and had reservations at 8pm and were immediately seated. This place was overall an amazing experience. The ambiance is beautiful, the staff is very friendly and the food was delicious. My friend and I started with the lobster wontons as an appetizer. Perfect portion size and had a unique and very flavorful taste. For our entree we ordered the duck for two and a side of the sausage fried rice which comes with a fried egg on top and is mixed at your table in front of you. Everything we ordered was exceptional! Highly recommened for large groups or even a couple.

If you've ever been to any of the New York locations, the Vegas location will disappoint. The decor (for the most part) is just as lovely as any of the NY locations, however the photos of sumo wrestlers over the sushi station seem a bit out of place in an otherwise very upscale decor. 

The service was great and our waiter was as nice as can be. He was enthusiastic about the food and very attentive. 

Ambience: loud. The music in addition to the very load ambience was a bit too much. 

Pad Thai was under par. My husband ordered spicy chicken dish with pineapple and peppers which was very tasty however the chicken was a bit over cooked. The pad Thai was overwhelmed with sprouts and coriander and served in a very annoying vessel which made it hard to eat. 

Our fortune cookies tasted great but oddly?  had very sexual fortunes.

Overall ok. Didn't meet expectations compared to other locations.

Good food but expensive as hell
Good place to be at least once in your life
Great atmosphere and good service
The best spicy tuna crispy rice. Great food cool ambience. Really great Vegas dinner spot we go at least once each Vegas trip and are always happy. Sushi samba is great too and a little cheaper
One of the best restaurant I have been to Vegas.  Great food, drinks, and service.   Perfect for big party or date night.  It is pricy, but worth it.

Out of all of the places I've eaten at on the strip, Tao has to have the worst customer service at a high-end Vegas restaurant on the strip.  It was as if they were doing everything they could to get us in and out as fast as possible.  The individual assisting our waiter kept taking our food before we were done - even after I told him to stop.  After spending $100 a plate I'd like to finish my food. 

After all of this, I tried desperately to speak to a manager without any luck.  It was as if the employees at Tao were intentionally preventing me from speaking with a manager because they were afraid they'd get in trouble.  They told me that I had to talk to the general manager.  I called twice and they finally transferred me to his voice mail which obviously wasn't the general manager.   Seems like something a general manager shouldn't be handling anyway.

The food was okay.  We ordered Peking Duck.  I've had better.  The only good thing the whole night was our waiter Dave.  

After my experience here, I am telling everyone I know not to eat here.

Walking into a club to have dinner wasn't something on the top of my list of things to do but I heard many good things, so in I went. Red accents along a dark backdrop. A hallway full of naked women in bathtubs covered in rose petals. Winding maze to get from the hallways to the upstairs dining area. Plenty of bouncers to ensure eating privacy. All seemed fairly crazy to me at a place we were to have dinner but It was well worth it.

The Tao restaurant had some of the most delicious salmon I've ever had. I ordered the soy ginger glazed salmon with udon noodles and spinach. The salmon cooked to perfection, beautifully medium in the middle, and the udon was amazing. Every morsel, every bite, and every scent was packed full of flavor. The seasoning enhanced the flavor of the salmon rather than masking it.

I eat a lot of Asian food, not because I'm Asian myself but because there is an abundant amount of Asian restaurants in my area. I wouldn't say the food at Tao is authentic but it is a warm welcome to to the culinary world with Asian influences.

Overall, It was the best salmon I've ever had and definitely worth the price and I would definitely return. Next time I'm bringing my appetite and dancing shoes as the club is amazing.
Fabulous!!! Had the most amazing sea bass! Everything from service and food was the best.

My wife and I have eaten here before and had a wonderful meal. But tonight? No. Fail. Fail. Fail.

We had reservations and upon arrival we're given a pager and sat in the lounge. We brought our own wine and were ready for a good evening. So far, so good.

Sitting in the lounge, no one asked if we wanted a drink or needed anything. Fail. 

After zero service in the lounge we became impatient and my wife took the wine we brought to the bar to have them open it so we could start enjoying our evening.

About ten minutes later (still no help at the bar) the pager went off.  I went to the hostess and said we were waiting on our wine. 

My wife waited at the bar and was finally told the corkage fee was $50. Really steep for a non-Michelin place, but not the point.

About another 10 minutes later still no service.

Ridiculous. 

After waiting another 5 minutes my wife finally had to ask for our bottle back so we could leave.  Fail. 

After speaking to the manager, the response was, "if you'll stay I'll make sure you're taken care of."  We didn't want anything but the manager made no attempt to address the concern and just made some promise of satisfaction.  Fail. 

We won't be back. 

Fortunately, we were able to order delivery from JC Cuisine and had great food (in the pic)... for less than the Tao corkage fee

Had dinner here on a Saturday night for my bachelorette party. I had to talk to someone no less than 6x to confirm a reservation for 15. They also made me give them my credit card and said they were going to have to split my party up at two tables. When we got there, they said we could wait 15 minutes for a large enough table for all of us (and we didn't have to pay $90 per person for the pre fix menu like they had initially wanted!) They poured us all drinks and this left plenty of time for photos with the Tao backdrop! The waiter recommended splitting the meals family style and though the portions weren't huge, we had plenty of food and the bill was actually not too badly priced!! Way less than I expected! They brought out a cool looking dessert as well!  The only thing I will say is the restaurant is dimly lit and the atmosphere isn't as night club/lively as I would have thought Tao restaurant would be. We got stamped so we could just walk up the stairs to the nightclub and had to get a second stamp which was kind of a pain but overall great way to get in without worrying about waiting in line.

good asian food.  i don't usually like places that mix, japanese, chinese, thai etc cuisines, but this place makes it work. everything we got was at least good, with the chinese sausage fried rice, the pastrami fried rice, the potstickers, the grilled bbq pork buns and the halibut entree being great.

one star automatically taken off for the condescending and judgmental main hostess.

I visited this place when I was in Vegas a friends bachelor weekend. The food was amazing. I think my favorite was the sea bass And the coconut shrimp. The staff was very friendly and service was quick. This was my first experience here even though they have one in New York and I'm there all the time. I won't be going back to Vegas anytime soon but I will definitely be going to the one in New York when I get the chance!

Made a reservation through open table which was easy and efficient.  Atmosphere was great and food even better.   We had the waiter pick the entrees after giving our food preferences.  This was really fun way to go as our waiter did not disappoint.

Server was extremely nice. We requested our bill to be separated for the table and that was not done so it lead to other issues for our group. Food was good overall. Restaurant has a club on the upper level, if you eat dinner you can get validated to enter the club without paying the cover fee.

My first time bringing my parents to TAO and they loved it! Ordered the Imperial Vegetable Egg Roll, Pad Thai with Chicken, and Orange Chicken. We highly recommend this restaurant if you are coming to Vegas!

I definitely have a beef with this place.  There's a long wait, and the food is very very average.  Plus, they pulled that "sparkling or still" water crap.  Excuse me if I don't go to fancy places all the time where tap water isn't given as a choice.  Our table of 7 (? it's been a while, I don't remember the exact number) spent about $40-$50 just on freaking water!!  The food was expensive too.

Lastly, I take issue with the whole Buddha, fake Asian thing.  Seems kind of tacky.  And wrong.

I went last night for my birthday. The food is good. It's meant to be shareable so that is great for parties with multiple guests. I liked the tempura green beans. They are addictive. The Thai Chili crab cake were good too. One thing that I disliked was that the Busboys constantly cleared they table. They were not personable and they came to the the table constantly. I felt rushed and couldn't really enjoy my meal because they were trying to clear items before we were finished. It was not busy that night so I don't know why they were trying to turn over our table.
OMG this was the best meal I ever had in Vegas.   Service was fantastic as well as the food and atmosphere.  I highly recommend the sea bad and the curry scallops.
Not the cheapest restaurant but it's a unique experience. Beautiful decor and great food. Great service too.

Ambience:  terrific. The large Buddha in the middle makes you wonder how they got it in there. The lighting is relaxing and the decorations are tasteful. 5stars.

Service: our waiter was J. Macintosh. I only saw his name on the check and that's all it showed. Best service experience of my life. He has a gift for describing each item on the menu. You can taste his descriptions. He is very attentive and friendly. 

Food: best salmon nigiri I've ever eaten. Everyone that tried one said the same. The Chilean sea bass was amazing as was the chinese sausage fried rice. There was a sashimi dish my dad ordered that had jalape√±os on top. Don't order that. It kills the taste of the sashimi. The fortune cookie dessert was creative and delicious. Definitely order one.

One of my favorite chain Asian fusion spots. The food is tasty and the service is decent. It's a little on the pricey side so buyer beware. Also, atmosphere is dark and loud (club like) so it doesn't really scream family environment.

Take it from someone who experienced great tasting sushi as fresh as they come.

Stationed overseas for 4 years I've had the luxury of experiencing and enjoying varieties of sushi and Japanese cuisine from Tokyo to Osaka. With high expectations and standards I expected nothing, but quality and taste for the appropriate price for the right food. (Especially being in the main spotlight of Vegas.) Sushi is expensive and in all Vegas is expensive, but charging 9 dollars for an instant miso soup deluged in hot water is beyond overpriced, but rather senseless. As for the main course I would compare it to Japan's dollar conveyor belt sushi resturaunts were they serve two large sushi for a dollar and the miso soup is actually miso soup! It's not Japan (I know) and no, the world is not running out of fish either. I say this not for my own health, but for next wallet waiting to be dipped in soy sauce. 

But the resturaunt is kinda pretty.
Excellent option for dinner in Vegas. Sexy ambiance, good food, reasonable prices for what it is. And dinner gets you immediate entry into one of the best clubs in Vegas.

everyone loves buddha, right? who doesn't? tao's got one, a 20-foot golden buddha gracefully staring down at you. now, that's what i'm talking about. this is vegas, baby, and it's all about money.  FYI, tao was the highest grossing indepenent restaurant in the US in 2006. ($55 mil, that's $16 mil more than No.2). they must be doing something right.

tao's service was surprisingly great although we arrived 8-ish without reservation. we were seated promptly with courtesy. our server was super nice and informative, as he explained every single dishes we've ordered as they arrived at our table.

interior deco was as usual. check it out for yourself on their website. 

some of the dishes we've tried:

small plate: thai stuffed shrimp with garlic, lime, and thai chili sauce 
small plate: satay of chilean sea bass with wok roasted asparagus
wasabi crusted filet mignon with tempura of onion rings
chef's roll
desert: chocolate zen parfait

the food was all excellent, but this place is really more about the vibe and the people-watching. tao is a popular destination for private parties among celebrities. the bill came out to be around $130, including a couple of drinks. not bad for a fun dinner in vegas.

i would definitely visit there again next time i go to vegas.
Amazing.   Food, service and ambiance were all worth the bit of extra money spent.   You have to try the coconut pudding so leave room for dessert!

I always have to get my TAO fix every time I go to Vegas.  Best Asian cuisine on the strip.  The food is always great and presentations creative. Haven't had a dish that I didn't like.  The wait staff is very professional, very knowledgeable from apps to dessert, cocktails to the wine list.  The evening that we were there, they offered a 3 course pre-pix menu for $55/person, with quite a few selections for each course.  The portions were plenty and the taste even more outstanding.  What we did was to get everything on the menu so we can share all the dishes.

Cocktails:
TAO-hito, TAO's version of the classic Mojito with Bacardi Limon Rum
Lychee Martini, Belvedere, Triple Sec and Fresh Lychee Puree 
Mango Tamarind Martini, Finlandia Mango Vodka, Cranberry Juice and Tamarind
Orient Express, Stolichnaya Vanilla Vodka, Kahlua and Chilled Espresso

Wines:  
Shiraz, Hope Estates 2007, Hunter Valley, Australia

Appetizers:
Satay of Chicken with Peanut Sauce - Chicken cooked just right.  Peanut sauce so tasty.

Spicy Tuna Tartare on Crispy Rice Cakes - Tartare just seasoned perfectly.  I could have had two of these... that good!

Crispy Thai Shrimp with Spicy Pineapple Sauce - Shrimps were huge!  Spice just right.

Entrees:
Wasabi Crusted Filet Mignon with Tempura of Onion Rings - Wasabi crust not too overwhelming as Wasabi can be.  Filet cooked at medium with just the right pink to the meat.

Pad Thai Noodles - Best Pad Thai ever....

Soy Ginger Glazed Salmon with Udon Noodles and Spinach - Salmon cooked medium, noodles flavorful. 

Side Dishes:  
Vegetable Fried Rice
Spicy Hoi Yin Eggplant

Desserts:
Chocolate Spring Rolls w/Kalamansi Dipping Sauce - OMG Delish!!!

Crispy Fuji Apple Blossoms serviced with Tahitian Vanilla Bean Ice Cream - OMG Delish!!!
Assorted Ice Creams and Sorbets with Almond Sesame Cookies - OMG Delish!!!


OVERALL EXPERIENCE:
Food:  Made sure you bring a big appetite.  The dishes don't skip on portion control.

Service:  Outstanding.

D√©cor:  Very Asian with a ZEN like feel.  Bring you camera for some great photo opts.  You know us Asian just love to take pictures!

Price:  Can be pricey, but wouldn't you just want to dine at a place with a ZEN like atmosphere and enjoy your food with calm....

After dinner, the restaurant turns into a nightclub, so enjoy the rest of your evening drinking and dancing.  What a way to end the evening!

Highly Recommend!

Enjoy!

Let me start off by saying that I absolutely LOVE Tao! The decor is amazing, the staff is very friendly & helpful, and the food is delicious. And if that's not enough for you, inform your waiter that you plan on going to the club after dinner and they will give you a stamp that will get you in for free (both males & females) and let you skip the line. You can't beat that! 

We visited Tao (Restaurant) on 4/1/10. We made same day reservations and they were able to accommodate us. I had the "Crispy coconut shrimp with Thai peanut sauce" and my date had the "Soy ginger glazed salmon with udon noodles and spinach." Both dishes were great - Cooked perfectly, even to the toughest food critic's standards. However, I think the best part of the meal came at the end. Like any other Asian restaurant, they give you a free fortune cookie with your bill. But these are not your standard boring fortune cookies. The fortunes inside are a little more unique than most. Mine said "You will receive a spanking in your near future" and they bear the Tao logo on the corner. Definitely made us laugh at the end of a really great meal. 

On the down side, prices are a little high here, but that is expected from any nice restaurant in Las Vegas. Don't let this deter you - This place is worth the splurge! I highly recommend Tao - I know I will make time for Tao every time I go to Vegas!

Eating in a place where the energy is so peaceful is priceless. The food is very good the cocktails are refreshing and nice presented and the menu is very good and it has a nice variety. I had the mandarin fried rice that I totally love and some sushi rolls ( I did not like the taste of my rolls too much) however is worth the experience the feeling is amazing when you are in the middle of such an amazing atmosphere.

I LOVE everything about this place!  It's a restaurant/night club at the Venetian.  When we called for reservations, the frist available time was at 11:15 pm. One of my male friends said that he and his friends had a difficult time getting in the last time they were in Vegas.   

We got there and we had to wait a few minutes at the lounge for our table.  People were already partying and they got us free drinks, yes!

This place is very trendy, very hip.  The decor and lighting was perfect and  there were at least 2 giant buddhas that I saw.  It was a very nice touch, added to the elegance of the place.

The one thing we did not like is that it's hard to talk to everyone at the table during the meal.  Loud music was busting from the night club.  If you are looking to get that intimate conversation going on, this is not a good place.  But then,  that gave us time to just enjoy our great meal.

We had ordered:
Spicy Tuna Tartare on Crispy Rice
Pork Spring Roll with Thai Chili Sauce
Black Pepper Sizzled Filet Mignon with Udon Noodles
Pad Thai
Mandarin Sizzled Fried Rice with Roast Pork
Crispy Coconut Shrimp
Chai Kiss
Chocolate Lave for dessert

I won't even try to describe each of them.  Everything on our table was oh so good.  There was nothing that we didn't like.  We also ordered cocktails and they were refreshing.  All was good good good.

After dinner, we hit the club.  We liked the kind of music they were playing.  The dance floor was great.  It was packed and crowded. 

We just had a good time here.  This is definitely a must go restaurant/nightclub in Vegas.

100% Amazing. I look forward to returning each time a come to Las Vegas!  The food was probably the best I've ever had. Our waiter (Dalon?) never missed a beat and gave us perfect service. My new favorite place in Las Vegas!

Ok I didn't eat here, but I give it at least four stars for the design and ambiance. Absolutely gorgeous. Got a hot date? Take them here STAT!

The lobby sets a romantic tone w/ old-fashioned white bathtubs 3/4 full of water with candles and flowers floating on top.

We decided to come so that we can have a nice dinner and then easily get into Tao.  I actually thought the food was really good and the service was great too.  It is a bit pricey, but oh well - it's Vegas.

Made reservations on opentable.com and got seated pretty quickly (there were only 2 of us)

Crispy tuna sashimi roll - inventive and different, but just ok in my book
Lobster wontons with shitake ginger broth - yum, v. good, would get this again
Wok seared NY sirloin - good sized portion, nicely cooked meat, the sauce and mushrooms were very flavorful
TAO lo mein - really big portion, v. yummy but was your typical lo mein from any chinese restaurant

Before we left we got a stamp on our wrist that said "Line Pass".  We went back to our hotel to relax for a bit and then went to TAO a bit later and got in no problem.

We went as a company on business. The service was outstanding and the food was better. If you want a meal, cocktails and a great place to visit, this will blow you away. There was not a food they served that did not please the palate.

Better than the Tao in NYC!

Pros:  
Excellent food! Try about 3 oz. ($16 per oz) of the raw Kobe beef Tao Shabu Shabu. Also, the Soy Ginger Glazed Salmon with Udon Noodles and Spinach ($26).
Atmosphere is chic and just right. We sat at the sushi bar since there was limited seating, but the seats were spacious and comfortable. 
Drinks are excellent here. Especially their Saketini. 
Dress to impress. 

Cons: Reservations. My gf and I were here on a busy Labor Day Weekend. We called to make reservations the morning of, but they were fully booked until 10:45. The hostess answered that if it were just two people, then they should be able to seat us right away.  We had to wait for about an hour to find seats.
Food was really really good, really expensive tho, but thats what you can kinda expect at a place like this. One of the best asian themed restaurants on the las vegas strip. Make sure to get dessert

My new favorite place to dine in Las Vegas. I love the atmosphere and the food is excellent. I had the Chilean sea bass which is to die for. And the tempura shrimp and tuna roll, very good I will definitely dine there every time I'm in Vegas.

Tao never disappoints. It's sexy, romantic, and full of flare. Love the tubs with roses as you walk in. Anyone that has dined here, can't deny that the ambience is absolutely on point. You are swept away to another world upon entering

I can only speak on my GO TO dishes every time I've dined. Get these and you won't be disappointed: Spicy Tuna Tartare on Crispy Rice and the Miso Glazed Sea Bass. Did I mention that both of these can be made gluten free for this celiac? Yup, they can. The miso literally falls apart by practically just looking at it. The top has some sort of sweet and crispy delight baked in. It truly is divine. The Spicy tuna tartare that sits on a delectable crispy rice is out of this world. 

It's a fun splurge, and worth a sexy Vegas night with friends or that special someone. Job well done

Went to Tao for dinner and then when there upstairs opened into a night club later on... We were on vacation for my fianc√©es 30th bday. Food was delish! Loved the sushi. Got the lychee martini--- amazing, not too sweet but had a real nice kick to it. The ambiance was everything!
Great dinner. Sea bass is to die for! Service was great. We did A family style meal and let the staff pick for us. Overall great meal!
Came here on a business trip. The service was excellent and the food was delicious. The temperature of the restaurant was pretty cold though... probably in anticipation of dancing.

They may say Tao is meant to be a spiritual dining experience, but after our terrible night there I was closer to wrathful sin than enlightenment. 

I made a reservation at Tao for the second anniversary of the first date I had with my girlfriend. We came all the way to Vegas from San Diego, and we were curious about Tao's because of the interesting decor etc. 

Quite literally the moment we arrived the atmosphere became oppressive. Our biggest concern and the truly unforgivable factor in this ordeal was that the very second we arrived, there was a security guard playing on his phone who for some reason or other determined we were criminals of some sort.. He was large, Caucasian, and messy haired (I only write this in the hopes that the management will read this review at some point and give him a stern talking to), this lummox of a man took one look at us and apparently instantly decided we were up to no good. I have no idea why, we were a young couple, well dressed, happily chatting etc. He didn't take his eyes off of us for the entire night, he followed us when we went to the host to claim our reservation (which just FYI took about ten minutes or so after our reservation time), he followed us to our seats, glowering the whole time. He checked in on us every now and again, just standing a bit away from us trying (and failing) not to be obvious about it. When we had eaten and we started to head out he was coming back to check on us again, the moment he saw us he turned back around and started speaking into what I assume was an earpiece. Not subtle at all... My girlfriend at this point was incredibly upset; she didn't know if he was sizing us up as criminals, drooling over her (she is very attractive), or if he thought her mid length skirt was a sign she was a hooker or something (no way...her outfit was very tasteful). Either way she walked straight out. I however walked up to our forboding shadow and asked if there was a problem and why he had been glowering at us all night. He responded with "Oh its just... Nothing..." and looked away. Very nice, Tao... Treat your patrons like criminals and then halfheartedly try to cover it up with lies... 

But that aside on to the restaurant itself. 

The atmosphere at Tao is admittedly very nice, trendy music playing constantly beats like the pounding heart of the restaurant. Clumsy Asian inspired art does its job in setting an oriental-fusion mood for the dining hall, watched over by a giant Buddha, overdone but altogether nicely set. 

Unfortunately the atmosphere is the best part of the restaurant. We had two people help us with our meal, a bus boy who was obviously better trained than any other member of their staff came, introduced himself, welcomed us to the restaurant and got us some water in a cordial yet amiable manner. I wish I had a better memory for names because if I could single him out for the managers I'd say he deserved a promotion.

Our actual waiter on the other hand never even bothered introducing himself, he was rushed and a bit curt if I'm being honest. but he did take our orders and get our food to us so there's that much... In his defense he did seem to have a full load in his section but it was still off-putting, that he didn't even say "Hi", just "So what can I get for you folks tonight"... 

The food itself was well... okay... I mean it was nice, don't misunderstand, it was good food. Just not great, definitely not worth what they asked for. I had the Crispy Thai Pork which almost seemed like it came out of a frozen meal package, and my lady had Spicy Chicken which oddly enough was less spicy than my dish, in fact the chicken itself was rather bland. So the food was a bit of a let down too. 

They were also out of most of my favorite beers, Tiger, Sapporo etc. so I settled for a warm Kirin out of the bottle. Not much to say other than well, warm beer. 

All in all I sadly have to warm away anyone who actually wants to have a good time in Vegas. Tao is rife with ridiculously bad staff and disappointing food. Do not ruin your evenings as we did by frequenting this travesty of a restaurant.

Boy I wish we had just ordered Room Service...

I had a really good experience at Tao for dinner. We didn't have to wait long for our table because Larry made reservations. The atmosphere is really nice. Very intimate! We had a very nice waiter (who even gave us stamps to go to Lavo.)

I ordered a Tao-tini. Yummy! I'm not a huge fan of hot and sour soup but I did enjoy theirs. The rest of the night I had sushi which were all fresh.

I went with my boyfriend & 4 yr old son & we really enjoyed it. Service was friendly, attentive & majority of the waiters were quite decent looking lol.

*Lychee Martini - Excellent
*Pork Spring Roll w/ Thai Chili sauce - delicioius, tho they're more like a triangle shape than a roll lol
*Pad Thai - mediocre, wouldn't order it again
*Crunchy Spicy Yellowtail Roll w/ Crushed Onion Rings - Flavorful, Fresh & unique
*a Crusted Red Snapper dish - Awesome. the fish was cooked just right: not too dry, not too undercooked.& the sauce went well with it. 

It's a fun, trendy atmosphere & I definitely want to go back...minus one star for the small portions...but ya gotta expect it in Vegas I guess.

I went to Tao Asian Bistro on April 4, 2013 with my boyfriend for our romantic date in Vegas. I loved the atmosphere and decor. The music is loud and pumping through out the restaurant but it didn't bother me at all. It could bother some older people though but it set the tone for the ambiance of the place and I personally enjoyed it.  I suggest making a reservation to the place since it is pretty busy.  The wait for our table did not take too long. We were able to grab a drink at the bar right there located in the entrance and get our barrings and enjoy what this place had to offer. The staff was very helpful and friendly. The food..amazing. I had the chilean sea bass..OMG! So good..so worth it. Boyfriend had the kobe steak topped with onions, amazing as well! Dessert was terrific.  After dinner, if you wanted to go to the nightclub all you have to do is ask your waiter and a hostess will stamp your hand to get in to the club. You still have to go outside to check your i.d. but the wait in the line is minimal.  
So, why the 3 star?  Well everything was GREAT except at the end of our meal when the waiter brought BACK our check to sign the total. I wasn't sure what that was about but pointed to my boyfriend to have him sign it because he was paying for it. Now, we are seated very close to the other people and the waiter yells out, " Well when you tip me less than 10% you have to initial that's what you want."  People next to us were looking at us and my face just went flush! Then he walked away muttering something under his breath, I was trippin! My boyfriend had miscalculated the tip, not usually coming to a place like this and feeling a bit uncomfortable, he quickly signed the bill over and gave it to the waiter not realizing he miscalculated the tip.  Now, I understand..don't get me wrong. I was a bartender so tips are apart of your income and perhaps in a place like this, management may look at the waiters performance as a reason why his tip was so small, which clearly was not the case, he was great. But to embarrass us like that, really upset me and instead of going to the club later, we just decided to go home. So much for a romantic night. But you know, regardless of all that, I do know that Vegas thrives on money and on our way out I gave the waiter another tip because he was good, no doubt. IT was just a misunderstanding. 
Again, I understand where the waiter was coming from but jeeze, maybe speak softer and don't walk away muttering things under your breathe making us feel like we were unwelcomed and like we did not belong. Because of this, regardless of the awesome food, we will not go back nor advise others to do so either because I believe it could have been handled better with less embarrassment for customers who spent over $200 for dinner.

This is my second visit to TAO and again I was net disappointed. Brought wife and two friends along

My wife had the sea bass and said it was the best she has ever had our friends had the sand bass and shrimp special both were delicious. We had sides of green beans and onion rings also great. The women ordered boldly Mary's which were not good our waiter was more then happy to replace the drinks. 

The service was great along with the manager checking if everything was ok. We had drinks and wine sushi and spring rolls. Be careful when ordering it turned out to be a lot of food! Total bill with out tip 425.00. 

Even with the cost this is a must when in Vegas. We will return order less food but based on the past enjoy great food

Our vacation in Las Vegas started with a romantic dinner at Tao...we had to race over to not miss our reservation, the restaurant is gorgeous. I loved the dim lighting and the hip music playing, they even honored my request for a booth. Well the booth was actually sofa cushions and throw pillows hehe. Our server was nice but as other yelpers have mentioned the service is fast, so fast I feel like you can't really enjoy your evening. Bussers constantly hoover around like ninjas to clear items right away making me feel rushed but I'm sure its because they have a lot of reservations. Started with the King crab roll , very good and then we had the miso seabass and the duck fried rice. The seabass was so delicious just like butta! Recommend this dish , the duck fried rice my guy seemed to enjoy and for dessert we had the molten chocolate cake Mmmm delightful!

Decided to come here for dinner, but the rude staff that look like bouncers said they were closed for an event. Not very happy about that but after speaking with the staff I'm glad we ended up going else where anyway. I'm sure the rest of the meal wouldn't have been as disappointing.

My boyfriend and I came here for one of my 21st birthday dinners (we were in Vegas celebrating).
