For main I had the Buddah Chicken, which was a Thai chicken dish which was pre sliced and presented very nicely. The taste was excellent as was the quality of the meal and flavors. My wife enjoyed her glazed salmon.  
With so many great places in Vegas and the bar raised so high it is hard to give out 5 stars. In any other city my visit would be a 5 star meal. In Vegas they roll with a solid 4!

This review is for the restaurant only. 

Well, the wait was about 40 minutes on a saturday night. Whatever, I expected it. Luckily they give you a pager and there are some shops around to kill time. Plus theres a room full of couches to wait around on, and a small bar as well as cocktail waitresses that will be more than happy to bring you $700 bottles. 

The food was pretty good. A lot of the "fancy food I have no idea what this is" type stuff on the menu. But if you're into the fancy stuff you'll like it.

Our waiter was super awesome. I expected some douche baggery at this place with the staff but everyone seemed pretty nice and even most of the security at the door were pretty nice guys. But back to the waiter, he hooked us up with drinks and was very helpful with menu questions. Unfortunately no "group drink" bowls for alcohol. Those are always fun and this would be the perfect place. 

The theme here is pretty cool too. You've got the Buddhist stuff going on, it's very dark, and theres a giant statue on one wall. They've got loud music going the whole time, not like club loud, but you certainly can't have a quiet conversation. 

Would I go back? Maybe. I don't regret going though. If you eat here you get free entrance to the club. Gotta get a stamp!

What is Tao? Lots of Chinese dishes in a dark opium den setting with Buddha statues, Chinese scrolls and generally nice decor. I was there with a party of 12 and the service was good until the entrees came out. Then it was a painful wait. To the point I wish we'd skipped dessert.

Now, the food was a hit with my group. But if you have eaten good Chinese or Asian fusion you'd say this was a tiny bit above average. I think an average meal at PF Chang's is about the same. I'm glad I have but ain't be choosing to come back.

We came here and made reservations for our sons 21st bday. First they did a great job in making my son feel great for his bday. The birthday package we purchased was perfect. The food and service was great and the after party in the club was amazing. We had a great time but most importantly my son had a great time and really enjoyed celebrating his 21st bday at your establishment thank you
Awesome dinner. Great service. The restaurant is really well decorated. The salmon sashimi was excellent. We also tried the orange chicken, pad Thai and filet mignon. Delicious!

High class Asian fusion restaurant in the Venetian hotel in Vegas. Near the left side of the building. 

Love Buddhist statues, wind instruments, and other varies decor. Even though the music doesn't fit the Asian theme it was still nice. 

I recommend sharing food and save room for dessert. Especially try the giant fortune cookie that you can't get anywhere else. It has chocolate and white chocolate mousse and you may get a funny fortune. 

I forget the name of the chicken dish but it was flavorful and sweet. The braised mushrooms and sushimi was excellent. And I like their Singapore noodles better than anywhere else, because they add veggies, meat and shrimp. I don't like shrimp but my dad does so he had plenty to eat in the noodles. 

They also have good cocktails and a wide menu of other beverages from teas to alcohol.

Low down:

Scene - 5 stars, great atmosphere and decor
Wait time - NA stars, can't knock them for being a popular spot...assume a 30+ min wait

Sushi - 3 stars - REALLY really good...but about $4 a piece. This is to date the most expensive nigiri I have ever eaten, not worth $4

Other Food: 4 star - food is great, great taste and great presentation

Cost: 1 star - we did a family style dinner with about 1-2 drinks each and after tip came to about $100 each and I felt like I hadn't eaten much  food. The others felt the same...which basically means Bling bling for not much

I booked an 8:30pm reservation several months ago when I planned my trip to Vegas. We were not seated until almost 10:00pm. The ambience and decor of the restaurant is spectacular. The Chilean sea bass was probably the best fish I have ever had. I would have given 5 stars but over an hour wait with a reservation is ridiculous.

I'm not a huge Asian Fusion fan, but I must concede that this place was great.
Stunning decor, attentive and personable waitstaff, and most importantly, fantastic food...
confirmed by my two total foodie Asian friends. Seven dishes: all super delicious, original, and unexpected. Our pitcher of cucumber mint mojito was dangerously delicious. 
We thoroughly enjoyed our evening here. Yeah yeah...so its a bit pricey.
Hey, it's The Venetian on Strip. Whatya expect!  
I did have to minus a star because:  1. two of the dishes were considerably over salted...the brussel sprouts and the long beans...no biggie, but ruined the perfection. 2. The ambiance although beautiful, was pitch black/dark and the music/noise was deafening...I know I know..it's also a nightclub...showing my dowdy age now?

Ambiance: Think buddhist temple meets upscale, classy Vegas restaurant. Dimly lit dining room with pulsing yet low music.

Service: Despite the busy, peak hour that I dined at TAO, I was happy with the attention and effort I was given from each and every staff member. Although I had to wait a tad bit long to get my order taken and for my bill, I still felt like a priority to my waitress. 

She took into account my dietary restrictions, asked the kitchen for details on specific ingredients, and made THE BEST menu suggestions!

Food: Wow! Their menu, a compilation of Chinese, Japanese and Thai food, is sure to impress. Try the Chilean Sea Bass (sweet, buttery and soft fish atop a bed of flavorful, saut√©ed veggies) and the shrimp tempura and spicy tuna roll with rice paper.

I also ordered the Drunken Lobster Pad Thai (which was lacking sauce and flavor and didn't live up to its name).

I give this place 3 stars

What is 5 star here:
-Lobster wontons are AMAZING!!! Like really mindblowing! This dish comes steaming in a balanced and flavorful shitake mushroom sauce. The wonton texture is perfectly cooked! A total standout dish!
-Ambience and service- Servers explain what is popular at the restaurant using soft statistics like "this dish is ordered 10 to 1 over others", etc. Our water glasses were always  filled and our tables cleared as soon as we finished. The place is hip with fresh rose petals in stone tubs and glass bowls and illuminated candles everywhere,
-Drinks! The taotini is great for chicks! The club makes a stinkin good cosmo too and for the normal club price of $13.
- Other - i have no opinion since i don't eat fish, but my hubby liked the chilean sea bass. 

1 Star Quality:
- The chicken sausage fried rice: it was SO SALTY!! I would have preferred fried rice from Panda Express over this lemon of a dish.  I had to choke it down with lots of water. With all the good reviews on this dish i hope what i had was just a fluke "lemon". The rice was soggy! And i picked out all the sausages to decrease the saltiness but that didn't help much. All i could think about was "I spent $18 on THIS???" 

Definitely not a fan of the prices particularly  because the food didn't blow my expectations to mars - I mean, an $18 Lobster wonton dish was awesome but only 5 pieces? My mom could cook that dish and charge $8 if she served it in a restaurant. And a salty fried rice also $18 is NOT how expensive chinese food should go for...
Food was good...service was horrible. We had the most obnoxious sever that was so rude last night for a birthday dinner. I will not be back.

Want the short of it? Don't, just don't...also CHECK YOUR BILL....want the whole story? Read on. 

They call it "vibe dining" because they certainly can't call it FINE dining. Not sure what "vibe" they were going for with the Asian heavy theme & weird choice 90's rock playing for the dinner service. 

Our story begins with a bubbly & gregarious hostess seating us and chatting about the menu. She informs us that the BEST way to dine is to do things "tapas" style and get lots of small plates. Well... we were here a couple days before for the New Years party and some of the small plate items were served. They were legit un edible. The salmon mousse was like salmon tooth paste! I forced myself to swallow it only because there was no place to spit it out. Any way.. seeing the same items on the menu I wasn't giving those things a second chance. At the time of the party I assumed it was because they went cheap for the New Years party & the actual food from the restaurant would be better. WRONG. 

Any way the friendly women in front of us asks for our drink selections and we both decide on the reasonably priced $18 sake flight. She lights up & says "Since you are both ordering one I will be sure to mix it up so you have a chance to taste even more of our sake and a couple higher end ones" This was a statement and not a question. We thought she was being genuinely nice. WRONG. She charged for what we thought was a complimentary up grade making those $18 flights about $64 each.

Now the food. I ordered the Singapore Mei Fun Noodles with no chicken extra shrimp. Did this piss off the kitchen or something? Cause my first complaint is that the shrimp were not all devained and even worst many of the ones that were had the "vain" sticking to the side of it instead. Really not appetizing. I couldn't get man buns attention so I kept cleaning them off and tried to just move past it. I should have kept them to show .... oh well. Then I bite into an onion and it is completely RAW all the red onions in my dish were raw. I like onions but this was terrible to do in a dish like this. It said it came with a sauce, the noodles had flavor but it they were dry ... there was no "sauce" that I could really tell. Basically I have had better Asian noodle dishes at the mall food court.

My boyfriend had the Duck fried rice. He said the duck was dry it might as well have been poorly cooked chicken. There was way to much hard rice to be considered reasonable even for fried rice and the flavor was only remotely enjoyable for a few bites before it just overwhelmed. 

We had been to the night club for New Years and one of the reasons we came back is I remembered them saying to show your ticket for 20% off of dinner so I ask about it and the waiter tells me has heard of no such thing but to his credit (the only credit he gets here) went to ask the manager. Turns out I was right but I missed the part about it being for New Years Day only. I felt it was completely reasonable to expect them to just honor it any way but they of course did not offer. 

When we get our bill & my BF realizes the BS over charge he also noticed that we haven't seen the girl who sat us for the rest of our meal. She brought out the drinks and left. He was annoyed at this point but the attitude of the wait staff and not being able to confront the girl he decide it isn't worth the fight. We were there on vacation relaxing & he didn't want to ruin it further by getting all worked up so he let it go. To be honest, if I had been the one paying the bill, I would have said something. I didn't know about this part till later & was pretty mad because the whole meal was a disappointment (even the "upgraded sake taste was bad. I didn't want blueberry crap for dinner and literally only one was good) and I would have spoken up.. I turned the other cheek on things like the raw onion just to keep the evening pleasant. Also, I don't think they care. I really don't think they gave a f*ck if we had nice meal. It is Vegas. Plenty of  new suckers. They don't NEED repeat customers.

Come here for the night life... maybe... not sure cause I paid for the special event... if the event says "heavily passed hors d'oeuvres" and you think GREAT I'll eat there! Don't count on it being something you WANT to eat. It was all so gross the waitresses serving were literally BEGGING people to take it. Not joking. They looked embarrassed having to serve it.  You would see them with the same 10 bites on their tray for like a half hour at a time because people would try ONE and never go back for another. You weren't fooling them twice. The Shrimp was like rubber and was being served cold but was warm... GROSS...

We had hot and sour and miso soups. We both preferred the hot and sour over the miso. It also comes with shrimp crackers. The lobster won tons were amazing as well as the yellowish sashimi with jalape√±os. For dessert we had the giant fortune cookie. It was filled with halo chocolate and have whipped cream and surrounded with fresh fruit. A great way end a meal.

The food was pretty good here, but the service was suckadellic!  It took FOREVER for us to get our check.  We weren't the only ones.  The table next to us was getting fed up too.  (Same waiter.)  We went around 8p on a Thursday.  Decided to pass on the club, because it was basically top 40.  I'm more into edm.

Came to Vegas for Vacation and stayed in the Venetian so this restaurant was a perfect location for my visit.  We arrived on a Wednesday evening and it wasn't that busy but we made reservations anyway for a party of 6.

I love the sexy Asian, contemporary atmosphere; It's very chic and upscale. I just wish there was a little more lighting to show off their interior decor even the more!  Their service was splendid and on point.  Our waiter was very detail oriented and also gave a great introduction and set the high expectation for the evening.  He recommended the chef special; it's basically an all you can eat smorgasbord and the chef makes what he recommends.  We did not take advantage of this because our party had too many food restrictions but I'm sure any party would!

We ordered the strip teriyaki steak, rainbow sushi, Orange chicken, and chili sea bass.  I highly recommend the strip steak and sea bass.  Both were perfectly cooked and very tender.  The sea bass felt like it melted in your mouth.  

A great restaurant for any celebration; with a party or a romantic dinner for couples.  You'll definitely want to make a reservation and put on cocktail attire for this visit!

My wife and I had dinner here with friends on Saturday night and came away a bit underwhelmed.

By no means was the food bad, it very tasty, mostly what soured my view of the establishment was the overly loud music. I realize it converts to a club at night, however not being able to hear someone across the table unless they speak loudly and I lean in does not make for an enjoyable dining experience.

I was also a bit disappointed that I was steered away from ordering the orange chicken by my waitress. I don't consider myself someone who enjoys very spicy food, and when I ordered it our waitress asked if I liked my food spicy. I explained I do like some spice, but not large amounts of it. She then told me I might be better off ordering something else. Not wanting to ruin dinner with friends by not eating my meal I opted to order the filet mignon with udon noodles. While I enjoyed the flavor of the filet with udon I was disappointed in two regards. Firstly the amount of filet mignon with the noodles was pitiful, I had maybe 3 oz of meat total in my meal I think. Secondly, the sauce with udon noodles was tossed in was pretty average, I think I've had the same sauce in a meal at Noodles & Co.  To top it off, my friend ordered the orange chicken despite our waitress' warning and found that it wasn't nearly as spicy as the waitress made it out to be.

Despite hearing how great some of the desserts here were, we decided to skip it and go elsewhere so that we could actually hold a conversation without shouting.

Called a couple weeks ahead to make reservations for our party, as there were going to be several girls for my bestie's bachelorette party. I was shocked at the rudeness over the phone.  Thankfully, they more than made up for it when we were there.

I took the advice of our server and passed on the Ahi for the Chilean Sea Bass.  That saying, "melts in your mouth" was true in this case.  The spices complimented the fish, and it was cooked to perfection as well.  Each bite was ecstasy.  That's really the only way to describe it.  And as embarrassing at it is, there were moments where I literally closed my eyes to fully enjoy it (and so did the other girl that ordered it!).

I had a bite of someone's sushi roll as well, which was also incredible; so fresh, and uh, last time I checked, Las Vegas is pretty inland, so... wow. Someone else ordered the Miso-glazed Salmon, and raved about that as well.  Lobster wontons, probably not the best choice, opt for something different.

Definitely trust what your server has to say... you can't possibly go wrong!

Went there for dinner on a Friday night on a recent trip to Vegas.  My girlfriends and I had plans to hit up Tao nightclub later that night, so we decided to go a little earlier and have dinner as well. I have always thought of the club and not the restaurant when I heard the name Tao, so I wasn't sure what to expect.  We didn't have a reservation, but we only had to wait 15 minutes or so.  The service was crazy fast even though it was packed at 9:30 on a Friday.  Our server was very friendly and was very honest when asked about what was good and what we should stay away from.  I had the New York strip steak, and it was fantastic!  They also had a Kobe steak on the menu, which is what I really wanted, but I decided to save myself $83 and use it on drinks later;)

We've been looking forward to dinner at Tao since we planned our trip to Las Vegas. We made a reservation for 9pm. We arrived on time. We were told our table would be ready shortly. We spent over an hour waiting at the bar for our table to be ready. FINALLY after sitting down at our table we waiting another 20 minutes before a server came to take our table to take our drink order. Waited another 15 minutes and no wine! 2 hours at Tao no drinks, no food, no apology. I set up a Yelp account specifically to rate this restaurant. I'm so disappointed.

The atmosphere is very nice and the statues are incredible. My party and I had a reservation; yet we still had to wait an hour for our table (without exaggeration). That was definitely a bummer. Other than that the waitress and bussers provided us with excellent service. The food was nothing special, we ordered a little bit of everything and nothing was my liking. The lobster pad Thai that is very popular here wasn't good and neither was the spring mountain roll I ordered. I only seemed to like the rock shrimp lettuce cups. I ordered the taotini and it was good but too strong for me. I don't think I'll be returning.

The restaurant on its own leaves something to be desired. If you buy a certain number of entrees, they let the party into the nightclub after, though, which is worth it. You are paying for the architecture and to be surrounded by the beautiful people, not for great cuisine. Not terrible, though.

We didn't actually go into the restaurant, rather we strolled into the lounge on a lowkey Sunday nite just to see what the hype was all about.
The decor was GORGEOUS.  I want my house to look like the inside of this place!
My drink was fantastic.  My friend ordered a tall greyhound and the waitress was nice enough to ask "double tall or tall w/ more grapefruit juice?"  No one has ever asked that before, so we gave her a big tip.
The downside was that our drinks cost a lot of $$, however, the place itself and the friendly waitstaff made it that much better.
We would definitely go again when/if we come back into town.

I ate at Tao while in las Vegas for a work conference. The place has a nice vibe, decor and DJ that reminded me a little bit of the Buddha bar in Paris. 

Given we were a large group, the menu was determined in advance and afforded us an opportunity to sample a large number of dishes. Large being the operative word as the dishes came out rapid fire. Overall, everything was delicious and cooked perfectly, a feat given the large size of the party.

Stand out appetizers included the Spicy tuna on crispy rice, Bamboo steamed vegetable dumplings, Chinese 5 spiced beef short ribs, Chicken Yakitori and the mini lettuce cups with Bang bang chicken. I wasn't asfond of the Peking duck Mushu wraps or the mini vegetable egg rolls. Foe entrees, we had the roasted Thai buddha chicken, which I would highly recommend, and Mr. Wongs jumbo shrimp, which was flavorful but drowning in sauce. The Che'f selection of mixed vegetables tempura was good if you like friend food. I only tried the sweet potatoes and they were delicious. The Singapore Mei fun noodles and Buddha's harmonized vegetable feast were ho hum and I would not rush to order either one.

Dessert was outrageous and featured a giant plate with fresh fruit, a HUGE fortune cookie filled with white and dark chocolate mousse, donuts and egg rolls filled with dark chocolate which were to die for.

If you're in the mood fro Asian food in a clubbish atmosphere, Tao should fit the bill.
Every dish with beautifully presented and so beautiful! Very unique great selection, the atmosphere is amazing, the service is great.  Just be ready to pay.

My husband and I went out to eat here on our first day in Vegas. The setting and decor of this place is Amazing and very intimate. We had the well-famous Chilean Sea Bass which held up to its praises. Our overall experience was truly unforgettable!  A MUST when visiting. 

Also, we were able to experience their nightclub. Although crowed, it was a nice vibe with all types of music playing. The atmosphere stayed in consistent "fun times".

Had reservation for 7:00 and got seated 7:45 and only cause we pushed them a bit otherwise looked like another half an hour.. Appetizers were ok ..i really liked the spring rolls.. Sushi was tasteless and rice was undercooked. Service could have been better..

I don't give out 5 stars often, but when I do, it's for a place like Mama's Fish House, or Tao Asian Bistro.

The food was amazing.  The service was the fastest and most friendly I have ever seen.  Lenny is amazing, and his boss, the Captain for our section was incredibly kind. 

We had so much great food!  Yellowtail, world's best dim sum, sushi that rocked, I can't remember the rest. JUST GO.  If you are in Vegas, GO TO TAO.  Then go to the super amazing nightclub upstairs.

PS my wife had her birthday and they brought her out a 16-inch fortune cookie with custard inside and a candle.  So fantastic.

Terrible food! Very loud inside. Bad service!
All 10 of us didn't like it! We don't recommend this place. Overpriced! NEVER come back! From the time of our reservation to the time of serving food - 2 hours!!!
Bad place!

Ultima sera a Las Vegas, che si mangia? Proviamo il Tao! Molto bello, con una statua del Buddha nella sala, terrazzine laterali insomma ambiente molto curato (come tutti i ristoranti della Strip).  

All'entrata c'√® il bar con tavoli per chi volesse fare solo l'happy hour (molto di moda ovunque qui) o prendere un cocktail.

Ci mettiamo a sedere proprio sotto la statua, molto suggestivo. Purtroppo la musica √® cos√¨ alta che facciamo fatica a sentirci al tavolo (eravamo in 6, quindi un tavolo rotondo a largo).
Luci molto basse che quasi non leggo il men√π (ma siamo due su sei con questo problema, quindi saremo noi).

Il cameriere ci propone degli antipasti da condividere perch√© siamo tanti e perderebbe la strada di ritorno per ordinare da ciascuno (ci fa capire). Risultato abbiamo avuto 5 antipasti con un boccone ciascuno, molto buoni ma ti lascano la voglia.
L'ordinazione dei piatti principali viene a prenderla solo dopo che abbiamo mangiato gli antipasti con il risultato che abbiano dovuto aspettare un bel po'.

Molto pi√π adatto a coppie o gruppetti di amici che dopo una giornata di lavoro.

Tao restaurant in vegas.......ughhhhhhhh....the food was okay,pricey,foo-foo food that comes to you in very small portions....the ambiance is pretty and calm,service is good. My friends and I always wanted to eat there,and in our mind we thought that we would be able to get into the Club Tao for free after spending all that $$$ for little foo-foo asian food,we were given only a LINE PASS!! a pass to bypass the line but still PAY.......so on top of the dinner, we had to pay an extra $20 to get into the club, and it was SOOOOOOOOOOO PACKED in there, that we could not even get on the dancefloor...instead hanging on the sidelines of the bars and not even on the main floor.....overall, a bad,expensive experience,which made the combo of the 2 affiliated TAO-ness......just horrible.........one thing comes to mind when I think of TAO now.......''OVER-RATED''

Hi we checked out TAO after our limo drive gave us some free coupons for free food/drinks here.  I guess it's ok but it felt sort of "chainy" for my tastes.  The food was sorta greasy and the service was great but if I had to pay for my food/drinks then I would probably give it 3 stars...
Sorry, but PF Chang does it better. The horrible house DJ made it impossible to talk.  And to spend $180 for 4. What a waste

Visually appealing, even though here in SF we aren't starving for this sort of decor or restaurant. I did like the stone walls and candle lit tubs in the entry way. Did not like the Cheesecake Factory type beeper thing they do even though you have a reservation.
The food is mediocre at best, if they just focused on Chinese, Thai or Japanese it would be a lot better, especially since they're trying to pull off a tapas thing. Nothing stood out as a wow, but they do use real crab in the California rolls. For these prices and since they claim to offer as shared plates, the portions could be larger. They have a decent wine & sake list and a full bar, which is where most of our money went, hello expense account!
The servers were right on it, cute and friendly. I even chatted with our guy about changes I think they could make & he agreed and had his own recommendations, that showed that he was interested and not just a Tao crony. He was also flattering, not just for tips I don't think, but after that glass of 12 year McCallum to top off the night, who knows...

This is a review for the Tao Restaurant:

I know what you're thinking: style over substance.  I was thinking that too when I first walked into this restaurant.  It is like eating in a nightclub or lounge.  Lots of well-dressed good looking people, and relatively loud music.  This place is a scene.  But you know what?  The substance was actually there for the meal that I had.

We shared a series of small dishes and main courses and were very impressed.  The substance was actually there in the food and the service was friendly and attentive.  A nice treat considering that I was expecting the worst.

For our starters we had the shrimp with peanut sauce, XO Chinese long beans, the crispy spicy tuna roll, and the spicy eggland dish.  All of the dishes were quite good, flavorful, and had a good portion size.  The dish that really stood out here was the crispy spicy tuna roll which ranks up there with one of the best rolls I've had -- it packed a nice kick and the fish was fresh.

For the main courses, we shared the chilean sea bass, the typhoon lobster, and the wasabi crusted filet mignon.  The main courses were all delicious.  The sea bass was fantastic as was the lobster.  It was all decadent and delicious.

I would come back here as the food lived up to the style of the restaurant.  Plus, you can a line pass if you eat here which allowed us to bypass the huge line into the Tao Nightclub and enter the club with no cover charge.  A nice bonus!

Is it loud? Yes. Expensive? Of course, it's Vegas and it's a half high end restaurant half night club. Is it still worth it? Yes. Just go. The service is phenomenal is the atmosphere is awesome. 

Be warned: going to Tao will ruin you for sushi. I'm worried I will never be able to top it.

Great service, great setting and great food....which was particularly exceptional given it was a large group and the restaurant was packed. We felt welcome from the beginning to the end including the hostess seating us, Brandon our server and the manager visiting a couple times. Other than a few choice items we left the selection of the food up to Brandon who took us on a great culinary journey of appetizers, sushi/sashimi and entrees - all of which I would order again. Especially notable are the miso glazed sea bass, garlic green beans, toro tatake, very fresh sashimi, eel special roll, etc. Definitely looking forward to go back to try more from their comprehensive menu. Definite must for Japanese food lovers.

We were eating here so we could easily get into the club.  It turns out the food is actually pretty good.  They sat us just a few minutes late.  We found a nice spot by the bar to have a few pre dinner drinks.  The drinks are pricey but the setting is great.

We started with the chicken satay and pork rolls.  Both were excellent.  The peanut sauce with the satay was great.  For my meal I had the filet with noodles.  The sauce was great.  I would have liked a little more meat, but I was still very happy with my meal.

For desert we shared the giant fortune cookie.  One half was filled with dark chocolate mouse.  The other half was filled white chocolate mouse.

Overall it was a very good meal.

This place is wonderful! Service was right on!! (Shout-out to Josh!!) Soo cute, but very knowledgeable and knew the menu inside and out. He also gave great trick on how to order besides the typical a la carte.

The cocktails were delish, very creative and original. 

TOTALLY would come back.

What can I say about TAO that hasn't already been said? Let me give it a shot! For starters, the bathtub looking decorations on the way in were stunning- filled with water and fresh rose petals with floating candles, absolutely gorgeous! There was no wait (amazing, given all the other reviews, but it was a Monday night...) so we were seated right by the floating Buddha. As for that-- this statue is breath-taking! It is approximately 20 feet tall, and appears to be floating on the pond of live koi fish. I happily drank with the TAO-tini (delish) and my companion had the lychee tini (a little too sweet for her) then the berries and bubbles (very good). 
We started with the Chicken Gyoza with Napa Cabbage and Soy Dipping Sauce (steamed) and we inhaled it. PERFECT! We then shared the miso glazed chilean sea bass over veggies (excellent) and the chicken pad thai (very good- not as spicy as I'd have liked though). The dessert menu was very diverse, and we settled on a 6-pack of buddha chocolates (adorably packaged-- almost too cute to eat! Milk, white and dark chocolates). 
The ambiance was absolutely divine, so much so that we did not want to leave. But our bellies were full, our drink glasses empty and the hour late-- so we did depart after all. But for sure, I will be going back!!
Delicious food, excellent service by Modesto and Toee!!! They made our night !!! Thank you again!!

4**** STARS FOR SERVICE AND AMBIANCE. 
2** STARS FOR FOOD. 

WOW, is the first thing I said when I entered. The decor is very asian themed but in a way that isn't too overwhelming or culture appropriation-y. I did like the little bath tubs filled with flowers and candles at the front entrance. 

There's a huge Buddha statue that's in the middle of the restaurant and it was pretty cool that they sat us in front of it. The servers and waitresses are quick and attentive. No complaints there, However, the food is another story.

I'd reccomend coming here for the experience and to lounge around but don't expect too much for the food. Out of the 5 dishes that we ordered, 2 were decent and 1 was a mochi dessert tasting. The sushi was kinda meh, but the postickers and shrimp lobster spring roll were tasty. I enjoyed the mochi tasting a lot, definitely a few unique flavors along with your usual chocolate and strawberry.


Overall, it was a nice dining experience that if you got some time and money to spend, I'd recommend trying.

We had a large party so we had to wait to be seated but as you come in the decor is all Asian Fusion flair and  and modern.  Once seated we got our drinks pretty quick and ordered a ton of small plates of: springrolls, spicy tuna rolls, prawns, yummy kobe sirloin, lobster wontons, etc.. Everything tasted pretty good but I was not wowed.  I ordered the chocolate parfait and it was the best!! Service seemed very prompt overall.  I think the place is nice but pretty pricey and maybe just a place you go one time and that is it.

Not only is Tao one of the most gorgeous restaurants i've ever seen, but the food AND service were at another level.  

Be sure to get the Sea Bass (melts like buttah, baby) and take full advantage of the bar.  The  eggplant, while quite spicy, is really good (and i normally HATE eggplant).  

The entire dining experience is great, and I found myself having a 3+ hr dinner at Tao (actually, we closed down the mezzanine dining level) and the waiter was not only attentive, but very personable.  The candle on our table went out and it took less than 30 seconds for someone to notice and replace it.  Yes, not really a critical part of having a nice dinner but it just showcases the level of service and attention to detail the wait staff had.  Everyone was willing to come by and ask how we're doing (including the mafia-don type manager who was really nice and actually kinda funny) but we didnt feel crowded at all.  

It's a bit pricey, esp if you have several drinks, but it's well worth it.

I ordered the pork pot stickers, they were very good. Also ordered hot edamame which were decent. Sushi was very good but expected. I ordered the Jordan Cabernet which was $120, about twice what it retails. I then ordered one of the most expensive items on the menu which was stir fried lobster, super salty, a little weird, should have gotten the Miso Chilean Sea Bass. The highlight was the deep friend Bread Pudding, which was one of the best desserts I have ever ever eaten. The fortune cookie dessert was not very good, looked good though. I then got a Warre's 1985 port which was amazing. I would pass on this one, way better restaurants in Vegas.

The Restaurant ambiance is amazing, super cool with a huge Buddha featured, flower baths and stunning lighting. The food was delicious. Highly recommend the Seabass, best I've ever had! Service (waitress) was a little short with us so I knocked the rating by one star. Other than that, definitely go check it out.

So, beautiful servers and the hosts are awesome. Lamar made me want to get table service. Vegas on a Thursday night didn't disappoint.  Grabbed table service the server was beautiful and very nice but literally disappeared for long periods of time.  Q was "Johnny on the spot" but I think for a "g" the attention would have been more prominent.  Vegas being Vegas the crowd was really good for Thursday but wasn't sold on Tao. But I am getting old.

My company choose to thow a party here for CES and let's just say it was a blast. How can you not have a blast when it's all you can drink? But by the end of the night we were starving. I would reccomend coming to Tao if you have a set reservation or know someone, otherwise you are going to be waiting in line for a long ass time. The place is like a maze and when you are drunk, figuring your way in and out is something else. During the club part, they have naked girls in the bathtubs which is pretty incredible. I couldn't stop staring. A great place to come if you are looking to throw down serious money for guareenteed good time. If you don't get bottle service, plan on trying to work your way into VIP or be sadly disappointed by the crowds surround the bar!!

Really amazing service.

Great table under "awning"  it was slightly quieter.  When we got in it was 80's music.  Gah.  It changed later.  Great knife display!

Split the Snapper on Sand.  Great #artofpresentation & amazing seasoning of flash fried fresh fish...  Lol! 

Roasted chicken dish ok...

Did I say great service?

Hated to leave anything behind.

Ate here before visiting the club and the 2 levels of seating and all around decor gives you a lot to look at. 

The club itself btw is such a thrill. Felt like partying in an Asian temple, hundreds of tea candles lighting the dance floor (where you can barely move due to overcrowding). 

I'd never tried quinoa sushi rolls before and it was delicious.

I ate here for a private dinner for 30 people (on the 3rd floor). The process of getting the dinner organized with the Tao staff was a huge pain in the ass (my good friend hosted). Basically, they know the place will be packed so if you don't want to deal with their bitchiness, they know someone else will gladly take your place.

I f-ing hate that attitude.

That said, I had the BEST veggie potstickers on the planet here. The kung pao tofu was amazing - and I'm the one who doesn't like tofu. But it was fried (like Mo Mong's tofu luc lac) and soooooo tasty.

I ordered a cappucino and it was horrific. Do not waste your money. 

I will say that once we were seated (after getting the runaround upon our arrival), the wait staff was very good. I appreciated that, bc obviously they knew a fat tip was built into the check, but they were on top of things and I didn't sense any attitude. 

Eating here is just one of those Vegas things that's nice to do at some point, if you find yourself in Vegas. And even though you swear you're not going to go to Vegas ever again, you do find yourself there. Again.

we went to tao for dinner for a bachelor's party... our party consisted of 12 people... we sat at the bar area upfront and had drinks while we waited for our table... the decor of the restaurant is really nice... the ambiance is really good... the food at the tao, ugh not so good... every dish we had was either too sweet, too salty, or over seasoned... portion sizes were small... the only dish that was semi mediocre was the sea bass... high priced less then average asian food... can definitely get better chinese/japanese/vietnamese fusion food elsewhere... h-100...

I don't really understand what all the hype is about. After hearing about this place almost every time I visited Vegas, I was quite excited about getting invited to a meal at Tao the last time I visited. Unfortunately, I was kind of let down. 

Don't get me wrong, the meal did have its high points and I saw a glimmer of what I had originally made this place out to be. They seated us relatively quickly for how absolutely packed the restaurant looked and a few of the dishes - particularly the albacore nigiri and green bean tempura - were pretty damn delicious. However, their jaunty service and sup-par special dishes left me wanting to come back for a do-over. 

Although the wait to be seated at the door wasn't bad, trying to catch a server (of which we had two who seemed to be quite distracted with their myriad other tables) took us quite a while for both our drink and dinner orders. Upon flagging one down, we placed our order (a few of her recommended favorites in the mix), and waited for our dishes.

The appetizer course - lobster wontons, green bean/avocado tempura, pork potstickers - was decent. The crispy green bean tempura and delicious sauce on the lobster wontons far outshined the heavy avocado tempura and chewy, thick pork postickers. Having ordered the miso glazed sea bass, crispy orange chicken , fatty tuna and chinese sausage fried rice as our mains, we eagerly waited the next course. While all the dishes were alright, none of them really stood out or made me want to come back and eat it again (but maybe that's not even the point with a gargatuan place like Tao?). The miso sea bass (a restaurant favorite) was cooked well, but a bit sweet. The crispy orange chicken was the biggest upset, as the promise of crunchy, tangy chicken was everything but. Neither crispy, nor flavorful. At 15 dollars an order, I was really counting on the fatty tuna to be the star, but was let down by it being a little warm for fresh nigiri and kind of floppy. The chinese sausage fried rice was good, but nothing worth almost $20. 

The saving grace came at the end of the meal in desert form. That was the one plate we cleaned entirely.The molten chocolate cake with coconut ice cream... get this if you come here. As someone who just questioned above if they'd ever return, it almost made me want to come back for more.

Such a stunning atmosphere- a little pricy but the food was great! We came here for a company Christmas Party so we had a big group... usually coming to restaurants is the worst because the waiters are overwhelmed and it makes you feel bad, but at TOA we had Jeffrey and not only was he a nice guy, but he was one of the best waiters I've ever had/seen EVER. Thank you for your hospitality Jeffrey! You made our night!

Since we were a large co-ed party of  10, it was really essential that we found a place with a hassle free door policy for the many boys in our group. And I'm pleased to announce that the night went off without a hitch! 

I'm not usually a fan of Asian fusion so my expectations were nonexistent but the menu was shockingly good:  The kimchi fried rice was perfectly balanced and the uni was pure creamy heaven. The bill was pretty reasonable considering our drunk asses were ordering like everything was free : $75/pp including tax& tip and that's AFTER covering our 2 guests of honor's split. In addition to good food and cocktails, our late dinner reservations successfully secured complimentary access to the club without a wait in line. It feels so good to stroll past the sour faces lined up outside for immediate entry. Just eat dinner here people, it's that simple!

The club was as crowded as it used to be when Jessica Simpson still had a career. Ok, maybe it's not that popping but it was still a really good showing. Oh, but whats with all the birthday shoutouts every 3 seconds? We don't care that Jennifer turned 21 and she's probably already passed out with her head in some random guy's lap. DJ: less talking, more music playing!

Went early as we had tickets for the Jersey Boys at 7.  Arrived on time for our reservation and were seated immediately, with a late request to sit near the buddha.

Service was decent.  We had to fill our wines a few times, didn't try any of the cocktails.  The wine list is fairly extensive with many options from relatively cheap (Vegas standards) to high end stuff.  (wines by the glass, not so extensive)  I ordered the pepper steak w/ udon noodles.  It was nice, although I expected more pepper for a pepper steak.  The noodles were done well and the sauce was tasty.  Overall, it was a nice dish, the problem was it's not worth the $30 they charge.  I get that this is Vegas, but there are better restaurants for that price within the Venetian.

Ambience was cool, the buddha is big, the bathrooms say yin and yang, so I walked into the wrong bathroom not knowing yin means women in some kind of Asian language.  I like the electronica playing and it was never overly loud, although we were there early.

The fortune cookies are very wise as well.  Mine read like this, "Sex is the most beautiful, natural, and wholesome thing that money can buy."  I should give them four stars just for the fortune.

There are better options for food, but if you want a hipster joint with decent food, this may be your spot.

I guess for Vegas this is suppose to be good. The front of the house was horrendous. Servers were friendly but pacing of the food was so off.  The food was ok, we had sushi and sashimi, over-priced.  I think this place is highly over-rated but I guess you go  for the ambience. I don't  think I would come back but coming from the Bay Area I have high expectations.

I have eaten here twice and both times the food has been great.  Kung Pao Chicken Was Great, The Sushi was better than average, and the fortune cookie was a great desert.  The Service However has been sub par.  The second time I went there dinner took almost 2 hours.  The place is so busy that its hard to get the attention of your server.  Expect your Cocktail to sit empty for a while before they bring you another one.  Next time I will try take out!

2 stars or 3.  Well, let's break it up.

The ambiance of course is awesome.  That's why we all want to go here, right?
The friendly waiters we had- 5 stars.  What helpful guys...Wish I had half their amount of energy.

Now for the food... Tiny portions, not out-of-this-world good at all and wayy too high prices.  I know it's the Strip and they rip you off like crazy but the prices seem higher here than the NYC restaurant and the portions and quality are better at the NY restaurant.

None of the special rolls I would recommend-- all tasted like any I could get for 7 bucks at your local take-out joint.  The salmon with crispy onions - 16 bucks for a few pieces of salmon...Unreal.  Hardly filled up with 3 tiny dishes and some sake and 100 bucks later...Well, hey it's Vegas.

1.  Too dark,  had to use phone light to read the menu,  could not see food while eating.

2.  Overpriced.

3.  Flier Mignon was super dry and bland.

We celebrated my sister's 30th birthday here. Booked a week in advance and explained that we had to be at a show by 7pm and they were great about our time restrictions and made everything happen. The staff were very fast, friendly and efficient. The food was wonderful especially the duck fried rice. The surprise birthday dessert they prepared for my sister was truly amazing (see pics) and delicious....AND fed the four of us! We loved the atmosphere and my sister said it was the best birthday dinner yet. A great dining experience!

I might be biased because I took my wife to TAO, 4 years ago, on the night we got engaged, but I love this restaurant. The ambiance is really wonderful, and they do a pretty good job of making sure that the service received and the experience is not effected by the huge amount of people that they fit in the restaurant.

The Food: I have never gotten anything on the menu that I didn't like. The Orange Chicken is good, the Peking Duck Rolls are amazing, the Egg and Sausage Rice is amazing, and ALL the sushi is fantastic. The food is all so fresh and so unique that we can't help but come back every year. I can't speak much for the beverages, but I hear that their sake selection is pretty decent as well. 

Go there to celebrate something! We have been for our anniversary two years in a row, and they don't give you a free slice of cake or bowl of ice cream, they provide a HUGE fortune cookie, filled with vanilla and chocolate mousse, and topped with all kinds of fresh fruit. It is so very delicious. My only complaint is that I leave every time with a stomach ache because the food was so good, that I couldn't stop eating. 

Go to TAO, it's worth the high price for the experience!

I am from Boston, and I do not rate places five stars unless they are worth....I would lose my Yelp credibility

First, Tao is gorgeous.  I imagine the build out must have been underwritten by the casino as a draw.  A normal restaurant probably would not have the cash to finance such a spectacular place.  Statues of Buddha adorn a very upscale place...A tip on the bathroom, the woman's room is nearest to the statue with the naked breasts

So my first thought is great place/horrible food like a RainForest Cafe, but this place really delivers great food.  The menu is all things Asian.  I guess we call that Pan-Asian.  You can eat anything from sushi to Peking Duck and beyond.

We split the Chilean Sea Bass, dumplings and duck, which were all incredible...The service was on the ball as well

If you are going to Vegas, this is a place worthy of visiting
Delicious and great environment, haven't had a bad dish here in all the years we've been coming. Love the music and that it turns into a club after hours. You really can't go wrong with Tao.

ATMOSPHERE: Romantic ambiance with a modern twist on the Buddhist and Asian-inspired designs. As you walk in, you'll see a line of bathtubs filled with rose petals and lit candles on both sides of the entrance way. The entire restaurant is clean and dimly-lit. 

FOOD QUALITY: Don't expect anything grand here for what you pay for. It's basically over-priced Chinese, Thai, and Japanese cuisine food. It's like the equivalent of eating at Panda Express or at some other Asian cuisine food court restaurant, except you're paying at least 3x as much for it. But then again, this is a restaurant right on the Vegas strip in Palazzo, so this shouldn't come as a surprise. After trying a couple of dishes, the only item that was actually good and worth its price would be the "Miso Glazed Chilean Sea Bass with Wok Vegetables" ($39.00). The fish's flavor and texture were excellent. 

SERVICE: I must say, our server Jeffrey was top-notch. He provided one of the best services I've ever had. Jeffrey was friendly, patient, and very easy to talk to. We had a group of 14 girls (bachelorette squad) and he was able to handle us like a pro. The bride's hair caught on fire from her dessert candle and one of the other servers who was passing by put it out within a second. Thanks for making sure our beautiful bride could return home to her fiance with a head full of hair.

OVERALL EXPERIENCE: It's a good place to go to mainly for the atmosphere and service, just don't expect to be blown away by the quality of the food. Not saying the food was bad, it's just that you can get the same quality of food elsewhere for much cheaper. Also, there are so many better restaurant options in Vegas with high-quality service, atmosphere, AND food.

My friend was in town and we wanted to go somewhere with a "scene," that simultaneously had good food.  Needless to say, Tao was not the right spot for us.  As for the "scene," Tao pretty much hits the mark.  It is a beautiful restaurant, dimly lit, and plenty of Las Vegas visitors looking for a good time.  As for the food, it was very mediocre.  I will not be returning.  On a busy Saturday night in Las Vegas without a reservation, we waited for our table for about 30 minutes.  Not bad, huh?  Well with the 40 bucks we tipped the hostess to get a table at all, I was expecting to be seated right away.  I want my 40 bucks back! Oh well, live and learn.  On to the food.  Between the two of us we split the chefs special roll, shrimp tempura roll, spicy yellowtail crunchy onion roll, lobster wontons, shishito peppers, vegetable brown fried rice, and edamame.  Sounds like a lot of food, but the portions are small.  This was definitely enough food for us though.  The sushi was really not impressive.  Yes, the fish is fresh, but unless you are ordering sashimi, it is still possible to get a bad roll.  Well, we got three.  The worst was the shrimp tempura roll.  So small! So bland! So boring! Come on, if you are going to list this a chefs speciality, it better be special.  The other two rolls were a little better, but both sitting on top of a heavy mayo sauce that did not taste good.  This is my pet peeve.  Leave off the heavy sauce people! Especially if it tastes like crap.  The lobster wontons were pretty decent, I could only eat one because they were rich, turn your stomach kind of rich- too saucy, too salty, too something.  I will say the vegetable brown fried rice was pretty good.  This "healthier" version of fried rice was packed with veggies and had a great flavor, the only downfall here is that it was served to us ice cold.  The best thing at this restaurant by far was the shishito peppers! I swear these should be on every asian restaurant menu.  I cant imagine it is too difficult to roast these bad boys up, but regardless, Tao did a good job here.  If you haven't tried these peppers before, please try them!  I wouldn't steer you in the wrong direction.  Anyway, I may come back to Tao for a drink, but as for food, I will take my sushi/ asian craving elsewhere.

We showed up an hour late for our Saturday night reservation. I assumed the worst... The manager Brooke handled everything above and beyond my expectations. Our party of 4 was seated within 20 minutes despite a full dining room. Food and service was on point. Thank you Brooke for such a great fix to our getting too drunk at the pool and almost ruining and missing our dinner.

Tao is your typical asian fusion restaurant that caters towards the American tastebud. It's like a fancy PF Chang's with Japanese food, chinese food, Thai food, korean food, a little bit of everything.
To start off, the service was amazing from start to finish. Our waiter gave us his recommendations for the food and checked up on us throughout our dinner enough for us to have everything we needed but not so much where we felt uncomfortable. Our water cups were constantly filled, if we had taken a sip they would come and fill it back up to the top. Everyone had a friendly smile on their face and seemed genuinely interested in making our dining experience great and it was! ... at least in the service aspect.
Now for the food, we ordered the sizzling fried size with roast pork, chinese 5 spices ribs, crispy pork bao buns, and a chicken pad Thai. The crispy pork and chinese 5 spices ribs were probably the best dishes of the four but they weren't great either. The sizzling fried rice was kind of dry and the pork looked like something I would find in a $3 breakfast burrito back in the middle school days. And the pad Thai, I couldn't even eat it. We took it for take out and I tried to eat it again as a drunchie and it still tasted horrible and it says a lot if food tastes bad when you're drunk.
If it weren't for the service and the ambience of the restaurant I probably would have given 3 stars but I probably would return again to try the sushi (which seemed popular) and other dishes. And mostly for the service and ambience.

This past weekend I had home to Vegas with my friends and then I met this amazing guy there and he wanted to take me to dinner... He said I'll look for something and looked at the reviews on yelp and made reservations! 

As soon as we walked in I could tell he was really into making an impression because the decor was stunning!  The atmosphere was elegant and sophisticated. 

Our server was amazing and patient.  We sat down and started the whole first date questions and every time our server would come we would me so wrapped up in our conversation we would forget to order lol.  But our server was more than happy to come back every time. 

The food was amazing, my date said he didn't like salmon because it was too fishy but he has a taste of my plate and was so amazed.  The sauces were amazing and I have tried salmon every where and this was definitely in my top 3!!  

Go here is you want a great dinner and time away from the whole party scene for a while.  It's so great!

Tao Asian Bistro is located in The Venetian hotel right next to TAO nightclub. Deciding what to order here was not easy since there is a variety of dishes to choose from but eventually we ordered the scallops, sashimi and pad Thai noodles. Everything was delicious as well as our drinks. This place is perfect for a date or with friends. We asked our waiter if we can get in the night club after dinner without having to wait in those long lines and he was very nice enough to direct us with the right people. We got stamped and had immediate access to the club. Food and service here is awesome!

The Verdict: "The ultimate zen experience."

Items ordered: pork chow mein, sushi, other fusion dishes

[Pros]
+Awesome decor with bathtubs filled with petals and candles lighting the dim entryways and a massive buddha statue in the main dining area
+Great food, my favorite was the garlicky, pork chow mein
+Polite service 

[Cons]
-Pricey (but it's worth the experience)
-Drinks are really pricey with small proportions 

Would I Recommend It?: Yes, a great place to hit if you are in Vegas! Great spot for pictures too!

It's been at least three or four years since I've been to Tao, but I would definitely go again and given a second great experience would gladly give it five stars. The first time I went was for my birthday. I ordered a drink, they checked my ID, and said nothing about my birthday from what I can remember. Later in the evening they brought me out a free dessert with "Happy Birthday" written in chocolate over the plate. The gesture was sweet, the fine dining experience was superb, and it's had many celebrities come through because of it's high quality reputation!

My boyfriend and I recently came here for an early Christmas celebration dinner. Yes it was pricey, but hey that's the strip for ya. Ambiance wise this place was outstanding. The decor is beautiful and elegant, but also trendy. The music was definitely more club like, but not too unbearably loud like some other restaurants tend to be.

As for the food, wow, delicious. We started with the tuna tartare small plate to share. The tuna was a bit spicy, but not too overpowering and I loved the different textures. We also shared the crispy thai pork and spring mountain roll. The pork was absolutely delicious! It came with mushrooms, onions and peppers also mixed in. The sushi roll was good, but nothing outstanding. Can't forget dessert too! I'm typically not one for fortune cookies, but this giant beast was pretty good. I especially enjoyed the fresh fruit garnish and vanilla cream filling.

A great date night spot for when you're looking to splurge a little bit. I highly recommend the tuna tartare on crispy rice and crispy thai pork!

First time diner, long time clubber. Me and eleven other "bachelors" enjoyed an incredible time at Tao for a friends stag party.

After three glasses of wine I honestly can't remember what appetizers we had but they were the bomb-ass rap song. If you don't believe me, ask L.A. Lakers Robert Horry - he was at the table next to us saying hells yeah... or maybe, "As usual, I'll take the check." I wonder if he knew that the hot red head sitting next to him just came over to our table and advertised the strip club where she would be working later that night?

Our server Sereka was the cats meow. Not only could she handle 12 crazy men, but she helped us haze the groom. She hand picked a table of bachelorettes for us to send a comp bottle of champagne. Imagine the groom-to-be's surprise when 10 boa-clad bachelorettes came over and personally thanked him for the bubbly.

Oh, and definitely get the miso sea bass - delicious!

4.5 * stars

Ever since I ate here, I have been dreaming about the dish I ordered. I ordered the Salmon Sashimi with onion and avocado and it was superb. I have to admit I came in quite hungry so if I would have known I was only going to get four pieces, I would have ordered more. The environment is very dim and relaxing and the service was great. The menu is pricey, but totally worth it. My bf ordered a saki martini that tasted wooonderful. I can't wait to go back and next time get to visit the Tao Nightclub next time (it was closed when we visited.)

My girl's bachelorette pack wandered in here a little after 2 or 3 a.m. The ambience and decor is nice - one friend tried to dip her feet in the rose petal covered "baths" that line the entrance, that is until security reprimanded her.

We were already pretty tipsy so we didn't have anymore drinks, we were just there for the music and, quite frankly, since we stayed at the Venetian it was the most convenient, and open place for us to go. I guess that it kind of won by default but we still liked it. 

They have cool buddist projections on the dimly lit walls, and the hallway to the restroom is lined in buddist monk art. They should have named this place Buddist because of all the bodacious Buddist decor at every corner.

Anyway, the only negative is that we tried to explore the upper level, but got denied because we didn't have a stamp on our hand. Not sure what that stamp was, or where to get it, but it was probably a buddah head. Oh well, we enjoyed ourselves anyway. But be forewarned that if you head in at the wee hours of the night, there are drunks o plenty who are full of brave juice and you'll have to either laugh em off or swat them away like flies! Either way it makes for some hilarious times!

My favorite place to eat in Vegas!! Been here many times and I always come back. The atmosphere is cool, the service is always great and the food is amazing! I always end up with sea bass, sometimes the skewers, sometimes the miso glazed sea bass filet. Hands down, the best sea bass ever! But I'm constantly sharing appetizers and tasting other's food too and honestly, you can't go wrong. The presentation is beautiful and the flavors are amazing! I'll keep coming back every time I'm in Vegas.

We made reservations at Tao after hearing good things and it lived up to our expectations. My favorites out of everything our group of 4 ordered were the Pork Spring Rolls with Thai Chili Sauce, Unagi, and Chinese Sausage Fried Rice. I took off one star because you don't get good portions for the price and one of our dishes was just okay. The decor is very nice though. We were seated right beside the giant buddha over a pool of koi. Since we had dinner, we were given a stamp for free entry into the upstairs club which unfortunately wasn't as good as the restaurant.

I love the setting and the mood of this place. I've tried a small number of different entrees here, and the only thing i would recommend anyone getting would be the Typhoon Lobster with Fingerling Potatoes. They serve you a whole damn lobster and more for $45!! then, you get free entry to TAO nightclub. awesome!

Insanely good Sea Bass and delicious pad thai but more than anything the atmosphere makes this place amazing.  Even the girls laying in rose pedals when you walk in left an impression.  The food was forgettable while everything that I saw around me made a lasting impression.

We were celebrating a friend's birthday in Vegas and decided to dine at Tao, as had heard raving reviews about it.  The ambiance is great.  Love the dimly lit dining area, with a huge Buddha statue in the center.  Definitely reminded me of Buddha Bar in New York.

We got reservations easily and were seated promptly.  Our server was extremely friendly and even recommended drinks and food options.  I wish I remembered his name, so I could call him out.  But overall, great service.

Here is what I ordered:
- Hot Edamame: Standard dish and was good to munch on as we waited for our food to arrive.
- Bamboo Steamed Vegetable Dumplings with Crunchy Cucumbers: This was the best thing I had all night.  This is so good that even my non-vegetarian friends ended up my share, and I had to order another one.  I could have just ordered a bunch of these for my dinner.  Definitely order this for the table...its too good.
- Pad Thai Noodles: This was disappointing.  It lacked flavor that Pad Thai usually has.  After eating the veggie dumplings, this was definitely a let down.

Overall, the food was mediocre, with the exception of the Veggie Dumplings that were amazing.

The kobe beef dumplings were our favorite.  I think they were a special that night, but they should be on the menu.  The nigiri was fresh, and Tao has a nice wine list.  We ordered plates to share, just a bit at a time, and we never felt rushed.

Asian fusion at the Venetian.  Prices are your typical Vegas on-the-strip prices, which means they are overpriced.  The entrees themselves are well prepared, but the atmosphere oozes of pretension.  

P.S.  What's with the creepy baby statues strung along the wall where the hostess checks in people?

Came here for my birthday dinner and it wasn't as special as I thought it was gonna be, just another overpriced restaurant with mediocre food, it just wasn't worth it, the duck fried rice was decent at best the sushi below average and the ambience was cool and that's about it, nothing spectacular.

Checked in for our 10pm reservation. Were finally seated by 10:35pm. They sat us at a table that didn't fit our group. When someone in our group inquired about the available booth, they should have said no, you have too many people. Instead we were squished in like sardines. Menu is very limited, quality nothing to write home about. They gave us all sticky forks, and we had to ask for new ones. Service was average. Atmosphere was mostly watching people walk up to the club.  There are better places with similar cuisine in Vegas.Did not meet expectations.

The decor is nice - but by Vegas standards it's meh.
The only thing I liked here was the tuna on crispy rice. 
.......nuff said.

Every single time I go to Vegas, I go to Tao. 
I love their food & drinks. 
They are awesome! 
I love this place! 
Tao is my Favorite Restaurant in Vegas!

I love this place! Partly for the fond memories surrounding us going, but the food was fantastic! I had never been a fan of sushi before (in fact, had a few bad experiences with sushi) but was willing to try a "good" place. Wow! So yummy!! Highly recommend it! 

There were four of us in the party and we didn't have reservations--highly recommend you make reservations--so we had to wait for like an hour. We sat in the bar downstairs and got properly drunk while we waited. By the time we were heading to our table, it was standing room only, and difficult to move.

As with everything else in Vegas, it's pricey. But worth it. With dinner, you get a hand stamp to get into the club upstairs for free. That was pretty cool. Unfortunately I was with some people that didn't want to go to the club, so I just poked my head in and looked around but didn't stay.

The bathrooms were very cool too.

It was almost midnight when we settled the bill and left. The place was PACKED and the music was loud, but enjoyable. I'd definitely go back again and again!

The only downside, besides being pricey, was that it was hard to find inside the Venetian. I'm not sure which entrance it's at, but I always get lost inside The Venetian!

I truly have not had a bad experience at Tao. The quality of the service is great and the food is excellent. 
The sushi is always nice and fresh and the Main entrees are delicious. I would recommend to get the crab cakes for appetizer. They are meaty and very tasty. The glazed miso cod is one of the best things on the menu. For side dishes you can never go wrong with the fried rice or the noodles. And for dessert, well you have to get the amazing fortune cookie. This is a giant fortune cookie with half chocolate and half cream! It's just delish! 
If you are planning on visiting Tao you will be pleased with the food. However, the restaurant is not cheap. Well I guess you get for what you pay!

If you haven't read, most clubs in Las Vegas are extremely hard to get into without paying a host. XS, Marquee are probably the hottest night clubs right now in Vegas but don't count out Tao. Once midnight hits and the patio is open Tao is shoulder to shoulder busy with people all over the place partying.

We all took advantage of the popularity of Tao nightclub by eating at Tao which provides expedited access to their night club.

My initial impressions of Tao was a restaurant trying to cash in on the Asian theme. When you walk into Tao and see how it opens up however, you're quickly reminded that a lot of thought had gone into designing the space. Lights are dim to set the mood which plays off the color scheme quite well. A giant Buddha statue sits in the middle of an open hall that spans two floors. Asian art is hung everywhere with bamboo vegetation. At the same time, it wasn't hokey, I really appreciated what they were trying to do here.

Onto the food itself, our parties ordered a large number of appetizers which were delectable. I suggest the sashimi platter which had bite-sized party-in-your-mouth morsels of deliciousness.
My main meal was a deep sea dive scallops in basil curry. If you had a bowl of rice to this dish, it is such a full complete meal considering. The sauce was rich and the scallops itself were very large.

I would definitely recommend you explore other sea food dishes as my samplings of them were also quite rich.

Somewhere around 3.5 stars for dinner for me.  Nice decor and vibe.  Dinner was a little fast-paced...I had read that Tao was the top-grossing restaurant in the U.S. (probably with the club receipts), and I realize that means table turnover is crucial, but it's not like we were four girls taking up the table for hours after splitting a salad.  Food was tasty -- loved the squab lettuce wraps and yes, the chilean sea bass (although isn't it still on the do-not-eat list?) melts in your mouth.  Not sure if that one's worth the guilt.

Drinkwise, the Taotini is the way to go...it's like juice and is practically a value drink at $10.

I've been to Tao many times, but never actually sat down for dinner until I went to Vegas last weekend. I got to say, I was very impressed. I went on a Sunday (holiday weekend) and the wait was about 30 minutes. We had a drink in the lounge area so it wasn't bad. The music and ambiance were perfect. Once we were seated, we had nothing but GREAT service. Our server was extremely friendly and knowledgeable and our food came out super fast. We ordered the lobster wontons, the trio of sashimi with wasabi salsa (I'm not a big fan of wasabi, but this was sooo good!), sea bass with asparagus, and the chef's roll. Everything we ordered was delicious, however the chef's roll was okay.

Again, the servers there were great. It was a team effort. If another server saw that we had a question or had finished our plates, he/she would come right away. Anyway, if you're looking for a restaurant that has great food plus a fun and fresh atmosphere, Tao is perfect. 

P.S - I took off one star because this place is a little pricey and the portions are a bit small too.

7:30pm reservation.  Arrived on-time and seated promptly.  The place was already packed and there was a good vibe.  Not too loud, not too quiet.  Our waitress was very friendly, responsive, and timely.

Drinks- Tao-tini..  They were good.  Smooth and wound up putting back quite a few through the dinner.  Didn't really feel the effects so I'm thinking the "smoothness" was perhaps just a lack of alcohol.

There was a chef's tasting menu being offered this night for an unbelievable $55.  Super cheap.  Both the gf and I went with this option.  First course- spicy tuna tartare over crispy rice.  Yum.  She went with the thai stuffed shrimp.  Again yum.

Second course-  Fried vegetable rice.. eh ok.  She went with the roasted peppers.  Neither of us enjoyed as they were extremely bitter and wound up each only taking two bites.

Third course-  Wasabi crusted filet with tempura onion rings.  Two others at the table also ordered this and theirs was cooked perfect medium.  Unfortunately I ordered the same temperature and was brought a completely rare piece of meat.  After taking the piece back to the kitchen, it returned 5 minutes later completely charred on the outside yet still very much rare on the inside.  I'm not one to send a piece of steak back twice, so I just left it alone.  I finished the 1/2 of my gf's perfectly cooked filet.

Fourth course-  Chocolate spring rolls and a citrus dipping sauce.  Very good and very rich.  Juniper apple blossom with vanilla ice cream.  Nothing special, but good none the less.

If we didn't get such a great deal with the tasting menu, I know my review would be completely different based on my filet mignon not being cooked to order two times, and eventually just giving up on that course.  With that aside, I did enjoy myself and the majority of the meal was very good.... btw... if you order a coffee with Bailey's, it is brought out in a mug large enough to wash your hands.
Amazing atmosphere, amazing food, amazing service. The food was inspiring and delicious, the service impeccable, a highlight of my vegas trip!

I had visited the restaraunt in the past. Came back for a second visit. This place is great.
Love the food. Loved the server. She was helpful with suggestions.
I would return again and again if I lived in Vegas.

Was surprised this was rated only 3.5 stars on Yelp.  Had a great dinner last night.  Ambience and service were great, and food was very good!  Fun specialty cocktail menu and diverse wine list.  Best Asian bistro I've ever been to, and highly recommended.

Came here on a girls trip and did the dinner/bottle service bundle. There were 11 of us and we each paid about $160 for the 3 course meal. It was totally worth it! We got two bottles of Jameson 

You have the option to choose your own three course meal OR you can do a family style dining where you get a large portion of EVERYTHING on the menu. We went with the family style and it was extremely worth it. We got huge portions of each course.

For appetizers we had the temple salad, sea bass, and chicken gyoza. The salad had to be my favorite of the three. The sea bass was also very delicious.

For the entree we had the salmon, coconut shrimp, and orange chicken. I wasn't a big fan of the salmon and i don't think anyone else was either. The shrimp however was a big hit, i really enjoyed the size and the peanut curry glaze! I had about two of them and I was already full. The orange chicken had good flavor but it was really dry like the chicken was over cooked.

For dessert we got fried chocolate spring rolls, yoga sugar dusted donuts, and seasonal fresh fruit with mandarin ice cream! The fresh fruits came with kiwis, blueberries, mangoes, grapes, blackberries, strawberries, and raspberries! The donuts were really good and tasted fresh. I wasn't a big fan of the spring rolls with dark chocolate like inside. 

After every course, the servers would come by and change our plates and utensils. The food came out quickly which is definitely a plus!

Overall, if you go with a group of friends I definitely recommend the dinner style! you get to try all the goodies AND it comes with huge portions!

I am giving Tao 4 stars based on my other experiences in Las Vegas, particularly on the Strip.  Restaurants there are generally over-priced.  You have to remember that Las Vegas is far from any port so if you are visiting from a town where they choose their fish daily from the port side fish market and you like seafood, they have a bit of a challenge here.
We went with a group of 7. We enjoyed both the bar and the restaurant.  Another yelper complained about the glass wine list, I don't mind trying new wines so I actually thought it was a good list.  
This is not a place to go for group discussion, you can't hear across the table.  But so long as you have good dinner partners on either side of you, you'll have a great time.  Beautiful People watching gets an A+.  The vibe and the atmosphere is definitely fun.
Most of our party got the miso seabass which as someone mentioned miso fish (officially called "saikyo" preparation in Japanese) is always good.  I was very happy with my seafood hotpot that included nice sized scallops, shrimp and chunks of lobster.  
At the bar they serve complementary wasabi dried peas that are totally addictive.
We were at the Venetian for a trade show and had a big day following so we didn't take advantage of the VIP tickets to the club that they gave us with our dinner.

The worst Asian fusion restaurant and also the most overrated and overpriced. Seriously the only reason why this restaurant still exists is because of tourists who eat here hoping to get a spot into the Tao club. Don't waste your money eating here. The decor is cool and over the top which is good for Vegas life but that's about it. 

I ordered filet mignon mixed with Chinese broccoli and green peppers. Terrible. Super super salty drenched in heavy oyster sauce. And filet mignon didn't even taste like high quality beef- tasted like cheap beef from a Chinese restaurant for $ in your local area; And yet they're charging $$$ here. Truly a joke. Everything we ordered was so bad I refused to order anymore. Flavors are just off- either too salty, too greasy, too sweet or a combination of everything. The only things that were decent were the drinks and the large fortune cookie for dessert. And it seems like all the waiters come by for is to check if you want to order more food meaning spend more money, but we know better than that. It's just all for show and the glitz and glamour. 

Bottom line is if you want better Asian cuisine, go eat at your local restaurants for $ or $$ and I'm certain it'll taste way better than this. But if you really want to go to the Tao club, go early but do yourself a favor and save your money for a decent meal somewhere else in Vegas.

First time ever eating at any TAO restaurant, and we had such incredible service and food we had to come back two days later before we left Vegas. 
We ordered the Peking duck, lobster wontons, miso soup, coconut shrimp, vegetable fried rice and the spring mountain sushi roll. I wasn't disappointed with anything, however my personal favorites were the lobster wontons and the Peking duck. The portion size of the Peking duck is huge. While priced per person, it really is huge and would definitely recommend only having a light appetizer or no appetizer when ordering because the portion size is so big. Would definitely come back.

Oh man were do I begin?! We weren't seated right away, party of 11, bc not everyone was there. Pretty stupid if you ask me. Then we had the most snarky waiter I have ever met. He was probably 37, acting like he was 13 and a pube. He obviously hates his life. He didn't give our entire table menus, only a select few. And he gave us ONE drink list. When he asked us if there was anything else he could do for us, in a very fresh tone, I leaned in and told him to dial down the sass. Needless to say we were then approached by a waitress for a dual effort. The food was good but you have to order several plates to make you full. By the time it finally arrives at the table, good luck trying to remember what is what. It all looks and tastes relatively the same. One positive thing, the sushi was great. Management definitely relies on the fact that this place is considered trendy. I would pass, unless you hate the person you are with lol

So far I have to say that this is my favorite restaurant in Las Vegas. I haven't had any of the sushi here but bet it is good. I've had scallops that were delicious and the miso soup. OMG!

First of all this place gets a 5 for ambiance. The two-story tall Buddha statue looks like something I would put in my house if I was a millionare. I love Asian decor. I have a much smaller red Buddha in my condo as we speak. I love the Koi pond and this place is just cool. What can I say. It's not just the place. It literally makes you feel like a cooler person when you walk in here. The food is awesome. Nothing on the menu is bad. I've had steak entrees that were great and everything else is just delicious. The miso clam soup is soo good. They put whole clams in the shell into your soup. I don't know who thought this would work but it actually does! Delicious. I love Tao.
